most vvorthy to be serued:
Then from my foes I am right sure
that I shall be preserued.
The pangs of death did compasse me,
and bound me euery vvhere:
The flovving vvaues of vvickednesse
did put me in great feare
The flye and subtill snares of hell
vvere round about me set:
And for my death there vvas preparde
a deadly trapping net.
I thus beset vvith paine and griefe,
did pray to God for grace:
And he forth-vvith did heare my plaint
out of his holy place.
Such is his povver that in his vvrath,
he made the earth to quake:
Yea, the foundation of the mount
of Basan for to shake.
And from his nostrils came a smoake,
vvhen kindled vvas his ire:
And from his mouth came kindled coals
of hot consuming fire.
The Lord descended from aboue,
and bov • ed the heauens hie:
And vnderneath his feet he cast
the darke • esse of the skie.
On Cherubs and on Cherubin •
full royally he road:
And on the vvings of all the vvindes,
came flying all abroad.
And like a den most darke he made
his hid and secret place:
VVith vvaters black and ayrie clouds,
enuironed he vvas.
But vvhen the presence of his face
in brightnesse shall appeare:
The clouds consume, and in their stead
came hayle and coales of fire.
These fiery darts and thunderbolts
disperse them here and there:
And vvith his often lightenings,
he puts them in great feare.
Lord at thy vvrath and threatnings,
and at thy chiding cheare:
The springs a • d the foundations
of all the vvorld appeare.
And from aboue the Lord sent dovvne
to fetch me from belovv:
And pluckt me out of vvaters great,
that vvould me ouerflovv.
And me deliuered from my foes
that vvould haue made me thrall.
Yea, from such foes as vvere too strong
for me to deale vvithall.
They did preuent me to oppresse
in time of my great griefe:
But yet the Lord vvas my defence,
my succour and reliefe.
He brought me forth in open place,
vvhereas I might be free:
And kept me safe because he had
a fauour vnto me.
And as I vvas an innocent,
so did he me regard:
And to the cleannesse of my hands,
he gaue me my revvard.
For that I vvalked in his vvayes,
and in his pathes haue trod:
And haue not vvauered vvickedly
against my Lord and God.
But euermore I haue respect
to his lavv and decree
His statutes and commandements
I cast not out from me.
But pure, and cleane, and vncorrupt,
appearde before his face:
And did refraine from vvickednesse▪
and sinne in any case.
The Lord therefore vvill me revvard
as I haue done aright:
And to the cleannesse of my hands
appearing in his sight.
For Lord vvith him that holy is,
vvilt thou be holy too:
And vvith the good and vertuous men,
right vertuously vvilt doe.
And to the louing and elect,
thy loue thou vvilt reserue:
And thou vvilt vse the vvicked men,
as vvicked men deserue.
For thou dost saue the simple folke,
in trouble vvhen they lye:
And dost bring dovvne the countenance
of them that looke full hie.
The Lord vvill light my candle so,
that it shall shine full bright:
The Lord my God vvill make also
my darknesse to be light:
For by thy help an hoa •• of men
discomfit Lord I shall:
By thee I scale and ouer-leape
the strength of any vvall.
Vnspotted are the vvayes of God:
his vvord is purely tride:
He is a sure defence to such,
as in his faith abide.
For vvho is God except the Lord?
for other there is none:
Or else vvho is omnipotent,
sauing our God alone?
The God that girdeth me vvith strēgth
is he that I doe meane:
That all the vvayes vvherein I vvalke
did euermore keepe cleane.
That made my feete like to the Harts
in svviftnesse of my pace:
And for my surety brought me forth
into an open place.
He did in order put my hands,
to battaile and to fight:
To breake in sunder bars of brasse,
he gaue mine armes the might.
Thou teachest me thy sauing health,
thy right hand is my tovver▪
Thy loue and familiaritie
doth still increase my povver.
And vnder me thou makest plaine
the vvay vvhere I should vvalke:
So that my feet shall neuer slip,
nor stumble at a balke:
And fiercely I pursue and take
my foes that me anoyd:
And from the field doe not returne
till they be cleane destroyd.
So I suppresse and vvound my foes,
that they can rise no more:
For at my feet they fall dovvne flat,
I strike them all so sore.
For thou dost gird me vvith thy strength,
to vvarre in such a vvise:
That they be all scattred abroad
that vp against me rise.
Lord thou hast put into my hands
my mortall enemies yoke:
And all my foes thou dost diuide,
in sunder vvith thy stroke.
They cald for help, but none gaue eare
nor holpe them vvith reliefe:
Yea, to the Lord they cald for helpe,
yet heard he not their griefe.
And still like dust before the vvinde,
I driue them vnder feet:
And svveepe them out like filthy clay,
that stinketh in the street.
Thou keepst me from seditious folke,
that still in strife be led:
And thou dost of the heathen folke
appoint me to be head.
A people strange to me vnknovvne,
and yet they shall me serue:
And at the first obey my vvord,
vvhereas mine ovvne vvill svverue.
I shall be irkesome to mine ovvne,
they shall not see my light.
But vvander vvide out of their vvayes▪
and hide them out of sight.
But blessed be the liuing Lord,
most vvorthy of all praise:
That is my rocke and sauing health,
praised be he alvvayes.
For God it is that gaue me povver,
reuenged for to be:
And vvith his holy vvord subdude
the people vnto me.
And from my foes me deliuered,
and set me higher then those,
That cruell and vngodly vvere,
and vp against me rose.
And for this cause O Lord my God,
to thee giue thanks I shall:
And sing out praises to thy name,
among the Gentiles all.
That gauest great prosperitie
vnto the king I say:
To Dauid thine annointed king,
and to his seed for aye.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
THe heauens and the firmament doe vvondrously declare
〈♫〉
The glory of God omnipotent, his vvorkes and vvhat they are.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
THe heauens and the firmament doe vvondrously declare

〈♫〉
The glory of God omnipotent, his vvorkes and vvhat they are.

div.head: TENOR, or Playnsong.
div.l:
☞ 〈♫〉
THe heauens and the firmament doe vvondrously declare

〈♫〉
The glory of God omnipotent, his vvorkes and vvhat they are.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
THe heauens and the firmament doe vvondrously declare

〈♫〉
The glory of God omnipotent, his vvorkes and vvhat they are.

lg.l: The vvondrous vvorks of God appeare
by euery dayes successe:
The nights vvhich likevvise their race run
the selfe same things expresse.
There is no language, tongue or speech
vvhere their sound is not heard:
In all the earth and coasts thereof,
their knovvledge is conferd.
In them the Lord made for the Sunne
a place of great renovvne:
VVho like a bridegroome ready trimde,
doth from his chamber come.
And as a valiant champion▪
vvho for to get a prize:
VVith ioy doth haste to take in hand
some noble enterprise.
And all the Skie from end to end,
he compasseth about:
Nothing can hide it from his heate,
but he vvill finde it out.
Hovv perfect is the Lavv of God,
hovv is his couenant sure?
Conuerting soules, and making vvise
the simple and obscure.
Iust are the Lords Commandements,
and glad both heart and minde:
His precepts pure, and giueth light
to eyes that be full blinde.
The feare of God is excellent,
and doth endure for euer:
The iudgements of the Lord are true,
and righteous altogether.
And more to be imbrac'de alvvayes,
then fined gold I say▪
The honey and the honey combe
are not so svveet as they.
By them thy seruant is forevvarnd
to haue God in regard:
And in performance of the same.
there shall be great revvard,
But Lord vvhat earthly man doth knovv
the errors of his life?
Then cleanse my soule from secret sins,
vvhich are in me most rife.
And keepe me that presumptuous sins
preuaile not ouer me:
And so shall I be innocent,
and great offences flye.
Accept my mouth and eke my heart.
my vvords and thoughts each one:
For my Redeemer and my strength
O Lord thou art alone.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
IN trouble and aduersitie, the Lord God heare thee still:

〈♫〉
The maiestie of Ia- cobs God de- fend thee from all ill.

div.head: Psalme 20.
MEDIVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
IN trouble and aduersitie, the Lord God heare thee still:

〈♫〉
The maiestie of Iacobs God, defend thee from all ill.

div.head: TENOR, or Playnsong.
div.l:
☞ 〈♫〉
IN trouble and aduersitie, the Lord God heare thee still:

〈♫〉
The maiestie of Iacobs God defend thee from all ill.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
IN trouble and aduersitie, the Lord God heare thee still:

〈♫〉
The maiestie of Ia- cobs God, defend thee from all ill.

lg.l: And send thee from his holy place,
his help at euery need:
And so in Sion stablish thee,
and make thee strong indeed.
Remembring vvell the sacrifice
that novv to him is done:
And so receiue right thankfully,
thy burnt offerings each one.
According to thy hearts desire,
the Lord grant vnto thee:
And all thy counsell and deuice
full vvell performe may he.
VVe shall reioyce vvhen thou vs sauest,
and our banners display:
Vnto the Lord vvhich thy requests,
fulfilled hath alvvay.
The Lord vvill his annointed saue
I knovv vvell by his grace:
And send him health by his right hand,
out of his holy place.
In chariots some put confidence,
and some in horses trust:
But vve remember God our Lord,
that keepeth promise iust.
They fall dovvne flat, but vve doe rise
and stand vp stedfastly:
Novv saue and helpe vs Lord and King,
on thee vvhen vve doe cry.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
O Lord hovv ioyfull is the king in thy strength and thy povver? Hovv
〈♫〉
vehemently doth he reioyce in thee his Sauiour? For thou hast giuen vnto him
〈♫〉
his godly hearts desire: to him nothing hast thou denide, of that he did require.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
O Lord hovv ioyfull is the King in thy strength and thy povver? Hovv
〈♫〉
vehemently doth he reioyce in thee his Sauiour? For thou hast giuen vnto him
〈♫〉
his godly hearts desire, to him nothing hast thou denide, of that he did require.

div.head: TENOR, or Playnsong.
div.p:
☞ 〈♫〉
O Lord hovv ioyfull is the King in thy strength and thy povver? Hovv
〈♫〉
vehemently doth he reioyce in thee his Sauiour? For thou hast giuen vnto him
〈♫〉
his godly hearts desire: to him nothing hast thou denide, of that he did require.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
O Lord hovv ioyfull is the King in my strength and thy povver? Hovv
〈♫〉
vehemently doth he reioyce in thee his Sauiour? For thou hast giuen vnto him
〈♫〉
his godly hearts desire: to him nothing hast thou denide, of that he did require.

lg.l: Thou didst preuent him vvith thy gifts
and blessings manifold:
And thou hast set vpon his head
a crovvne of perfect gold.
And vvhen he asked life of thee,
thereof thou mad'st him sure
To haue long life, yea such a life
as euer should endure.
Great is his glory by thy helpe
thy benefits and aide:
Great vvorship and great honour both
thou hast vpon him laid.
Thou vvilt giue him felicitie
that neuer shall decay:
And vvith thy chearfull countenance
vvilt comfort him alvvay.
For vvhy? the King doth strongly trust
in God for to preuaile:
Therefore his goodnesse and his grace
vvill not that he shall quaile.
But let thine enemies feele thy force,
aed those that thee vvithstand:
Finde out thy foes, and let them feele
the povver of thy right hand.
And like an Ouen burne them Lord
in fiery flame and fume:
Thine anger shall destroy them all,
and fire shall them consume.
And thou vvilt root out of the earth,
their fruit that should increase:
And from the number of thy flocke,
their seed shall end and cease.
For vvhy? much mischief did they muse
against thy holy name:
Yet did they faile, and had no povver
for to performe the same▪
But as a marke thou shalt them set
in a more open place:
And charge thy bovv-strings readily
against thine enemies face.
Be thou exalted Lord therefore,
in thy strength euery houre:
So shall vve sing right solemnly,
praysing thy might and povver.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
O God my God vvherefore dost thou forsake me vtterly? And helpest
〈♫〉
not vvhen I doe make my great complaint and cry?

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
O God my God, vvherefore dost thou forsake me vtterly? And helpest
〈♫〉
not vvhen I doe make my great complaint and cry?

div.head: TENOR, or Playnsong.
div.p:
☞ 〈♫〉
O God my God, vvherefore dost thou forsake me vtterly? And helpest
〈♫〉
not vvhen I doe make my great complaint and cry?

div.head: BASSVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
O God my God, vvherefore dost thou forsake me vtterly? And helpest
〈♫〉
not vvhen I doe make my great complaint and cry?

lg.l: To thee my God euen all day long,
I doe both cry and call:
I cease not all the night, and yet
thou hearest not at all.
Euen thou that in thy Sanctuary,
and holy place dost dvvell:
Thou art the comfort and the ioy,
and glory of Israel.
And he in vvhom our fathers old,
had all their hope for euer:
And vvhen they put their trust in thee,
so dost thou them deliuer,
They vvere deliuered euer vvhen
they called on thy name:
And for the faith they had in thee,
they vvere not put to shame.
But I am novv become a vvorme
more like then any man:
An out-cast vvhom the people scorne,
vvith all the spight they can.
And me despise as they behold
me vvalking on the vvay:
They grin, they movv, they nod their heads
and in this vvise they say.
This man did glory in the Lord,
his fauour and his loue:
Let him redeeme and helpe him novv,
his povver if he vvill proue.
But Lord out of my mothers vvombe,
I came by thy request:
Thou didst preserue mee still in hope,
vvhile I did sucke her brest.
I vvas committed from my birth,
vvith thee to haue abode:
Since I vvas in my mothers vvombe,
thou hast beene euer my God.
Then Lord depart not novv from me
in this my present griefe:
Since I haue none to be my helpe,
my succour and reliefe.
So many Bulles doe compasse me,
that be full strong of head:
Yea, Buls so fat as though they had
in Basan field beene fed.
They gape vpon me greedily,
as though they vvould me stay:
Much like a Lyon roaring out,
and ramping for his prey.
But I drop dovvne like vvater shed,
my ioynts in sunder breake:
My heart doth in my body melt,
like vvaxe against the heat.
And like a potsheard dryth my strēgth,
my tongue it cleaueth fast
Vnto my iavves, and I am brought
to dust of death at last.
And many dogs doe compasse me,
and vvicked counsell eke
Conspire against me cursedly,
they pierce my hands and feet.
I vvas tormented, so that I
might all my bones haue told:
Yet still vpon me they doe looke,
and still they mee behold.
My garments they diuided eke
in parts among them all:
And for my coat they did c • st lots,
to vvhom it might befall.
Therefore I pray thee be not far
from me at my great need:
But rather sith thou art my strength,
to helpe me Lord make speed.
And frō the svvord Lord saue my soule
by thy might and thy povver:
And keepe my soule thy darling deere▪
from dogs that vvould deuoure.
And from the Lyons mouth that vvould
me all in sunder shiuer▪
And from the homes of Vnicomes,
Lord safely me deliuer.
• nd I shall to my brethren all
thy maiestie record:
And in thy Church shall praise the name
of thee the liuing Lord.
All ye that feare him▪ praise the Lord,
thou Iacob honour him:
And all ye seed of Israel,
vvith reuerence vvorship him.
For he despiseth not the poore,
he turneth not avvay
His countenance vvhen they doe call,
but granteth to their cry.
Among the folke that feare the Lord,
I vvill therefore proclaime
Thy praise, and keepe my promise made
for setting forth thy name.
The poore shall ea • e and be suffi • de,
and those that doe their deuer
To knovv the Lord, shal praise his name,
their hearts shall liue for euer.
All coasts of earth shall praise the Lord
and turne to him for grace:
The heathen folke shall vvorship him
before his blessed face.
The kingdome of the heathen folke,
the Lord shall haue therefore:
And he shall be their gouernour,
and king for euermore.
The rich man of his goodly gifts,
shall feed and taste also:
And in his presence vvorship him,
and bovv their knees full lovv.
And all that shall goe dovvn to dust,
of life by him must taste▪
My seed shall liue and praise the Lord,
vvhile any vvorld shall last.
My seed shall plainely shevv to them
that shall be borne hereafter:
His iustice and his righteousnesse,
and all his vvorkes of vvonder.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
THE Lord is onely my support, and he that doth me feede: Hovv
〈♫〉
can I then lacke any thing, vvhereof I stand in need?

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
THE Lord is onely my support, and he that doth me feede: Hovv
〈♫〉
can I then lacke any thing, vvhereof I stand in need?

div.head: TENOR, or Playnsong.
div.p:
☞ 〈♫〉
THE Lord is onely my support, and he that doth me feede: Hovv
〈♫〉
can I then lacke any thing, vvhereof I stand in need.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
THE Lord is onely my support, and he that doth me feede: Hovv
〈♫〉
can I then lacke any thing, vvhereof I stand in need.

lg.l: He doth me fold in coates most safe,
the tender grasse fast by:
And after driues me to the streames
vvhich run most pleasantly.
And vvhen I feele my selfe neere lost,
then doth he me home take:
Conducting me in his right pathes.
euen for his ovvne names sake.
And though I vvere euen at deaths door
yet vvould I feare none ill:
For vvith thy rod and shepheards crooke
I am comforted still.
Thou hast my table richly deckt,
in despight of my foe:
Thou hast my head vvith balme refresht,
my cup doth ouerflovv.
And finally vvhile breath doth last,
thy grace shall me defend:
And in the house of God vvill I
my life for euer spend.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
MY Shepheard is the liuing Lord, nothing therefore I need:
〈♫〉
In pastures faire vvith vvaters calme, he set me for to feed.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
MY Shepheard is the liuing Lord, nothing therefore I need:
〈♫〉
In pastures faire vvith vvaters calme, he set me for to feed.

div.head: TENOR, or Playnsong.
div.p:
☞ 〈♫〉
MY Shepheard is the liuing Lord, nothing therefore I need:
☞ 〈♫〉
In pastures faire vvith vvaters calme, he set me for to feed.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
MY Shepheard is the liuing Lord, nothing therefore I need:
〈♫〉
In pastures faire vvith vvaters calme, he set me for to feed.

lg.l: He did conuert and glad my soule,
and brought my minde in frame:
To vvalke in pathes of righteousnesse,
for his most holy name.
Yea, though I vvalke in vale of death▪
yet vvould I feare none ill:
Thy rod, thy staffe doth comfort me,
and thou art vvith me still.
And in the presence of my foes,
my table thou shalt spread:
Thou shalt (O Lord) fill full my cup,
and eke annoint my head.
Through all my life thy fauour is
so frankely shevved to me?
That in thy house for euermore
my dvvelling place shall be.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
THe earth is all the Lords, vvith all her store and furniture:

〈♫〉
Yea, his is all the vvorld, and all that therein doth indure.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
THE earth is all the Lords, vvith all her store and furniture:

〈♫〉
Yea, his is all the vvorld, and all that therein doth indure.

div.head: TENOR, or Playnsong.
div.l:
☞ 〈♫〉
THe earth is all the Lords vvith all her store and furniture:

〈♫〉
Yea, his is all the vvorld, and all that therein doth indure.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
THE earth is all the Lords, vvith all her store and furniture:

〈♫〉
Yea, his is all the vvorld, and all that therein doth indure.

lg.l: For he hath fastly founded it
aboue the sea to stand:
And laid alovv the liquide flouds
to flovv beneath the land.
For vvho is he (O Lord that shall
ascend vnto thy hill?
Or passe into thy holy place,
there to continue still?
vvhose hands are barmles, & vvhosehart
no spot there doth defile:
His soule not set on vanitie,
vvho hath not svvorne to guile.
Him that is such a one, the Lord
shall place in blissefull plight:
And God his God and Sauiour
shall yeeld to him his right.
This is the brood of trauellers▪
in seeking of his grace:
As Iacob did the Israelites
in that time of his race.
Ye Princes open your gates, stand open
the euerlasting gate:
For there shall enter in thereby
the Prince of glorious state.
VVhat is the king of glorious state?
the strong and mightie Lord:
The mighty Lord in battailes stout,
and tryall of the svvord.
Ye Princes open your gates stand open
the euerlasting gate:
For there shall enter in thereby,
the King of glorious state.
VVhat is the King of glorious state?
the Lord of hosts it is,
The kingdome and the royaltie
of glorious state is his.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
I Lift my heart to thee, my God and guide most lust: Novv suffer me
〈♫〉
to take no shame, for in thee doe I trust.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
I Lift my heart to thee, my God and guide most iust: Novv suffer me
〈♫〉
to take no shame, for in thee doe I trust.

div.head: TENOR, or Playnsong.
div.p:
☞ 〈♫〉
I Lift my heart to thee, my God and guide most iust: Novv suffer me
☞ 〈♫〉
to take no shame, for in thee doe I trust.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
I Lift my heart to thee, my God and guide most iust: Novv suffer me
〈♫〉
to take no shame, for in thee doe I trust.

lg.l: Let not my foes reioyce,
nor make a scorne of me:
And let them not be ouerthrovvne,
that put their trust in thee▪
But shame shall them befall.
vvhich harme them vvrongfully▪
Therefore thy paths and thy right vvayes,
vnto me Lord descrie.
Direct me in thy truth,
and teach me I thee pray:
Thou art my God and Sauiour,
on thee I vvait alvvay.
Thy mercies manifold,
I pray thee Lord remember:
And eke thy pittie plentifull,
for they haue beene for euer.
Remember not the faults
and frailtie of my youth:
Remember not hovv ignorant
I haue beene of thy truth.
Nor after my deserts,
let me thy mercy finde:
But of thine ovvne benignitie,
Lord haue me in thy minde.
His mercy is full svveet,
his truth a perfect guide:
Therefore the Lord vvill sinners teach,
and such as goe aside.
The humble he vvill teach,
his precepes for to keepe:
He vvill direct in all his vvayes,
the lovvly and the meeke.
For all the vvayes of God
are truth and mercy both:
To them that keepe his testament,
the vvitnesse of his troth.
Novv for thy holy name,
O Lord I thee intreat
To grant me pardon for my sinne,
for it is vvondrous great.
VVho so doth feare the Lord,
the Lord vvill him direct:
To lead his life in such a vvay,
as he doth best accept.
His soule shall euermore
in goodnesse dvvell and stand:
His seed and his posteritie
inherit shall the land.
All those that feare the Lord,
knovv his secret intent:
And vnto them he doth declare
his vvill and testament.
Mine eyes and eke my heart,
to him I vvill aduance,
That pluckt my feet out of the snare
of sinne and ignorance.
VVith mercy me behold,
to thee I make my mone:
For I am poore and desolate,
and comfortlesse alone.
The troubles of my heart
are multiplide indeed:
Bring me out of this miserie,
necessitie and need.
Behold my pouertie,
my anguish, and my paine:
Remit my sinne and mine offence,
and make me cleane againe.
O Lord behold my foes
hovv they doe still increase:
Pursuing me vvith deadly hate,
that faine vvould liue in peace▪
Preserue and keepe my soule▪
and eke deliuer me:
And let me not be ouerthrovvne,
because I trust in thee.
Let my simple purenesse,
me from mine enemies shend:
Because I looke as one of thine,
that thou shouldst me defend.
Deliuer Lord thy folke,
and send them some reliefe:
I meane thy chosen Israel,
from all their paine and griefe.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
LOrd be my Iudge, and thou shalt see my pathes are right and plaine:

〈♫〉
I trust in God, and hope that he vvill strength me to remaine.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
LOrd be my Iudge, and thou shalt see my pathes are right & plaine:

〈♫〉
I trust in God, and hope that he vvill strength me to remaine.

div.head: TENOR, or Playnsong.
div.l:
☞ 〈♫〉
LOrd be my Iudge, and thou shalt see my pathes are right and plaine:

〈♫〉
I trust in God, and hope that hee vvill strength me to remaine.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
LOrd be my iudge, and thou shalt see my pathes are right & plaine,

〈♫〉
I trust in God, and hope that he vvill strength me to remaine.

lg.l: Proue me my God I thee desire,
my vvayes to search and try,
As men doe proue their gold vvith fire,
my reynes and heart espie.
Thy goodnesse laid before my face,
I durst behold alvvayes:
For of thy truth I tread the trace,
and vvill doe all my dayes▪
I doe not lust to haunt or vse
vvith men vvhose deeds are vaine:
To come in house I doe refuse
vvith the deceitfull trayne.
I much abhorre the vvicked sort,
their deeds I doe despise:
I doe not once to them resort,
that hurtfull things deuise.
My hands I vvash, and doe proceed
in vvorkes to vvalke vpright:
Then to thine altar I make speed
to offer there in sight.
That I may speak & preach the praise
that doth belong to thee:
And so declare hovv vvondrous vvayes
thou hast beene good to me.
O Lord thy house I loue most deare,
to me it doth excell:
I haue delight and vvould dravv neere,
vvhereas thy grace doth dvvell.
O shut not vp my soule vvith them
in sinne that take their fill:
Nor yet my soule among those men
that seeke much bloud to spill.
VVhose hands are heapt vvith craft & guile
their life thereof is full:
And their right hand vvith vvrench and vvile
for bribes doth pluck and pull.
But I in righteousnesse intend,
my time and dayes to serue:
Haue mercy Lord, and me defend,
so that I doe not svverue.
My foot is staid for all assayes,
it standeth vvell and right:
VVherefore to God vvill I giue prais • ,
in all the peoples sight.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
THe Lord is both my he • lth and light, shall man make me dismaid?

〈♫〉
Sith God doth giue me strength and might vvhy should I be afraid?

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
THe Lord is both my health and light, shall man make me dismaid?

〈♫〉
Sith God doth giue me strength and might, vvhy should I be afraid?

div.head: TENOR, or Playnsong.
div.l:
☞ 〈♫〉
THe Lord is both my health and light, shall man make me dismaid?

〈♫〉
Sith God doth giue me strength and might, vvhy should I be afraid?

div.head: BASSVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
THe Lord is both my health and light, shall man make me dismaid?

〈♫〉
Sith God doth giue me strength and might, vvhy should I be afraid?

lg.l: VVhile that my foes vvith all their strength
begin vvith me to braule:
And thinke to eate me vp at length,
themselues haue caught the fall.
Though they in camp against me lie,
my heart is not afraid:
In battaile pight if they vvill try,
I trust in God for aide
One thing of God I doe require,
that he vvill not deny:
For vvhich I pray, and vvill desire,
till he to me apply.
That I vvithin his holy place,
my life throughout my dvvell:
To see the beauty of his face,
and vievv his temple vvell.
In time of dread he shall me hide
vvithin his place most pure:
And keepe me secret by his side,
as on a rocke most sure.
At length I knovv the Lords good grac •
shall make me strong and stout:
My foes to spoyle and cleane deface,
that compasse me about.
Therefore vvithin his house vvill I
giue sacrifice of praise▪
VVith Psalmes and songs I vvill apply
to laud the Lord alvvayes.
Lord heare the voyce of my request,
for vvhich to thee I call:
Haue mercy Lord on me opprest,
and send me help vvithall.
My heart doth knovvledge vnto thee,
I sue to haue thy grace:
Then seeke my face (saist thou to me)
Lord I vvill seeke thy face.
In vvrath turne not thy selfe avvay,
nor suffer me to slide:
Thou art my help still to this day,
be still my God and guide.
My parents both their sonne forsooke
and cast me off at large:
And then the Lord himselfe yet tooke
of me the care and charge.
Teach me O God the vvay to thee,
and lead me on forth right:
For feare of such as vvatch for me▪
to trap me if they might.
Doe not betake me to the vvill
of them that be my foes:
For they surmise against me still,
false vvitnesse to depose.
My heart vvould faint, but that in me
this hope is fixed fast:
The Lord Gods good grace shall I see,
in life that aye shall last.
• rust still in God, vvhose vvhole thou art
his vvill abide thou must:
And he shall ease and strength thy heart,
if thou in him doe trust.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
THou art O Lord, my strength and stay, the succour vvhich I craue:
〈♫〉
Neglect me not, lest I be like to them that goe to graue.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
THou art O Lord, my strength and stay, the succour vvhich I craue:
〈♫〉
Neglect me not, lest I be like to them that goe to graue.

div.head: TENOR, or Playnsong.
div.p:
☞ 〈♫〉
THou art O Lord, my strength and stay, the succour vvhich I craue:
☞ 〈♫〉
Neglect me not, lest I be like to them that goe to graue.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
THou art O Lord, my strength and stay, the succour vvhich I craue:
〈♫〉
Neglect me not, left I be like to them that goe to graue.

lg.l: The voyce of thy suppliant heare,
that vnto thee doth cry:
VVhen I lift vp my hands vnto
thy holy Arke most hie.
Repute me not among the sort
of vvicked and peruert:
That speak right faire vnto their friends
and thinke full ill in heart.
According to their handy vvorke,
as they deserue indeed:
And after their inuentions,
let them receiue their meed.
For they regard nothing Gods vvord,
his lavv ne yet his lore:
Therefore vvill he them and their seed
destroy for euermore.
To render thankes vnto the Lord,
hovv great a cause haue I?
My voyce, my prayer, and my complaint
that heard so vvillingly.
He is my shield and fortitude,
my buckler in distresse:
My hope, my helpe, my hearts reliefe,
my song shall him confesse.
He is our strength and our defence,
our enemies to resist:
The health and the saluation
of his elect by Christ.
Thy people and thy heritage,
Lord, blesse, guide, and preserue:
Increase them Lord, and rule their heart,
that they doe neuer svverue.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
GIue to the Lord yee Potentates, yee Rulers of the vvorld:

〈♫〉
Giue yee all praise, honour and strength vnto the liuing Lord.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
GIue to the Lord yee Potentates, yee Rulers of the vvorld:

〈♫〉
Giue yee all praise, honour and strength vnto the liuing Lord.

div.head: TENOR▪ or Playnsong.
div.l:
☞ 〈♫〉
GIue to the Lord yee Potentates, yee Rulers of the vvorld:

〈♫〉
Giue ye all praise, honour and strength vnto the liuing Lord.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
GIue to the Lord yee Potentates, yee Rul • rs of the vvorld:

〈♫〉
Giue ye all praise, honour and strength vnto the liuing Lord.

lg.l: Giue glory to his • oly name,
and honour him alone:
VVorship him in his maiesty,
vvithin his holy throne.
His voyce doth rule the vvaters all▪
euen as himselfe doth please:
He doth prepare the thunderclaps,
and gouerns all the Seas.
The voyce of God is of great force,
and vvondrous excellent:
It is most mighty in effect,
and most magnificent.
The voyce of God doth rend & breake
the Cedar trees so long:
The Cedar trees of Libanus,
vvhich are most hie and strong.
And makes them leape like as a calfe,
or else an Vnicorne:
Not onely trees, but mountaines great
vvhereon the trees are borne.
His voyce diuides the flames of fire,
and shakes the vvildernesse:
It makes the desart quake for feare,
that called is Cades.
It makes the Hinds for feare to calue,
and makes the couert plaine:
Then in his Temple euery man
his glory doth proclaime.
The Lord vvas set aboue the • ouds,
ruling the raging sea:
So shall he raigne as Lord and King,
for euer and for aye.
The Lord vvill giue his people povver
in vertue to increase:
The Lord vvill blesse his chosen folke
vvith euerlasting peace.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
ALl laud and praise vvith heart and voyce, O Lord I giue to thee:
〈♫〉
vvhich didst not make my foes reioyce, but hast exalted me. O Lord
〈♫〉
my God to thee I cride in all my paine and griefe, thou gauest an eare,
〈♫〉
and didst prouide, to ease me vvith reliefe.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
ALl laud and praise vvith heart and voyce, O Lord I giue to thee:
〈♫〉
vvhich didst not make my foes reioyce, but hast exalted me. O Lord my
〈♫〉
God to thee I cride in all my paine and griefe, thou gauest an eare
〈♫〉
and didst prouide, to ease me vvith reliefe.

div.head: TENOR. or Playnsong.
div.p:
☞ 〈♫〉
ALl laud and praise vvith hea • t and voyce, O Lord I giue to thee:
☞ 〈♫〉
vvhich didst not make my foes reioyce, but hast exalted mee. O Lord
〈♫〉
my God to thee I cride in all my paine and griefe, thou gauest an eare,
〈♫〉
and didst prouide, to ease me vvith reliefe.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
ALl laud and praise vvith heart and voyce, O Lord I giue to thee:
〈♫〉
vvhich didst not make my foes reioyce, but hast exalted mee. O Lord
〈♫〉
my God to thee I cryde in all my paine and griefe, thou gauest an eare,
〈♫〉
and didst prouide to ease me vvith reliefe:

lg.l: Of thy good vvill thou haste calde back
my soule from hell to saue:
Thou didst reuiue vvhen strength did lack
and keptst me from the graue.
Sing praise ye Saints that proue & see
the goodnesse of the Lord:
In memory of his maiesty.
reioyce vvith one accord.
For vvhy his anger but a space
doth last and slake againe:
But in his fauour and his grace,
alvvayes doth life remaine.
Though gripes of griefe, and pangs full sore
shall lodge vvith vs all night:
The Lord to ioy shall vs restore,
before the day be light.
VVhen I inioyde the vvorld at vvill,
thus vvould I boast and say:
Tush I am sure to feele none ill,
this vvealth shall not decay:
For thou O God of thy good grace
hast sent me strength and aid.
But vvhen thou turndst avvay thy face,
my minde vvas sore dismaid.
VVherefore againe yet did I cry
to thee O Lord of might:
My God vvith plaints I did apply,
and praide both day and night.
VVhat gaine is in my bloud said I,
if death destroy my dayes?
Doth dust declare thy maiestie,
or yet thy truth doth praise?
VVherefore my God some pitty take,
O Lord I thee desire:
Doe not this simple soule forsake,
of helpe I thee require.
Then didst thou turn my grief & vvoe
vnto a chearefull voyce:
The mourning vveed thou tookst me fro,
and mad'st me to reioyce.
VVherefore my soule vncessantly
shall sing vnto thy praise:
My Lord, my God, to thee vvill I
giue laud and thanks alvvayes.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
O Lord I put my trust in thee, let nothing vvorke me shame:

〈♫〉
As thou art iust deliuer me, and set me quite from blame.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
O Lord I put my trust in thee, let nothing vvorke me shame:

〈♫〉
As thou art iust, deliuer me, and set me quite from blame.

div.head: TENOR, or Playnsong.
div.l:
☞ 〈♫〉
O Lord I put my trust in thee, let nothing vvorke me shame:

〈♫〉
As thou art iust, deliuer me, and set me quite from blame.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
O Lord I put my trust in thee, let nothing vvorke mee shame:

〈♫〉
As thou art iust, deliuer me, and set me quite from blame.

lg.l: Heare me O Lord and that anone,
to help me make good speed:
Be thou my rocke and house of stone,
my fence in time of need.
For vvhy? as stones by strength is tride,
thou art my fort and tovver:
For thy names sake be thou my guide,
and lead me in thy povver.
Pluck forth my feet out of the snare
vvhich they for me haue laid:
Thou art my strength, and all my care
is for thy might and aide.
Into thy hands Lord I commit
my spirit vvhich is thy due:
For vvhy? thou hast redeemed it,
O Lord my God most true.
I hate such folke as vvill not part
from things to be abhord:
VVhen they on trifles set their heart,
my trust is in the Lord.
For I vvill in thy mercy ioy▪
I see it doth excell:
Thou seest vvhen ought vvould me annoy
and knovvest my soule full vvell:
Thou hast not left me in their hand,
that vvould me ouercharge:
But thou hast set me out of band,
to vvalke abroad at large.
Great griefe O Lord doth me assaile,
some pittie on me take:
Mine eyes vvaxe dim, my fight doth faile,
my vvombe for vvoe doth ake.
My life is vvorne vvith griefe & paine
my yeares in vvoe are past:
My strength is gone, and through disdain
my bones corrupt and vvaste.
Among my foes I am a scorne,
my friends are all dismaid:
My neighbours and my kinsmen borne,
to see me are afraid.
As men once dead are out of minde,
so am I novv forgot:
As small effect in me they finde,
as in a broken pot.
I heard the brags of all the rout,
their threats my minde did fray:
Hovv they conspired and vvent about
to take my life avvay.
But Lord I trust in thee for aide,
not to be ouertrod:
For I confesse and still haue said,
thou art my Lord and God.
The length of all my life and age,
O Lord is in thy hand:
Defend me from the vvrath and rage
of them that thee vvithstand.
To me thy feruant Lord expresse,
and shevv thy ioyfull face:
And saue me Lord for thy goodnesse,
thy mercy and thy grace.
Lord let me not be put to blame,
for that on thee I call:
But let the vvicked beare the shame,
and in the graue to fall.
Oh hovv great good hast thou in store
laid vp full safe for them:
That feare and trust in thee therefore
before the sonnes of men?
Thy presence shal them fence & guide
from all proud brags and vvrongs:
VVithin thy place thou shalt them hide
from all the strife of tongues.
Thanks to the Lord that hath declar'd
on me his grace so far:
Me to defend vvith vvatch and vvard,
as in a tovvne of vvarre
Thus did I say both day and night,
vvhen I vvas sore opprest:
Loe I vvas cleane cast out of sight,
yet heardst thou my request.
Yee Saints loue ye the Lord I say,
the faithfull he doth guide:
And to the proud he vvill repay
according to their pride.
Be strong, & God shall stay your heart,
be bold and haue a lust:
For sure the Lord vvill take your part,
sith ye on him doe trust.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
THe man is blest vvhose vvickednes the Lord hath cleane remitted:

〈♫〉
And he vvhose sinne and vvretchednesse is hid and also couered.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
THE man is blest vvhose vvickednesse the Lord hath cleane remitted:

〈♫〉
And he vvhose sinne and vvretchednesse, is hid and also couered.

div.head: TENOR, or Playnsong.
div.l:
☞ 〈♫〉
THe man is bles • vvhose vvickednesse the Lord hath cleane remitted:

〈♫〉
And he vvhose sinne and vvretchednesse is hid and al- so couered.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
THE man is blest vvhose vvickednesse the Lord hath cleane remitted:

〈♫〉
And he vvhose sinne and vvretchednesse, is hid and also couered.

lg.l: And blest is he to vvhom the Lord
imputeth not his sinne:
VVhich in his heart hath hid no guile,
not fraud is found therein.
For vvhilst that I kept close my sinne,
in silence and constraint:
My bones did vveare and vvaste avvay
vvith daily mo • e and plaint.
For night and day thy hand on me
so grieuous vvas and smart:
That all my bloud and humours moist,
to drynesse did conuert.
I did therefore confesse my fault,
and all my sinnes discouer:
Then thou O Lord didst me forgiue,
and all my sinnes passe ouer.
The humble man shall pray therefo ••
and seeke thee in due time:
So that the flouds of vvater great
shall haue no povver on him.
VVhen trouble and aduersitie
doe compasse me about:
Thou art my refuge and my ioy,
and thou dost rid me out.
Come hither and I shall thee teach,
hovv thou shalt vvalke vpright:
And vvill thee guide, as I my selfe
haue learnd by proofe and sight.
Be not so rude and ignorant,
as is the Horse or Mule,
VVhose mouth vvithout a raigne or bit,
from harme thou canst not rule.
The vvicked man shall manifold
sorrovves and griefe sustaine:
But vnto him that trusts in God,
his goodnesse shall remaine.
Be merry therefore in the Lord,
yee iust lift vp your voyce:
And yee of pure and perfect heart,
〈◊〉 glad and eke reioyce,

div.head: CANTVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
YEE righteous in the Lord reioyce: it is a seemely sight:

〈♫〉
that vpright men vvith thankfull voyce should praise the God of might.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
YEE righteous in the Lord reioyce: it is a seemely sight,

〈♫〉
that vpright men vvith thankfull voyce should praise the God of might:

div.head: TENOR, or Playnsong.
div.l:
☞ 〈♫〉
YEE righteous in the Lord reioyce: it is a seemely sight,

〈♫〉
that vpright men vvith thankfull voyce should praise the God of might.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
YEE righteous in the Lord reioyce: it is a seemely sight,

〈♫〉
that vpright men vvith thankfull voyce should praise the God of might.

lg.l: Praise ye the Lord vvith Harp & song,
in Psalms and pleasant things:
VVith Lute and Instruments among,
that soundeth vvith ten strings.
Sing to the Lord a song most nevv,
vvith courage giue him praise:
For vvhy, his vvord is euer true,
his vvorkes and all his vvayes.
To iudgement, equitie, and right,
he hath a great good vvill:
And vvith his gifts he doth delight
the earth throughout to fill.
For by the vvord of God alone,
the heauens all vvere vvrought:
Their hoasts and povvers euery one,
his breath to passe hath brought.
The vvaters great gathered hath he
on heapes vvithin the shore:
And hid them in the depth to be
as in a house of store.
All men on earth both least and most,
feare God and keepe his lavv:
Yee that inhabit in each coast,
dread him and stand in avve.
VVhat he commanded, vvrought it vvas
at once vvith present speede:
VVhat he doth vvill is brought to passe
vvith full effect indeed.
The counsailes of the nations rude,
the Lord doth bring to nought:
He doth defend the multitude
of their deuice and thought.
But his decrees continue still,
they neuer slake or svvage:
The motions of his minde and vvill,
take place in euery age.
And blest are they to vvhom the Lord
as God and guide is knovvne:
VVhom he doth chuse of meere accord
to take them as his ovvne.
The Lord from heauen cast his sight
on men mortall by birth:
Considering from his seat of might,
the dvvellers on the earth.
The Lord (I say) vvhose hand hath vvrought
mans heart & doth it frame:
For he alone doth knovv the thought,
and vvorking of the same.
A King that trusteth in his host,
shall nought preuaile at length:
The man that of his might doth boast,
shall fall for all his strength.
The troups of horsemen eke shal faile
their sturdy Steeds shall sterue:
The strength of horse shall not preuaile
the rider to preserue▪
But loe the eyes of God intend,
and vvatch to aide the iust▪
VVith such as feare him to offend,
and on his goodnesse trust.
That he of death and all distresse,
may set their soules from dread:
And if that death their land oppresse,
in hunger them to feede.
VVherefore our soules doe still depend
on Godour strength and stay:
He is the shield vs to defend,
and driue all darts avvay.
Our soule in God hath ioy and game,
reioycing in his might:
For vvhy? in his most holy name
vve hope and haue delight.
Therefore let thy goodnesse O Lord,
still present vvith vs be:
As vve alvvayes vvith one accord,
doe onely trust in thee.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
I VVill giue laud and honour both vnto the Lord alvvayes:

〈♫〉
And eke my mouth for euermore shall speake vnto his praise.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
I VVill giue laud and honour both vnto the Lord alvvayes:

〈♫〉
And eke my mouth for euermore shall speake vnto his praise.

div.head: TENOR, or Playnsong.
div.l:
☞ 〈♫〉
I VVill giue laud and honour both vnto the Lord alvvayes:

〈♫〉
And eke my mouth for euermore shall speak: vnto his praise,

div.head: BASSVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
I VVill giue laud and honour both vnto the Lord alvvayes:

〈♫〉
And eke my mouth for euermore shall speake vnto his praise.

lg.l: I doe delight to laud the Lord
in soule and eke in voyce:
That humble men and mortified
may heare and so reioyce.
Therefore see that ye magnifie
vvith me the liuing Lord:
And let vs novv exalt his name,
together vvith one accord.
For I myselfe besought the Lord,
he ansvvered me againe:
And me deliuered incontinent
from all my feare and paine:
VVho so they be that him behold,
shall see his light most cleare:
Their countenance shall not be dasht,
they need it not to feare:
This silly soule for some reliefe,
vnto the Lord did call:
VVho did him heare vvithout delay,
and rid him out of thrall.
The Angell of the Lord doth pitch
his tents in euery place:
To saue all such as feare the Lord.
that nothing them deface.
Taste and consider vvell therefore,
that God is good and iust:
O happy man that maketh him
his onely stay and trust.
Feare ye the Lord ye holy ones,
aboue all earthly thing:
For they that feare the liuing Lord▪
are sure to lacke nothing.
The Lyons shall be hungerbit,
and pinde vvith famine much:
But as for them that feare the Lord,
no lacke shall be to such.
Come neer therfore my children deere
and to my vvords giue eare:
I shall you teach the perfect vvay,
hovv you the Lord shall feare.
VVho is the man that vvould liue long
and lead a blessed life?
See thou refraine thy tongue and lips
from all deceit and strife.
Turne back thy face from doing ill,
and doe the godly deede:
Inquire for peace and quietnesse,
and follovv it vvith speed.
For vvhy? the eyes of God aboue,
vpon the iust are bent?
His eares likevvise doth heare the plaint
of the poore innocent.
But he doth frovvn & bend his brovvs
vpon the vvicked traine:
And cuts avvay the memory,
that should of them remaine.
But vvhen the iust doe call and cry,
the Lord doth heare them so:
That out of paine and misery,
forthvvith he lets them goe.
The Lord is kinde and mercifull
to such as be contrite:
He saues also the sorrovvfull,
the meeke, and poore in sprite.
Full many be the miseries,
that righteous men doe suffer:
But out of all aduersities,
the Lord vvill them deli • er.
The Lord doth so preserue and keepe
his very bo • es alvvay:
That not so much as one of them
doth perish or decay.
The sinne shall slay the vvicked man,
vvhich he himselfe hath vvrought:
And such as hate the righteous man,
shall soone be brought to nought.
But they that serue the liuing Lord,
the Lord doth saue them sound:
And vvho that put their trust in him,
nothing shall them confound.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
LOrd plead my cause against my foes, confound their force and might:

〈♫〉
Fight on my part against all those that seeke vvith me to fight.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
LOrd plead my cause against my foes, confound their force and might:

〈♫〉
Fight on my part against all those that seeke vvith me to fight.

div.head: TENOR, or Playnsong:
div.l:
☞ 〈♫〉
LOrd plead my cause against my foes confound their force and might:

〈♫〉
Fight on my part against all those that seeke vvith me to fight.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
LOrd plead my cause against my foes, confound their force and might:

〈♫〉
Fight on my part against all those that seeke vvith me to fight.

lg.l: Lay hand vpon thy speare and shield,
thy selfe in armour dresse:
Stand vp for me, and fight the field,
to helpe me from distresse.
Gi • d on thy svvord, aud stop the vvay,
mine enemies to vvithstand:
That thou vnto my soule m • ist say,
Loe I thy helpe at hand.
Con • ound them vvith rebuke & blame,
that seeke my soule to spill:
Let them turn back, & flee vvith shame,
that seeke to vvorke me ill.
Let them disperse and flye abroad,
as vvinde doth driue the dust:
And that the Angell of our God,
their might avvay may thrust.
Let all their vvayes be void of light,
and slipperie like to fall:
And send thine Angell vvith thy might
to persecute them all.
For vvhy vvithout my fault they haue
in secret set their grin:
And for no cause haue digg'd a caue,
to take my soule therein.
VVhen they think least, & haue no care
O Lord destroy them all:
Let them be trapt in their ovvn snare,
and in their mischiefe fall.
And let my soule my he • rt, my voyce,
in God haue ioy and vvealth:
That in the Lord I may reioyce,
and in his sauing health.
And then my bones shall speake and say,
my parts shall all agree:
O Lord, though they doe seeme full gay,
vvhat man is like to thee?
Thou dost defend the vveak from them
that are both stout and strong▪
And rid the poore from vvicked men,
that spoyle and doe them vvrong.
My cruell foes against me rise,
to vvitnesse things vntrue:
And to accuse me they deuise,
of that I neuer knevv.
Where I to them doe ovve good vvill,
they quite me vvith disdaine:
That they should pay my good vvith ill,
my soule doth sore complaine.
VVhen they vvere sick, I mournd therfore,
and clad my selfe in sack:
VVith fasting I did faintfull sore,
to pray I vvas not slack.
As they had beene my brethren deare,
I did my selfe behaue:
As one that maketh vvofull cheare
about his mothers graue.
But they a • my disease did ioy,
and gather on a rout:
Yea, abiect slaues at me did toy
vvith mocks and checks full •• out.
The belly-gods and flattering traine,
that all good things deride:
At me doe grin vvith great disdaine,
and pluck their mouth aside.
Lord, vvhē vvilt thou amend this gear
vvhy dost thou stay and pause?
Oh rid my soule, mine onely deare,
out of these Lyons clavves.
And then vvill I giue thanks to thee
before the Church alvvayes:
And vvhereas most of people be,
there vvill I shevv thy praise.
Let not my foes preuaile on me,
vvhich hate me for no fault:
Not yet to vvinck ot turne their eye,
that causelesse me assault.
Of peace no vvord they thinke or say,
their talke is all vntrue:
They still co • sult, and vvould betray
all those that peace ensue.
VVith open mouth they runne at me,
they gape, they laugh they fleere:
VVell vvell, say they, our eye doth see
the thing that vve desire.
But Lord thou seest vvhat vvaies they take
cease not this geare to mend:
Be not farre off, nor me forsake,
as men that faile their friend.
Avvake, arise, and stirre abroad,
defend me in my right:
Reuenge my cause, my Lord, my God,
and ayde me vvith thy might.
According to thy righteousnesse,
my Lord God set me free:
And let not them their pride expresse,
nor triumph ouer me.
Let not their hearts reioyce and cry,
there, there, this geare goeth trim:
Nor giue them cause to say, on hye,
vve haue our vvill on him.
Confound them vvith rebuke & shame
that ioy vvhen I doe mourne:
And pay them homevvith spite & blame,
that brag at me vvith scorne.
Let them be glad and eke reioyce,
vvhich loue mine vpright vvay:
And they all times vvith heart and voyce
shall praise the Lord, and say,
Great is the Lord, and doth excell,
for vvhy? he doth delight
To see his seruants prosper vvell,
that is his pleasant sight.
VVherefore my tongue I vvill apply,
thy righteousnesse to prayse:
Vnto thee Lord my God vvill I
sing laud and thanks alvvayes.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
THe vvicked vvith his vvorks vniust, doth thus persvvade his heart:

〈♫〉
That of the Lord he hath no trust, his feare is set apart.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
THE vvicked vvith his vvorkes vniust, doth thus persvvade his heart:

〈♫〉
That of the Lord he hath no trust, his feare is set apart.

div.head: TENOR, or Playnsong.
div.l:
☞ 〈♫〉
THe vvicked vvith his vvorkes vniust, doth thus persvvade his heart:

〈♫〉
That of the Lord he hath no trust, his feare is set apart.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
THE vvicked vvith his vvorkes vniust, doth thus persvvade his heart:

〈♫〉
That of the Lord he hath no trust, his feare is set apart.

lg.l: Yet doth he ioy in his estate,
to vvalke as he began:
So long till be deserue the hate
of God and eke of man.
His vvorks are vvicked, vile & nought,
his tongue no truth doth tell:
Yet at no hand vvill he be taught,
vvhich vvay he may doe vvell.
vvhen he shold sleep, then doth he muse
his mischiefes to fulfill:
No vvicked vvayes doth he refuse,
no • nothing that is ill.
But Lord thy goodnesse doth ascend
aboue the heauens hie:
So doth thy truth it selfe extend,
vnto the cloudy skye.
Much more then hils so high & steepe,
thy iustice is exprest:
Thy iudgements like to seas most deepe,
thou • auest both man and beast.
Thy mercy is aboue all things,
O God it doth excell
In trust vvhereof as in thy vvings,
the sonnes of men shall dvvell.
VVithin thy house they shall be fed
vvith plenty at their vvill:
Of all delights they shall be sped,
and take thereof their fill.
For vvhy? the vvell of life so pure,
doth ouerflovv from thee:
And in thy light vve are full sure,
the lasting light to see.
From such as thee desire to knovv▪
let not thy grace depart:
Thy righteousnesse declare, and shevv
to men of vpright heart.
Let not the proud on me preuaile,
O Lord of thy good grace:
Nor let the vvicked me assaile,
to throvv me out of place.
But they in their deuice shall fall,
that vvicked vvorks maintaine:
They shall be ouerthrovvne vvithall,
and neuer rise againe.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
GRudge not to see the vvicked men, in vvealth to flourish still

〈♫〉
Nor yet enuie such as to ill, haue bent and set their vvill.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
GRudge not to see the vvicked men, in vvealth to flourish still:

〈♫〉
Nor yet enuie such as to ill, haue bent and set their vvill.

div.head: TENOR, or Playnsong.
div.l:
〈♫〉
GRudge not to see the vvicked men, in vvealth to flourish still:

〈♫〉
Nor yet enuie such as to ill, haue bent and set their vvill.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
GRudge not to see the vvicked men, in vvealth to flourish still:

〈♫〉
Nor yet enuie such as to ill, haue bent and set their vvill.

lg.l: For as greene grasse & florishing herbs
are cut and vvith • ravvay:
So shall their great prosperitie,
soone pa •• fa • e and decay.
Trust thou therefore in God alone,
to doe vvel giue thy minde▪
So shalt thou haue the land as thine,
and there sure food shalt finde.
In God set all thy hearts delight,
and looke vvhat thou vvouldst haue:
Or else canst vvish in all the vvorld▪
thou needst it not to craue.
Cast both thy selfe and thine affaires,
on God vvith perfect trust:
And thou shalt see vvith patience:
the effect both sure and iust.
Thy perfect life and godly name,
he vvill cleare as the light:
So that the sun euen as noone dayes,
shall not shine halfe so bright.
Be still therefore and stedfastly,
on God see thou vvaite then:
Not shrinking for the prosperous state
of levvd and vvicked men.
Shake off despight, enuie and hate,
at least in my vvise:
Their vvicked steps auoid and flye,
and follovv not their gui • e:
For euery vvicked man vvill God
destroy both more and lesse:
But such as trust in him are sure
the land for to possesse.
Watch but a vvhile & thou shalt see
no more the vvicked trayne:
No not so much as house or place,
vvhere once he did remaine.
But mercifull and humble men,
enioy shall sea and land:
In rest and peace they shall reioyce,
for sought shall them vvithstand.
The levvd men and malitions,
against the iust conspire:
They gnash their teeth at him, as men
vvhich doe his bane desire.
But vvhile that levvd men thus do think
the Lord laughes them to scorne:
For vvhy he seeth their terme approach,
vvhe • they shall sigh and mourne.
The vvicked haue their svvord out dravvn,
their bovv eke haue they bent
To ouerthrovv and kill the poore,
as they the right vvay vvent.
But the same svvord shall pierce their hearts,
vvhich vvas to kill the iust:
Likevvise the bovv shal break to shiuers
vvherein they put their trust.
Doubtlesse the iust mans poore estate
is better a great deale more:
Then all these levvd and vvorldly mens
rich pomp and heaped store.
For be their povver neuer so strong,
God vvill it ouerthrovv:
VVhere co • trary he doth preserue
the humble men and lovv.
He seeth by his great prouidence,
the good mens trade and vvay:
And vvill giue them inheritance,
vvhich neuer shall decay.
They shall not be discouraged,
vvhen some are hard bestead:
When other shall be hunger-bit,
they shall be clad and fed.
For vvhosoeuer vvicked is,
and enemie to the Lord:
Shal quaile, yea melt euen as lambs grese
or smoake that flyeth abroad.
Behold the vvicked borrovveth much,
aud neuer payeth againe:
VVhereas the iust by liberall gifts,
makes many glad and faine.
For they vvhom God doth blesse shall haue
the land for heritage:
And they vvhom he doth curse likevvise,
shall perish in his rage.
The Lord the iust mans vvayes doth guide,
and giues him good successe:
To euery thing he takes in hand,
he sendeth good addresse.
Though that he fall, yet is he sure
not vtterly to quaile:
Because the Lord stretcheth out his hand
at need, and doth not quaile.
I haue beene young, and novv am'old,
yet did I neuer see
The iust man left, nor yet his seed
to beg for misery.
But giues alvvayes most liberally,
and lendeth vvhereas is neede:
His children and posteritie,
receiue of God their meede.
Flye vice therefore and vvickednesse,
and vertue doe imbrace:
So God shall grant thee long to haue
on earth a dvvelling place.
For God so loueth equitie,
and shevveth to his such grace:
That he pres • rues them euermore,
destroying the vvicked race.
VVhereas the good and godly men,
inherit shall the land:
Hauing as Lords all things therein,
in their ovvne povver and hand.
The iust mans mouth doth euerspeake
of matters vvise and hie:
His tongue doth talke to edifie,
vvith truth and equitie.
For in his heart the lavv of God
the Lord doth still abide:
So that vvhere euer he goe or vvalke,
his foot can neuer slide.
The vvicked like a raueuing vvolfe,
the iust man doth beset:
By all meanes seeking him to kill,
if he fall in his net.
Though he should fall into his hands,
yet God vvould succour send:
Though men against him sentence giue,
God vvould him yet defend.
VVait thou on God, & keep his vvay,
he shall preserue thee then:
The earth to rule, and thou shalt see
destroyd these vvicked men.
The vvicked haue I seene most strong,
and placed in hie degree:
Flourishing in all vvealth and store,
as doth the Laurell tree.
But suddenly he passeth avvay,
and loe he vvas quite gone:
Then I him sought but could scarce finde
the place vvhere dvvelt such one.
Marke & behold the perfect man,
bovv God doth him increase:
For the iust man shall haue at length,
great ioy vvith rest and peace.
As for transgressors, vvoe to them,
destroyde they shall all be:
God vvill cut off their budding race,
and rich posteritie:
But the saluation of the iust,
doth come from God aboue:
VVho in their trouble sends them aide,
of his meere grace and loue.
God doth them help, saue & deliuer,
from levvd men and vniust:
And still vvill saue them vvhilst that they
in him doe put their trust.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
PVt me not to rebuke O Lord, in thy prouoked ire: Ne in thy heauie
〈♫〉
vvrath O Lord, correct me I desire. Thine arrovves doe sticke fast in me, thy
〈♫〉
hand doth presse me sore: And in my flesh no health at all appeareth any more.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
PVt me not to rebuke O Lord, in thy prouoked ire: Ne in thy heauie
〈♫〉
vvrath O Lord, correct me I desire. Thine arrovves doe sticke fast in me, thy
〈♫〉
hand doth presse me sore: And in my flesh no health at all appeareth any more.

div.head: TENOR, or Playnsong.
div.p:
☞ 〈♫〉
PVt me not to rebuke O Lord, in thy prouoked ire: Ne in thy heauie
〈♫〉
vvrath O Lord, correct me I desire. Thine arrovves doe sticke fast in me, thy
〈♫〉
hand doth presse me sore: And in my flesh no health at all appeareth any more.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
PVt me not to rebuke O Lord, in thy prouoked ire: Ne in thy heauie
〈♫〉
vvrath O Lord, correct me I desire. Thine arrovves doe sticke fast in me, thy
〈♫〉
hand doth presse me sore: And in my flesh no health at all appeareth any more.

lg.l: And all this is by reason of
thy vvrath that I am in:
Nor any rest is in my bones,
by reason of my sinne.
For loe my vvicked doings Lord,
aboue my head are gone:
A greater loade then I can beare,
they lye me sore vpon.
My vvounds stink and are festred so,
and loathsome are to see:
VVhich all through mine ovvn foolishnesse:
betideth vnto me.
And I in carefull vvise am brought,
in trouble and distresse:
That I goe vvayling all the day
in dolefull heauinesse.
My loynes are fild vvith sore disease,
my flesh hath no vvhole part:
I feeble am and broken sore,
I roare for griefe of heart.
Thou knovvest Lord my desire, my grones
are open in thy sight:
My heart doth pant, my strength hath faild
mine eyes haue lost their light.
My louers and my vvouted friends,
stand looking on my vvoe:
And eke my kinsmen far avvay,
are me departed fro.
They that did seeke my life, laid snares
and they that sought the vvay,
To doe me hurt, speake lyes, and thought
on treason all the day.
But as a deafe man I became,
that cannot heare at all:
And as one dumbe that opens not
his mouth to speake at all:
For all my confidence (O Lord)
is vvholly set on thee:
O Lord, thou Lord, that art my God,
thou shalt giue eare to mee.
This did I craue that they my foes
triumph not ouer me:
For vvhen my foot did slip, then they
did ioy my fall to see.
And truely I poore vvretch am set
in plague a vvofull vvight:
And eke my grieuous heauinesse,
is euer in my sight.
For vvhile that I my vvickednesse,
in humble vvise confesse:
And vvhile I for my sinfull deeds,
my sorrovves doe expresse.
My foes doe still remaine aliue,
and mighty are also:
And they that hate me vvrongfully.
in number hugely grovv,
They stand against me that my good
vvith euill did repay:
Because that good and honest things
I doe ensue alvvay.
Forsake me not (O Lord my God)
be thou not far avvay:
Haste thee to help (my Lord my God)
my safety and my stay.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
I Said I vvill looke to my vvayes, for feare I should goe vvrong:
〈♫〉
I vvill take heed all times that I offend not in my tongue.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
I Said I vvill looke to my vvayes, for feare I should got vvrong:
〈♫〉
I vvill take heed all times that I offend not in my tongue.

div.head: TENOR, or Playnsong.
div.p:
☞I Said I vvill looke to my vvayes, for feare I should goe vvrong:
☞ 〈♫〉
I vvill take heed all times that I offend not in my tongue.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
I Said I vvill looke to my vvayes, for feare I should goe vvrong:
〈♫〉
I vvill take heed all times that I offend not in my tongue.

lg.l: As vvith a bit I vvill keepe fast
my mouth vvith force and might:
Not once to vvhisper all the vvhile
the vvicked are in sight.
I held my tongue and spake no vvord▪
but kept me close and still:
Yea, from good talke I did refraine,
but so • e against my vvill.
My heart vv • xt hot vvithin my brest,
vvith musing▪ thought and doubt:
Which did increase and stirre the fire,
at last these vvords burst out:
Lord number out my life and dayes,
vvhich yet I haue not past:
So that I may be certified
hovv long my life shall last:
Lord thou hast pointed out my life
in length much like a span:
Mine age is nothing vnto thee,
so vaine is euery man.
Man vvalketh like a shade, and doth
in vaine himselfe annoy:
In getting goods, and cannot tell
vvho shall the same inioy.
Novv Lord sith things this vvise doe frame,
vvhat helpe doe I desire?
Of truth my helpe doth hang on thee,
I nothing else require.
From all the sinnes that I haue done,
Lord quite me out of hand:
And make me not a scorne to fooles,
that nothing vnderstand.
I vvas as dumbe, and to complaine,
no trouble might me moue:
Because I knovv it vvas thy vvorke,
my patience for to proue.
Lord take from me thy scourge and plague,
I can them not vvithstand:
I faint and pine avvay for feare
of thy most heauy hand.
VVhen thou for sinne dost man rebuke,
he vvaxeth vvoe and vvan:
As doth a cloath that Mothes haue fret,
so vaine a thing is man.
Lord heare my sute & giue good heed
regard my teares that fall:
I soiourne like a stranger here,
as did my fathers all.
O spare a little, giue me space,
my strength for to restore:
Before I goe avvay from hence,
and shall be seene no more.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
I VVaited long and sought the Lord, and patiently did beare:

〈♫〉
At length to me he did accord, my voyce and cry to heare.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
I VVaited long and sought the Lord, and patiently did beare:

〈♫〉
At length to me he did accord, my voyce and cry to heare.

div.head: TENOR, or Playnsong.
div.l:
☞ 〈♫〉
I VVaited long and sought the Lord, and patiently did beare:

〈♫〉
At length to me he did accord, my voyce and cry to heare.

div.head: BASSVS▪
div.l:
〈♫〉
I VVaited long and sought the Lord, and patiently did beare:

〈♫〉
At length to me he did accord, my voyce and cry to heare.

lg.l: He pluckt me from the lake so deepe,
out of the mire and clay:
And on a rocke he set my feet,
and he did guide my vvay.
To me he taught a Psalme of praise,
vvhich I must shevv abroad:
And sing nevv songs of thanks alvvayes,
vnto the Lord our God.
VVhen all the folke these things shall see
as people much afraid:
Then they vnto the Lord vvill • lee,
and trust vpon his aide,
O blest is he vvhose hope and heart
doth in the Lord remaine:
That vvith the proud doth take no part,
nor such as lye and faine.
For Lord my God, thy vvondrous deeds,
in greatnesse far doe passe:
Thy fauour tovvards vs exceeds
all things that euer vvas.
VVhen I entend and doe deuise
thy vvorks abroad to shevv:
To such a reckoning they doe rise,
thereof no end I knovv.
But offerings thou delightest not in,
I knovv thy vvhole desire?
With sacrifice to purge his sinne,
thou dost no man require.
Meate offerings and sacrifice,
thou vvouldst not haue at all:
But thou O Lord hast open made
mine eares to heare vvithall.
But then shall I behold and looke,
I come a meane to be:
For in the volume of thy Booke,
thus it is said of me.
That I O God should doe thy minde,
vvhich thing doth like me vvell:
For in my heart thy Lavv I finde,
fast placed there to dvvell.
Thy iustice and thy righteousnesse,
in great resort I tell:
Behold my tongue no time doth cease,
O Lord thou knovvest full vvell.
I haue not hid vvithin my brest.
thy goodnesse as by stealth:
But I declare and haue exprest
thy truth and sauing health▪
I kept not close thy louing minde,
that no man should it knovv:
The trust that in thy truth I finde,
to all the vvorld I shovv.
For I vvith mischiefes many one,
am sore beset about:
My sinnes increase, and so come on,
I cannot s • ye them out.
For vvhy? in number they exceed
the haires vpon my head:
My heart doth faint for very dread,
that I am almost dead.
VVith speed send help & set me free,
O Lord I thee require:
Make haste vvith aide to succour me,
O Lord I' thee desire.
Let them sustaine rebuke and shame,
that seeke my soule to spill:
Driue back my foes and them defame,
that vvish and vvould me ill.
For their ill feates doe them descry.
that vvould deface thy name:
Alvvayes on me they raile and cry,
• ie on him, fie for shame.
Let them in thee haue ioy & vvealth,
that seeke to thee alvvayes:
That those that loue thy f • uing health▪
may say, to God be praise.
But as for me I am but poore,
opprest and brought full lovv:
Yet thou O Lord vvilt me restore
to health full vvell I knovv.
For vvhy? thou art my hope and trust,
my refuge, helpe and stay:
VVherefore my God as thou art iust,
vvith me no time delay.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
THE man is blest, that carefull is, the needy to consider: For
〈♫〉
in the season perilous. the Lord vvill him deliuer. The Lord vvill make
〈♫〉
him safe and sound, and happy in the Land, and he vvill not deli- uer him
〈♫〉
into his enemies hand.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
THe man is blest, that carefull is, the needy to consider: For
〈♫〉
in the season perilous, the Lord vvill him deliuer. The Lord vvill make
〈♫〉
him safe and sound, and happy in the Land, and he vvill not deliuer him
〈♫〉
into his enemies hand.

div.head: TENOR, or Playnsong.
div.p:
☞ 〈♫〉
THE man is blest, that carefull is, the needy to consider: For
〈♫〉
in the season perilous, the Lord vvill him deliuer. The Lord vvill make
〈♫〉
him safe and sound, and happy in the Land, and he vvill not deliuer him
〈♫〉
into his enemies hand.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
THe man is blest that carefull is, the needy to consider: For
〈♫〉
in the season perilous, the Lord vvill him deliuer. The Lord vvill make
〈♫〉
him safe and sound, and happy in the Land, and he vvill not deliuer him
〈♫〉
into his enemies hand.

lg.l: And in his bed vvhen he lieth sicke,
the Lord vvill him restore:
And thou O Lord vvilt turne to health
his sicknesse and his sore.
Then in my sicknesse thus say I,
haue mercy Lord on me:
And heale my soule, vvhich is full vvoe
that I offended thee.
Mine enemies vvish me ill in heart,
and thus of me doe say:
VVhen shall he dye, that all his name
may vanish quite avvay?
And vvhen they come to visit me,
they aske if I doe vvell:
But in their hearts they mischiefe hatch,
and to their mates it tell.
They bi • e their lips and vvhisper so,
as though they vvould me charme:
And cast their fetches hovv to trap
me vvith some mortall harme.
Some grieuous sin hath brought him to
this sicknesse say they plaine:
He is so lovv, that vvithout doubt,
rise can he not againe.
The man also that I did trust,
vvith me did vse deceit:
VVho at my table eate my bread,
the same for me laid vvait.
Haue mercy Lord on me therefore,
and let me be preserued:
That I may render vnto them,
the things they haue deserued.
By this I knovv assuredly,
to be beloued of thee:
VVhen that mine enemies haue no cause
to triumph ouer me.
But in my right thou hast me kept,
and maintained alvvay:
And in thy presence place a •• ignde,
vvhere I shall dvvell for aye.
The Lord the God of Israel
be praised be euermore:
Euen so be it Lord vvill I say,
euen so be it therefore.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
LIke as the Hart doth breath and bray, the vvel-spring to obtaine,
〈♫〉
so doth my soule desire alvvay, vvith the Lord to re- maine.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
LIke as the Hart doth breath and bray, the vvel-spring to obtaine,
〈♫〉
so doth my soule desire alvvay vvith the Lord to remaine.

div.head: TENOR, or Playnsong.
div.p:
☞ 〈♫〉
LIke as the Hart doth breath and bray, the vvel-spring to obtaine,
〈♫〉
so doth my soule desire alvvay, vvith the Lord to remaine.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
LIke as the Hart doth breath and bray, the vvel-spring to obtaine,
〈♫〉
so doth my soule desire alvvay vvith the Lord to remaine.

lg.l: My soule doth thirst, and vvould dravv neare
the liuing Lord of might
Oh, vvhen shall I come and appeare
in presence of his sight?
The teares all times are my repast,
vvhich from mine eyes doe slide:
VVhen vvicked men cry out so fast,
vvhere novv is God thy guide?
Alas vvhat griefe is this to thinke,
vvhat freedome once I had?
Therefore my soule as at pits brinck,
is most heauy and sad.
VVhen I did march in good aray,
furnished vvith my traine:
Vnto the Temple vvas our vvay,
vvith songs and hearts most faine.
My soule vvhy art thou sad alvvayes,
and fretst thus in my brest?
Trust still in God, for him to praise
I hold it euer best.
By him I haue succour at need,
against all paine and griefe:
He is my God vvhich vvith all speed,
vvill haste to send reliefe.
And thus my soule vvithin me (Lord)
doth faint to thinke vpon
The Land of Iordan, and record
the little hill Hermon:
One griefe another in doth call,
as clouds burst out their voyce:
The • ouds of euill that doe fall,
run ouer me vvith noyse.
Yet I by day felt thy goodnesse
and helpe at all assayes:
Likevvise by night I doe not cease
the liuing Lord to praise.
I am persvvaded thus to say
to him vvith pure pretence:
O Lord thou art my guide and stay,
my rocke and my defence.
Why doe I then in pensiuenesse,
hanging the head thus vvalk▪
While that mine enemies me oppresse,
and vexe me vvith their talke?
For vvhy? they pierce the invvard parts
vvith pangs to be abhor'd:
When they cry out vvith stubborn harts
vvhere is thy God thy Lord?
So soone vvhy dost thou faint & quail,
my soule vvith paines opprest:
With thoughts vvhy dost thy selfe assaile
so sore vvithin my brest?
Trust in the Lord thy God alvvayes,
and thou the time shalt see:
To giue him thanks vvith laud & praise,
for health restord to thee.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
IVdge and reuenge my cause O Lord, from them that euill be:

〈♫〉
From vvicked and deceitfull men, O Lord de- liuer mee.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
IVdge and reuenge my cause O Lord, from them that euill be:

〈♫〉
From vvicked and deceitfull men, O Lord deliuer me.

div.head: TENOR, or Playnsong.
div.l:
☞ 〈♫〉
IVdge and reuenge my cause O Lord, from them that euill be:

〈♫〉
From vvicked and deceitfull men O Lord deliuer me.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
IVdge and reuenge my cause O Lord, from them that euill be:

〈♫〉
From vvicked and deceitfull men, O Lord deliuer me.

lg.l: For of my strength thou art the God,
vvhy putst thou me thee fro:
And vvhy vvalk I so heauily,
oppressed vvith my foe?
Send out thy light and eke thy truth,
and lead me vvith thy grace:
VVhich may conduct me to thy hill,
and to thy dvvelling place.
Then shall I to the altar goe
of God my ioy and cheare:
And on my Harp giue thanks to thee
O God, my God most deere.
VVhy art thou then so sad my soule,
and fretst thus in my brest?
Still trust in God, for him to praise
I hold it alvvayes best.
By him I haue deliuerance,
against all paine and griefe:
He is my God vvhich doth alvvayes
at need send me reliefe.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
OVR eares haue heard our fathers tell, and reuerently record
〈♫〉
the vvondrous vvorks that thou hast done in alder time O Lord. Hovv
〈♫〉
thou didst cast the Gentiles out, and stroydst them vvith strong hand, planting
〈♫〉
our Fathers in their place, and gau'st to them their Land.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
OVR eares haue heard our Fathers tell, and reuerently record
〈♫〉
the vvondrous vvorkes that thou hast done in alder time O Lord. Hovv
〈♫〉
thou didst cast the Gentiles out, and stroyd them vvith strong hand, planting
〈♫〉
our Fathers in their place, and gau'st to them their Land.

div.head: TENOR, or Playnsong.
div.p:
☞ 〈♫〉
OVR eares haue heard our Fathers tell, and reuerently record
〈♫〉
the vvondrous vvorkes that thou hast done in alder time O Lord. Hovv
〈♫〉
thou didst cast the Gentiles out, and stroydst them vvith strong hand, planting
〈♫〉
our Fathers in their place, and gau'st to them their Land.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
OVR eares haue heard our Fathers tell, and reuerently record
〈♫〉
the vvondrous vvorks that thou hast done in alder time O Lord. Hovv
〈♫〉
thou didst cast the Gentiles out, and stroydst them vvith strong hand, planting
〈♫〉
our Fathers in their place, and gau'st to them their Land.

lg.l: They conquered not by svvord nor strength
the Land of thy behest:
But by thy hand, thine arme and grace,
because thou louedst them best.
Thou art my King, O God that • olp
Iacob in sundry vvise:
Led vvith thy povver vve threvv dovvne such
as did against vs rise.
I trusted not in b • vv ne svvord,
they could not saue me sound:
Thou keptst vs from our enemies rage
thou didst our foes confound,
And still vve boast of thee our God,
and praise thy holy Name:
Yet novv thou goest not vvith our h • st,
but leauest vs to shame.
Thou mad'st vs flye before our foes,
and so vvere ouer-trod:
Our enemies spoild and robd our goods
vvhen vve vvere spearst abroad:
Thou hast vs giuen to our foes,
as sheepe for to be slaine:
Among the Heathen euery vvhere
scattred vve doe remaine.
Thy people thou hast fold like 〈◊〉 ,
and as a thing of nought:
For profit none thou hast thereby,
no gaine at all vvas sought.
And to our neighbors thou hast made
of vs a laughing •• ocke:
And those that doe about vs dvvell,
at vs doe grin and mock.
Thus vve serue for none other vse,
but for a common talke:
They mock, they scorne, they nod their heads
vvhere euer they goe or vvalk.
I am asham'd continually▪
to heare these vvicked men:
Yea, so I blush, that all my face
vvith red is couered then.
For vvhy▪ vve heard such slanderous vvords,
such false reports and lyes:
That death it is to see their vvrongs,
their threatnings and their cryes.
For all this vve forgot not thee,
nor yet thy couenant brake:
We turn not back our heart from thee
nor yet thy pathes forsake.

Yet thou hast trod vs dovvne to dust,
〈2 pages duplicate〉
vvhere dens of Dragons be:
And couered vs vvith shade of death,
and great aduersitie.
If that vve had our God forgot▪
and helpe of Idols sought:
VVould not God haue tride this out?
for he doth knovv our thought.
Nay, nay, for thy names sake O Lord,
alvvayes are vve slaine thus:
As sheepe vnto the shambles sent,
right so they deale vvith vs:
Vp Lord, vvhy s • eepest thou? avvake,
and leaue vs not for all.
VVhy hidest thou thy countenance,
and dost forget our thrall?
For dovvn to dust our soule is brought
and vve novv at last cast:
Our belly like as it vvere glude
vnto the ground, cleaues fast.
Rise vp therefore for our defence,
and helpe vs Lord at need:
VVe thee beseech of thy goodnesse,
to rescue vs vvith speede.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
MY heart doth take in hand, some godly song to sing: The praise
〈♫〉
that I shall shevv therein, pertaineth to the King.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
MY heart doth take in hand, some godly song to sing: The praise
〈♫〉
that I shall shevv therein, pertai- neth to the King.

div.head: TENOR, or Playnsong.
div.p:
☞ 〈♫〉
MY heart doth take in hand, some godly song to sing: The praise
〈♫〉
that I shall shevv therein, pertaineth to the King.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
MY heart doth take in hand, some godly song to sing: The praise
〈♫〉
that I shall shevv therein, pertaineth to the King.

lg.l: My tongue shall be as quick
his honour to indite:
As is the pen of any Scribe,
that vseth fast to vvrite.
O fairest of all men,
thy speech is perfect pure:
For God hath blessed thee vvith gifts,
for euer to indure.
About thee gird thy svvord,
O Prince of might elect:
VVith honour▪ glory and renovvne,
thy person pure is deckt.
Goe forth vvith goodly speede,
in meekenesse truth and right:
And thy right hand shall thee instruct,
in vvorkes of dreadfull might.
Thine arrovves sharp and keene.
their hearts so sore shall •• ing:
That folke shall fall and kneele to thee,
yea, all thy foes O King.
Thy royall seat O Lord,
for euer shall remaine:
Because the Scepter of thy realme,
doth righteousnesse maintaine.
Because thou • ou'st the right,
and dost the ill detest:
God, euen thy God hath nointed thee
vvith ioy aboue the rest.
VVith myrrhe and sauours svveet,
thy cloathes are all bespread:
When thou dost from thy pallace passe,
therein to make thee glad.
Kings daughters doe attend,
in fine and rich array.
At thy right hand the Queene doth stand,
in gold and garments gay.
O daughter take go • d heed,
incline and giue good eare:
Thou must forget thy kindred all,
and fathers house most deare.
Then shall the King desire
thy beauty faire and trim:
For vvhy? he is the Lord thy God,
and thou must vvorship him.
The daughters then of Tyre,
vvith gifts full rich to see:
And all the vvealthy of the land,
shall make their sute to thee.
The daughter of the King
is glorious to behold:
VVith in her clo • e • she doth sit,
all deckt in beaten gold.
In robes vvell vvrought vvith needle,
and many a pleasant thing:
VVith Virgins faire on her to vvaite,
she commeth to the King.
Thus are they brought vvith ioy
and mirth on euery side,
Into the palace of the King,
and there they doe abide.
In stead of Parents left,
O Queene the chance so stands:
Thou shalt haue sons vvhom thou maist set
as Princes in all lands.
VVherefore thy holy name,
all ages shall record:
Thy people shall giue thankes to thee,
for euermore O Lord.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
THe Lord is our defence and aid, the strength vvhereby vve stand:
〈♫〉
VVhen vve vvith vvoe are much dismaid, he is our helpe at hand. Though
〈♫〉
th'earth remoue vve vvill not feare, though hils so high and steepe, be thrust
〈♫〉
and hurled here and there vvithin the Sea so deepe.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
THe Lord is our defence and aid, the strength vvhereby vve stand:
〈♫〉
VVhen vvee vvith vvoe are much dismaid, hee is our helpe at hand. Though
〈♫〉
th earth remoue vve vvill not feare, though hils so hie and steepe, be thrust
〈♫〉
and hurled here and there vvithin the Sea so deepe.

div.head: TENOR, or Playnsong.
div.p:
☞ 〈♫〉
THe Lord is our defence and aid, the strength vvhereby vve stand:
☞ 〈♫〉
VVhen vve vvith vvoe are much dismaid, he is our helpe at hand. Though
〈♫〉
th'earth remoue vve vvill not feare, though hils so hie and steepe, be thrust
〈♫〉
and hurled here and there vvithin the Sea so deepe.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
THe Lord is our defence and aid, the strength vvhereby vve stand:
〈♫〉
VVhen vve vvith vvoe are much dismaid, hee is our helpe at hand. Though
〈♫〉
th'earth remoue vve vvill not feare: though hils so hie and steepe, be thrust
〈♫〉
and hurled here and there vvithin the Sea so deepe.

lg.l: No though the vvaues doe rage so sore,
that all the bank • it spils:
And though it ouerflovv the shore
and beare dovvn mighty hils.
For one faire floud doth send abroad
his pleasant streames apace:
To fresh the Citie of our God,
and vvash his holy place.
