In midst of her the Lord doth dvvell,
she can no vvhit decay:
All things against it that rebell,
the Lord vvill truely stay.
The heathen folke, the kingdomes feare
the people make a noyse:
The earth doth melt and not appeare,
vvhen God puts forth his voyce.
The Lord of hosts doth take our part.
to vs he hath an eye:
Our hope of health vvith all our heart
on Iacobs God doth lie.
Come heare, and see vvith minde and thought
the vvorking of our God:
VVhat vvonders he himself hath vvrought
throughout the earth ab • oad.
By him all vvars are husht and gone,
vvhich countries did conspire:
Their bovves he brake, & spears each one
their Chariots burnt vvith fire.
Leaue off therefore (saith he) & knovv
I am a God most stout:
Among the heathen hie and lovv,
a • d all the earth throughout.
The Lord of hosts doth vs defend,
he is ou • strength and tovver:
On Iacobs God vve doe depend,
and on his mighty povver.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
YE people all vvith one accord, clap hands and eke re- ioyce:

〈♫〉
Be glad and sing vnto the Lord vvith svveet and pleasant voyce.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
YE people all vvith one accord, clap hands and eke re- ioyce:

〈♫〉
Be glad and sing vnto the Lord vvith svveet and pleasant voyce.

div.head: TENOR, or Playnsong.
div.l:
☞ 〈♫〉
YE people all vvith one accord, clap hands and eke reioyce:

〈♫〉
Be glad and sing vnto the Lord, vvith svveet and pleasant voyce,

div.head: BASSVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
YE people all vvith one accord, clap hands and eke reioyce:

〈♫〉
Be glad and sing vnto the Lord vvith svveet and pleasant voyce,

lg.l: For high the Lord and dreadfull is,
vvith vvonders manifold:
A mighty King he is truely,
in all the earth extold.
The people shall he make to be,
vnto our bondage • hrall:
And vnderneath our feet he shall
the nations make to fall.
For vs the heritage he chose,
vvhich vve possesse alone:
The flouring vvorship of Iacob,
his vvelbeloued one.
Our God ascendeth vp on hye,
vvith ioy and pleasant noyse:
The Lord goeth vp aboue the skye,
vvith trumpets royall voyce.
Sing praise vnto our God, sing praise,
sing praises to our King:
For God is King of all the earth,
all skilfull praises sing.
God on the heathen raignes and sits,
vpon his holy throne:
The Princes of the people haue
them ioyned euery one
To Abrahams people: for our God,
vvhich is exalted hye.
As vvith a buckler doth defend
the earth coutinually.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
GReat is the Lord, and vvith great praise to be aduanced still.

〈♫〉
VVith in the Citie of our Lord, vpon his holy hill.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
GReat is the Lord, and vvith great praise to be aduanced still:

〈♫〉
VVithin the Citie of our Lord, vpon his holy hill.

div.head: TENOR or Playnsong.
div.l:
☞ 〈♫〉
GReat is the Lord, and vvith great praise to be aduanced still:

〈♫〉
VVithin the Citie of our Lord, vpon his holy hill.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
GReat is the Lord, and vvith great praise to be aduanced still:

〈♫〉
VVithin the Citie of our Lord, vpon his holy hill.

lg.l: Mount Sion is a pleasant place,
it gladdeth all the Land:
The Citie of the mightie King,
on her North-side doth stand.
VVithin the pallaces thereof,
God is a refuge knovvne:
For • oe the kings vvere gathered, and
together eke vvere gone.
But vvhen they did behold it so,
〈◊〉 vvondred, and they vvere
Asto •• ed much and sodainly
vvere driuen back vvith feare:
Great terrour there on them did fall,
for very vvoe they cry:
As doth a woman vvhen she shall
goe trauell by and by.
As thou vvith Easterne vvind the ship •
vpon the sea dost breake:
So vvere they staide▪ and euen as
vve heard our fathers speake.
So in the Citie of our God,
vve savv, it vvas so told:
Yea, in the Citie vvhich our God,
for euer vvill vphold.
O Lord vve vvait and doe attend
on thy good helpe and grace:
For vvhich I doe all times attend
vvithin thy holy place.
O Lord according to thy name,
for euer is thy praise:
And thy right hand O Lord is full
of righteousnesse alvvayes.
Let for thy iudgements Sion mount,
fulfilled be vvith ioyes:
And eke of Iuda grant (O Lord)
the daughter to reioyce.
Goe vvalke about all Sion hill,
yea, round about her goe:
And tell the tovvers that thereupon
are builded on a rovv.
And mark you vvell her bulvvarks all,
behold her tovvers there:
That ye may tell thereof to them,
that after shall be here:
For this God is our God, our God
for euermore is he:
Yea, and vnto the death also,
our guider shall he be.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
ALL people hearken and giue eare to that that I shall tell: Both
〈♫〉
high and lovv, both rich and poore, that in the vvorld doe dvvell.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
ALL people hearken and giue eare to that that I shall tell: Both
〈♫〉
high and lovv, both rich and poore, that in the vvorld doe dvvell.

div.head: TENOR, or Playnsong.
div.p:
☞ 〈♫〉
ALL people hearken and giue eare to that that I shall tell Both
☞ 〈♫〉
high and lovv, both rich and poore, that in the vvorld doe dvvell.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
ALL people hearken and giue eare to that that I shall tell Both
〈♫〉
high and lovv, both rich and poore, that in the vvorld doe dvvell.

lg.l: For vvhy my mouth shal make discourse
of many things right vvise:
In vnderstanding shall my heart
his study exercise.
I vvill incline mine eares to knovv
thy parables so darke:
And open all my doubtfull speech,
in meeter on my Harp.
VVhy should I feare afflictions,
or any carefull toyle:
Or else my foes vvhich at my heeles,
are prest my life to spolye?
For as for such as riches haue,
vvherein their trust is most:
And they vvhich of their treasures great
themselues doe brag and boast.
There is not one of them that can
his brothers death redeeme:
Or that can giue a price to God,
sufficient for him.
It is too great a price to pay,
none can thereto attaine:
Or that he might his life prolong,
or not in graue remaine:
They see vvise men as vvell as fooles,
subiect vnto deaths hands:
And being dead, strangers possesse
their goods, their rents, their lands.
Their care is to build houses faire,
and to determine sure:
To make their name right great on earth
for euer to indure.
Yet shall no man alvvay enioy
his honour, vvealth, and rest:
But shall at length taste of deaths cup▪
as vvell as the brute beast.
And though they try their foolish thoughts
to be most levvd and vaine:
Their children eke approue their talke,
and in like sinne remaine.
As sheepe vnto the fold are brought,
so shall they into graue:
Death shall them eate, and in that day
the iust shall Lordship haue.
Their image and their royall port,
shall fade and quite decay?
VVhen as from house to pit they passe,
vvith vvoe and vveale avvay.
But surely God vvill preserue me
from death and endlesse paine:
Because he vvill of his good grace,
my soule receiue againe.
If any man vvaxe vvondrous rich,
feare not I say therefore:
Although the glory of his house
encreaseth more and more.
For vvhen he dyeth, of all these things
nothing shall he receiue:
His glory vvill not follovv him,
his pompe vvill take her leaue.
Yet in this life he takes himselfe
the happiest vnder Sunne:
And others likevvise flatter him,
saying all is vvell done.
And presuppose he liue as long
as did his fathers old:
Yet must he needs at length giue place,
and be brought to deaths fold.
Thus man to honour God hath calde,
yet doth he not consider:
But like brute beasts so doth he liue,
vvhich turne to dust or povvder.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
THE mighty God th'Eternall hath thus spoke, and all the vvorld
〈♫〉
he vvill call and prouoke, euen from the East, and so forth to the VVest:
〈♫〉
From tovvard Sion, vvhich place him liketh best: God vvill appeare in beautie
〈♫〉
most ex- cellent, Our God vvill come before that long time be spent.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
THE mighty God th'Eternall hath thus spoke, and all the vvorld
〈♫〉
hee vvill call and prouoke, euen from the East, and so forth to the VVest:
〈♫〉
From tovvard Sion vvhich place him liketh best: God vvill appeare in beautie
〈♫〉
most excellent. Our God vvill come before that long time be spent.

div.head: TENOR, or Faburden.
div.p:
☞ 〈♫〉
THE mighty God th'Eternall hath thus spoke and all the vvorld
〈♫〉
hee vvill call and prouoke, euen from the East, and so forth to the VVest.
〈♫〉
From tovvard Sion, vvhich place him liketh best: God vvill appeare in beautie
☞ 〈♫〉
most excel- lent, Our God vvill come before that long time be spent.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
THE mighty God th'Eternall hath thus spoke, and all the vvorld
〈♫〉
he vvill call and prouoke, euen from the East, and so forth to the VVest:
〈♫〉
From tovvard Sion vvhich place him liketh best. God vvill appear in beautie
〈♫〉
most excellent. Our God vvill come before that long time be spent.

lg.l: Deuouring fire
s • all go • before his face,
A great tempest
shall round about him trace.
Then shall he call
the 〈◊〉 a • d heauens bright,
To iudge his folke
vvith equitie and right.
Saving goe to
and novv my Saints assemble▪
My he • s they keepe,
their gifts doe not dissemble.
The heauens shall
declare his righteousnesse:
For God is Iudge
of all things more and lesse:
Heare my people,
for I vvill novv reueale:
List Israel,
I vvill thee nought conceale.
Thy God thy God
am I, and vvill not blame thee:
For giuing not
all manner offerings to me.
I haue not neede
to take of thee at all,
Goats of thy fold,
or calfe out of thy stall.
For all the beasts
are mine vvithin the vvoods,
On thousand hils
cattell are mine ovvne goods,
I knovv for mine
all birds that are on mountaines:
All beasts are mine
vvhich haunt the fields and fountaines▪
Hungry if I vvere,
I vvould not thee it tell:
For all is mine
that in the vvorld doe dvvell.
Eate I the flesh
of great Buls or Bullocks?
Or drinke the bloud
of Goats, or of the flockes?
Offer to God
prayse and hearty thanksgiuing:
And pay thy vovves
vnto God euerliuing.
Call vpon me,
vvhen troubled thou shalt be,
Then vvill I help,
and thou shalt honour me.
To the vvicked,
thus saith the eternall God:
VVhy dost thou preach
my lavves and hests abroad,
Seeing thou hast
them vvith thy mouth abused.
And hat'st to be
by discipline reformed?
My vvords I say,
thou dost reiect and hate:
If that thou see
a theefe, as vvith thy mate,
Thou runst vvith him▪
and so your prey doe seeke:
And art all one
vvith bauds and ruffians eke:
Thou giuest thy selfe
to backbite and to slander,
And hovv thy tongue
deceiueth, it's a vvonder.
Thou sittest musing
thy brother hovv to blame:
And hovv to put
thy mothers sonne to shame:
These things thou didst,
and vvhilst I held my tongue,
Thou didst me iudge
(because I staid so long)
Like to thy selfe,
yet though I keepe long silence,
Once shalt thou feele
of thy vvrongs iust recompence.
Consider this
ye that forget the Lord▪
And feare not vvhen
he threatneth vvith his vvord:
Lest vvithout help
I spoyle you as a prey.
But he that thanks
offreth, praiseth me aye,
Saith the Lord God,
and he that vvalketh this trace,
I vvill him teach
Gods sauing health to imbrace.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
THE God of Gods, the Lord hath calde the earth by name:

〈♫〉
From vvhere the Sunne doth rise, vnto the setting of the same.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
THE God of Gods, the Lord hath calde the earth by name:

〈♫〉
From vvhere the Sunne doth rise, vnto the setting of the same.

div.head: TENOR, or Playnsong.
div.l:
☞ 〈♫〉
THE God of Gods, the Lord hath calde the earth by name:

〈♫〉
From vvhere the Sunne doth rise, vnto the setting of the same.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
THE God of Gods, the Lord hath calde the earth by name:

〈♫〉
From vvhere the Sunne doth rise, vnto the setting of the same.

lg.l: From Sion his faire place,
his glory bright and cleare:
The perfect beauty of his grace,
from thence it did appeare.
Our God shall come in haste,
to speake he shall not doubt:
Before him shall the fire vvaste,
and tempest round about.
The heauens from on hie,
the earth belovv likevvise:
He vvill call forth to iudge and try,
his folke he doth deuise.
Bring forth my Saints, saith he,
my faithfull • ock • to deare:
VVhich are in bond and league vvith me
my lavv to loue and feare.
And vvhen these things are tride,
the heauens shall record:
That God is iust, and all must bide
the iudgements of the Lord.
My people O giue heed,
Israel to thee I cry:
I am thy God, thy helpe at need,
thou canst it not deny.
I doe not say to thee,
thy sacrifice is • lack?
Thou offerest daily vnto me,
much more then I doe lack.
Thinkst thou that I doe need
thy cattell young or old?
Or else so much desire to feed,
on Goats out of thy folde?
Nay, all the beasts are mine,
in vvoods that eate their fils:
And thousands more of neat and kine,
that run vvilde on the hils.
The birds that build on hie,
in hils and out of sight:
And beasts that in the fields doe lye.
are subiect to my might.
Then though I hunger sore,
vvhat need I ought of thine:
Sith that the earth vvith her great store,
and all therein is mine?
To buls flesh haue I minde,
to eate it dost thou thinke?
Or such a svveetnesse doe I finde,
the bloud of Goates to drinke▪
Giue to the Lord his praise,
vvith thanks to him apply:
And see thou pay thy vovves a lvvayes
vnto the Lord most hye.
Then seeke and call to me.
vvhen ought vvould vvorke thee blame:
And I vvill sure deliuer thee,
that thou maist praise my name.
But to the vvicked traine,
vvhich talke of God each day:
And yet their vvorks are foule and vain,
to them the Lord vvill say,
VVith vvhat a face dar'st thou,
my vvord once speake or name?
VVhy doth thy talke my lavv allovv,
thy deeds deny the same?
VVhereas for to amend
thy life thou art so slack:
My vvord, the vvhich thou dost pretend,
is cast behinde thy backe.
VVhen thou a theefe dost see,
by theft to liue in vvealth:
VVith him thou runst, and dost agree
likevvise to thriue by stealth.
VVhen thou dost them behold,
that vviues and maides defile:
Thou likest it vvell, and vvaxest bold
to vse that life most vile.
Thy lips thou dost apply,
to slander and defame:
Thy tongue is • aught to craft and lye,
and still doth vse the same.
Thou studiest to reuile
thy friends to thee so neere:
VVith slander thou vvouldst needs defile
thy mothers sonne most deare.
Hereat vvhile I doe vvinke,
as though I did not see:
Thou goest on still, and so dost thinke
that I am like to thee.
But sure I vvill not let
to strike vvhen I begin:
Thy faults in order I vvill set,
and open all thy sinne.
Marke this I you require,
that haue not God in minde:
Le • t vvhen I plague you in my ire,
your helpe be far to finde.
He that doth giue to me
the sacrifice of praise:
Doth please me vvell, and he shall see
to vvalke in godly vvayes.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
O Lord consider my distresse, and novv vvith speed some pittie
〈♫〉
take: My sinnes deface, my faults redresse: good Lord for thy great mercies
〈♫〉
sake. VVash me O Lord, and make me cleane from this vniust and sinfull
〈♫〉
act: and purifie yet once againe, my hainous crime and bloudy fact.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
O Lord consider my distresse, and novv vvith speed some pitty
〈♫〉
take: My sinnes deface, my faults redresse, good Lord for thy great mercies
〈♫〉
sake. VVash me O Lord, and make me cleane from this vniust and sinfull
〈♫〉
act: and purifie yet once againe, my hainous crime and bloudy fact.

div.head: TENOR, or Playnsong.
div.p:
☞ 〈♫〉
O Lord consider my distresse, and novv vvith speed some pittie
〈♫〉
take: My sinnes deface, my faults redresse, good Lord for thy great mercies
〈♫〉
sake. VVash me O Lord, and make me cleane from this vniust and sinfull
☞ 〈♫〉
act: and purifie yet once againe, my hainous crime and bloudy fact.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
O Lord consider my distresse, and novv vvith speed some pittie
〈♫〉
take: My sinnes deface, my faults redresse, good Lord for thy great mercies
〈♫〉
sake, VVash me O Lord, and make me cleane from this vniust and sinfull
〈♫〉
act: and puri- fie yet once againe, my hainous crime and bloudy fact.

lg.l: Remorse and sorrovv doe constraine
Me to acknovvledge mine excesse:
My sinnes alas doe still remaine
Before my face vvithout release.
For thee alone I haue of • en led,
Committing euill in thy sight.
And if I vvere therefore condemned.
Yet vvere thy iudgements iust and right,
It is too manifest alas,
That first I vvas conceiued in sinne,
Yea, of my mother so borne vvas,
And yet vile vvretch remaine therein▪
Also behold Lord thou dost loue
The invvard truth of a pure heart:
Therefore thy vvisedome from aboue,
Thou hast reueal'd me to conuert.
If thou vvith Hysop purge this blot,
I shall be cleaner then the glasse:
And if thou vvash avvay my spot,
The snovv in vvhitenesse shall I passe.
Therefo • e O Lord such ioy me send,
• hat invvardly I may finde grace:
And that my strength may novv amend.
VVhich thou hast svvag'd for my trespas.
Turne back thy face & frovvning ire,
For I haue felt enough thy hand:
And purge my sinnes I thee desire,
VVhich doe in number passe the sand.
Make nevv my heart vvithin my brest,
And frame it to thy holy vvill:
Thy constant spirit in me let rest,
VVhich may these raging enemies kill:
Cast me not Lord out from thy face,
But speedily my torments end:
Take not from me thy spirit and grace,
VVhich may from danger me defend.
Restore me to those ioyes againe,
VVhich I vvas vvont in the to finde:
And let me thy free spirit retaine,
VVhich vnto thee may stirre my minde.
Thus vvhen I shall thy mercies knovv
I shall instruct others therein:
And men likevvise that are brought lovv
By mine ensample shall flye sinne.
O God that of my health art Lord,
Forgiue me this my bloudy vice:
My heart and tongue shall then accord,
To sing thy mercies and iustice.
Touch thou my lips, my tongue vntie,
O Lord vvhich onely art the key:
And then my mouth shall testifie
Thy vvondro • s vvorks & praise alvvay▪
And as for outvvard sacrifice,
I vvould haue offered many a one:
But thou esteemest them of no price,
And therein pleasure takest none.
The heauie heart, the minde opprest,
O Lord thou neuer dost reiect:
And to speake truth it is the best,
And of all sacrifice the effect.
Lord vnto Sion turne thy face.
Poure out thy mercies on thy hill
And on Ierusalem thy grace,
Build vp the vvals and loue it still.
Thou shalt accept then our offrings▪
Of peace and righteousnesse I say:
Yea, Calues and many other things
Vpon thine Altar vvill vve lay.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
HAue mercy on mee God af- ter thy great abundant grace:

〈♫〉
After thy mercies multi- tude, doe thou my sinnes de- face.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
HAue mercy on mee God after thy great abundant grace:

〈♫〉
After thy mercies multitude, doe thou my sinnes deface.

div.head: TENOR, or Playnsong.
div.l:
☞ 〈♫〉
HAue mercy on me God after thy great abundant grace:

〈♫〉
After thy mercies multitude, doe thou my sinnes deface.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
HAue mercy on mee God after thy great abundant grace:

〈♫〉
After thy mercies multi- tude, doe thou my sinnes deface.

lg.l: Yea, vvash me more from mine offence,
and cleanse me from my sinne:
For I doe knovv my faults and still
my sinnes are in mine eyne.
Against thee, thee alone I haue
offended in this case:
And euill haue I done before
the presence of thy face.
That in the things that thou dost say,
vpright thou maist be tride:
And eke in iudging that the doome▪
may passe vpon thy side.
Behold, in vvickednesse my kinde
and shape I did receiue:
And loe my sinfull mother eke,
in sinne did me conceiue.
But loe the truth of invvard parts
is pleasant vnto thee:
And secrets of thy vvisedome thou
reuealed hast to me.
VVith Hysop Lord besprinkle me,
I shall be cleansed so:
Yea, vvash thou me, and so I shall
be vvhiter then the snovv.
Of ioy and gladnesse make thou me
to heare the pleasing voyce:
That so the bruised bones vvhich thou
hast broken may reioyce.
From the beholding of my sinnes,
Lord turne avvay thy face:
And all my deeds of vvickednesse,
doe vtterly deface.
O God create in me a heart
vnspotted in thy sight.
And eke vvithin my bovvels Lord▪
renu • a stabled spirit.
Ne cast me from thy sight, nor ta • e
thy holy spirit avvay:
The comfort of thy sauing grace,
giue me againe I pray.
VVith thy free spirit establish me,
and I vvill teach therefore,
Sinners thy vvayes, and vvicked shall
be turned to thy lore.
O God that art my God of health,
from bloud deliuer me:
That prayses of thy righteousnesse,
my tongue may sing to thee.
My lips that yet fast closed be,
doe thou O Lord vnlose:
The praises of thy maiestie,
my mouth shall so disclose.
I vvould haue offered sacrifice,
if that had pleased thee:
But pleased vvith burnt offerings,
I knovv thou vvilt not be.
A troubled spirit is sacrifice,
delightfull in Gods eyes:
A broken and an humble heart,
God thou vvilt not despise.
In thy good vvill deale gently Lord
to Sion, and vvithall
Grant that of thy Ierusalem,
vpreard may be the vvall.
Burnt offerings, gifts, and sacrifice,
of iustice in that day:
Thou shalt accept, and Calues they shall
vpon thine Altar lay.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
WHY dost thou tyrant boast abroad, thy vvicked vvorkes to
〈♫〉
praise? dost thou not knovv there is a God, vvhose mercies last alvvayes?
〈♫〉
VVhy doth thy minde yet still deuise such vvicked vviles to vvarp? Thy
〈♫〉
tongue vntrue in forging lyes, is like a rasor sharpe.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
WHY dost thou tyrant boast abroad thy vvicked vvorkes to
〈♫〉
praise? dost thou not knovv there is a God, vvhose mercies last alvvayes?
〈♫〉
VVhy doth thy minde yet still deuise such vvicked vviles to vvarp? Thy
〈♫〉
tongue vntrue in forging lyes, is like a rasor sharpe.

div.head: TENOR, or Playnsong.
div.p:
☞ 〈♫〉
WHY dost thou tyrant boast abroad, thy vvicked vvorkes to
〈♫〉
praise▪ dost thou not knovv there is a God, vvhose mercies last alvvayes?
〈♫〉
VVhy doth thy minde yet still deuise such vvicked vviles to vvarp? Thy
〈♫〉
tongue vntrue in forging lyes is like a rasor sharpe.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
WHY dost thou tyrant boast abroad, thy vvicked vvorkes to
〈♫〉
praise? dost thou not knovv there is a God, vvhose mercies last alvvayes?
〈♫〉
VVhy doth thy minde yet still deuise such vvicked vviles to vvarp? Thy
〈♫〉
tongue vntrue in forging lyes, is like a rasor sharpe.

lg.l: On mischiefe vvhy sets • thou thy mind,
and vvilt not vvalke vpright?
Thou hast more lust false tales to finde▪
then bring the truth to light.
Thou dost delight in fraud and guile,
in mischiefe, bloud, and vvrong:
Thy lips haue learnd the flattering stile,
O thou deceitfull tongue.
Therefore God shall for euer confound
and plucke thee from thy place:
Thy seed root out from off the ground,
and so shall thee deface:
The iust vvhen they behold thy fall,
vvith feare shall praise the Lord:
And in reproach of thee vvithall,
cry out vvith one accord.
Behold the man vvhich vvould not take
the Lord for his defence:
But of his goods his God did make,
and trust his corrupt sence.
But I an Oliue fresh and greene,
vvill spring and spread abroad:
For vvhy? my trust all times hath beene
vpon the liuing God.
For this therefore vvill I giue praise
to thee vvith heart and voyce:
I vvill set forth thy name alvvayes
vvherein thy Saints reioyce.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
THe foolish man in that vvhich he vvithin his heart hath said:

〈♫〉
That there is any God at all, hath vtterly de- naid.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
THe foolish man in that vvhich he vvithin his heart hath said:

〈♫〉
That there is any God at all, hath vtterly de- naid.

div.head: TENOR, or Playnsong.
div.l:
☞ 〈♫〉
THe foolish man in that vvhich he vvithin his heart hath said:

〈♫〉
That there is any God at all, hath vtterly denaid.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
THe foolish man in that vvhich he vvithin his heart hath said:

〈♫〉
That there is any God at all, hath vtterly denaid.

lg.l: They are corrupt, and they also
a hainous vvorke haue vv • ought:
Among them all there is not one,
of good that vvorketh ought:
The Lord lookt dovvn on sons on men
from heauen all abroad:
To see if any vvere that vvould
be vvise, and seeke for God.
They are all gone out of the vvay,
they are corrupted all:
There is not one doth any good,
there is not one at all.
Doe not all vvicked vvorkers knovv
that they doe feed vpon
My people as they feed on bread?
the Lord they call not on.
Euen there they vvere afraid, & stood
vvith trembling all dismaid:
VVhereas there vvas no cause at all
vvhy they should be afraid.
For God his bones that thee besiegde
hath scattered all abroad:
Thou hast confounded them, for they
reiected are of God.
O Lord giue thou thy people health,
and thou O Lord fulfill
Thy promise made to Israel▪
from out of Sion hill.
VVhen God his people shall restore▪
that earst vvas captiue led:
Then Iacob shall therein reioyce,
and Israel shall be glad.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
GOD saue mee for thy holy name, and for thy goodnesse sake:

〈♫〉
Vnto the strength (Lord) of the same, I doe my cause betake.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
GOd saue mee for thy holy name, and for thy goodnesse sake:

〈♫〉
Vnto the strength (Lord) of the same, I doe my cause betake.

div.head: TENOR, or Playnsong.
div.l:
☞ 〈♫〉
GOD saue me for thy ho- ly name, and for thy goodnesse sake:

〈♫〉
Vnto the strength (Lord) of the same, I doe my cause betake.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
GOd saue me for thy ho- ly name, and for thy goodnesse sake:

〈♫〉
Vnto the strength (Lord) of the same, I doe my cause betake.

lg.l: Regard O Lord and giue an eare
to me vvhen I doe pray.
Bovv dovvne thy selfe to me, and heare
the vvords that I doe say.
For strange • s vp against me rise,
and tyrants vexe me still:
VVhich haue not God before their eyes,
they seeke my soule to spill.
But loe my God doth giue me aide,
the Lord is straight at hand
VVith them by vvhom my soule is staid,
the Lord doth euer stand.
VVith plagues repay againe all those
for me that lye in vvaite:
And in thy truth destroy my foes
vvith their ovvne, sna • e and baite.
An offering of free heart and vvill,
then I to thee shall make:
And praise thy name, for therein still
great comfort doe I take.
O Lord at length doe set me free
from them that craft conspire:
And novv mine eyes vvith ioy doe see
of them my hearts desire.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
O God giue eare, and doe apply to heare me vvhen I pray:

〈♫〉
And vvhen to thee I call and cry, hide not thy face a- vvay.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
O God giue eare, and doe apply to heare me vvhen I pray:

〈♫〉
And vvhen to thee I call and cry, hide not thy face avvay.

div.head: TENOR, or Playnsong.
div.l:
☞ 〈♫〉
O God giue eare, and doe apply to heare me vvhen I pray:

〈♫〉
And vvhen to thee I call and cry, hide not thy face a-vvay.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
O God giue eare, and doe apply to heare vvhen I doe pray:

〈♫〉
And vvhen to thee I call and cry, hide not thy face avvay.

lg.l: Take heede to me, grant my request,
and ansvvere me againe:
VVith plaints I pray, full sore opprest,
great griefe doth me constraine.
Because my foes vvith threats & cryes,
oppresse me through despight:
And so the vvicked sort likevvise,
to vexe me haue delight.
For they in counsell doe conspire
to charge me vvith some ill:
So in their hasty vvrath and ire,
they doe pursue me still.
My heart doth faint for vvant of breath
it panteth in my brest:
The terrors and the dread of death
doe vvorke me much vnrest.
Such dreadfull feare on me doth fall,
that I therevvith doe quake:
Such horror vvhelmeth me vvithall,
that I no shift can make.
But I doe say, vvho vvill giue me
the svvift and pleasant vvings
Of some faire Doue, that I may flye,
and tell the from these things.
〈◊〉 then I vvould goe farre avvay
to flye I vvould not cease:
And I vvould hide my selfe, and stay
in some great vvildernesse.
I vvould be gone in all the haste,
and not abide behinde:
That I vvere quite and ouer-past
these blasts of boystrous vvinde.
Diuide them Lord, and from them pull
their diuellish double tongue:
For I haue spied their Citie full
of • apine, strife, and vvrong.
VVhich things both night and day throughout
doe close her as a vvall
In midst of her is mischiefe stout,
and sorrovv eke vvithall.
Her priuie parts are vvicked plaine,
her deeds are much too vile:
And in her streets there doth remaine
all crasty fraud, and guile.
If that my foes did seeke my shame,
I might it vvell abide:
From open enemies checke and blame,
some vvhere I could me hide.
But thou it vvas my fellovv deare,
vvhich friendship didst pretend▪
And didst my secret counsell heare,
as my familiar friend.
VVith vvhom I had desire to talke
in secret and abroad:
And vve together oft did vvalke,
vvithin the house of God.
Let death in haste vpon them fall,
and send them quicke to hell:
For mischiefe raigneth in their hall
and parlour vvhere they dvvell.
But I vnto my God doe cry,
to him for helpe I flye:
The Lord doth heare me by and by,
and he doth succour me.
At morning noone, and euening tide
vnto the Lord I pray:
VVhen I so instantly haue cride,
he doth not say me nay.
To peace he shall restore me yet,
though vvar be novv at hand:
Although the number be full great,
that vvould against me stand.
• he Lord that first and last doth raign,
both novv and euermore:
VVill heare vvhen I to him complaine,
and punish them full sore.
For sure there is no hope that they
to turne vvill once accord:
For vvhy▪ they vvill not once obey,
nor doe not feare the Lord.
Vpō their friends they lay their hands
vvhich vvere in couenant knit:
Of friendship to neglect the bands,
they passe or care no vvhit.
VVhile they haue vvar vvithin their hearts,
as butter are their vvords▪
Although their vvords vvere smooth as oyle,
they cut as sharpe as svvords:
Cast thou thy care vpou the Lord,
and he shall nourish thee:
For in no vvise he vvill accord
the iust in thrall to see.
But God shall cast them deepe in pit,
that thirst for bloud alvvayes:
He vvill no guilefull man permit
to liue out halfe his dayes.
Though such be quite destroyd & gone
in thee O Lord I trust,
I shall depend thy grace vpon,
vvith all my heart and lust,

div.head: CANTVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
HAue mercy Lord on mee I pray, for man vvould mee deuoure:

〈♫〉
He fighteth vvith me night and day, and troubleth me each houre.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
HAue mercy Lord on me I pray, for man vvould mee deuoure:

〈♫〉
He fighteth vvith me night and day, and troubleth me each houre.

div.head: TENOR, or Playnsong.
div.l:
☞ 〈♫〉
HAue mercy Lord on me I pray, for man vvould me deuoure:

〈♫〉
He fighteth vvith me night and day, and troubleth me each houre.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
HAue mercy Lord on me I pray, for man vvould mee deuoure:

〈♫〉
He fighteth vvith me night and day, and troubleth me each houre.

lg.l: Mine enemies daily enterprise,
to svvallovv me out-right:
To fight against me many rise,
O thou most high of might.
VVhen they vvould make me most afraid
vvith boasts and brags of pride:
I trust in thee alone for aide,
by thee I vvill abide.
Gods promise I doe minde and praise,
O Lord I trust to thee:
I doe not care at all assaies,
vvhat flesh can doe to me.
VVhat things I eyther did or spake,
they vvrest them at their vvill:
And all their counsell that they take,
is hovv to vvorke me ill.
They all consent, themselues to hide,
close vvatch for me to lay:
To spie my pathes, and snares haue laid
to take my life avvay.
Shall they thus scape on mischiefe set:
thou God on them vvilt frovvne:
For in his vvrath he doth not let
to throvv vvhole kingdomes dovvne.
Thou seest hovv oft they make me flee,
and on my teares doth looke:
Reserue them in a glasse by thee,
and vvrite them in thy booke.
VVhen I doe call vpon thy name,
my foes avvay doe start:
I vvell perceiue it by the same,
that God doth take my part.
I glory in the vvord of God,
to praise it I accord:
VVith ioy I shall declare abroad,
the promise of the Lord.
I trust in God, and yet I say
as I before began:
The Lord he is my helpe and stay,
I doe not care for man.
I vvill performe vvith heart so free,
to God my vovves alvvayes:
And I O Lord all times to thee
vvill offer thanks and praise.
My soule from death thou dost defend,
and keepe my feet vpright:
That I before thee may ascend
vvith such as liue in light.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
TAke pittie for thy promise sake, haue mercy Lord on me: For
〈♫〉
vvhy▪ my soule doth her betake vnto the helpe of thee.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
TAke pittie for thy promise sake, haue mercy Lord on me: For
〈♫〉
vvhy? my soule doth her betake vnto the helpe of thee.

div.head: TENOR, or Playnsong.
div.p:
☞ 〈♫〉
TAke pittie for thy promise sake, haue mercy Lord on me: For
〈♫〉
vvhy? my soule doth her betake, vnto the helpe of thee.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
TAke pittie for thy promise sake, haue mercy Lord on me: For
〈♫〉
vvhy? my soule doth her betake vnto the helpe of thee.

lg.l: VVithin the shadovv of thy vvings,
I set my selfe full fast,
Till mischiefe, malice, and like things
be gone and ou • rpast.
I call vpon the God most hye,
to vvhom I sticke and stand:
I meane the God that vvill stand by
the cause I haue in hand.
From heauen he hath sent his aide,
to saue me from their spight:
That to deuoure me haue assaid
his mercy, truth, and might.
I lead my life vvith Lyors fell,
all set on vvrath and ire:
And vvith such vvicked men I dvvell,
that fret like flames of fire.
Their teeth are speares and arrovves long,
as sharp as I haue seene:
They vvound and cut vvith their quicke tongue
like svvords & vveapons keen.
Set vp and shevv thy selfe O God,
aboue the heauens bright:
Exalt thy praise on earth abroad,
thy maiestie and might.
They lay their nets, and doe prepare
a priuie cause and pit:
VVherein they thinke my soule to snare,
but they are fallen in it.
My heart is set to laud the Lord,
in him I ioy alvvayes:
My heart I say doth vvell accord
to sing his laud and praise.
Avvake my ioy, avvake I say,
my Lute, my Harpe and string:
For I my selfe before the day,
vvill rise, reioyce, and sing.
Among the people I vvill tell
the goodnesse of my God:
And shevv his praise that doth excell
in heathen Lands abroad.
His mercy doth extend as far
as heauens all are hye:
His truth as high as any Starre
that standeth in the skie.
Set forth and shevv thy selfe O God,
aboue the heauens bright:
Extoll thy praise on earth abroad,
thy maiestie and might.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
YE Rulers vvhich are put in trust to iudge of vvrong and right:

〈♫〉
Be all your iudgements true and iust, not knovving meede or might?

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
YE Rulers vvhich are put in trust to iudge of vvrong and right:

〈♫〉
Be all your iudgements true and iust, not knovving meede or might?

div.head: TENOR, or Playnsong.
div.l:
☞ 〈♫〉
YE Rulers vvhich are put in trust to iudge of vvrong and right:

〈♫〉
Be all your iudgements true and iust, not knovving meede or might?

div.head: BASSVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
YE Rulers vvhich are put in trust to iudge of vvrong and right:

〈♫〉
Be all your iudgements true and iust, not knovving meede or might?

lg.l: Nay in your hearts you mark and muse
in mischiefe to consent
And vvhere you should true iustice vse,
your hands to bribes are bent.
The vvicked sort from their birth day,
haue erred on this vvise:
And from their mothers vvombe alvvay,
haue vsed craft and lyes.
In them the poyson and the breath
of Serpents did appeare:
Yea, like the Adder that is deafe,
and fast doth stop his eare.
Because he vvill not heare the voyce
of one that charmeth vvell:
No though he vvere the chiefe of choice
and did therein excell.
O God breake thou their teeth at once
vvithin their mouthes throughout:
The tusks that in their great iavv-bones
like Lyons vvhelps hang out.
Let them consume avvay and vvaste,
as vvater run'th throughout.
The shafts that they doe shoote in haste,
let them be broke in • ight.
As Snailes doe vvaste vvithin the shell,
and vnto •• ime doe runne:
As one before his time that fell,
and neuer savv the Sunne.
Before the thornes that novv are yong
to bushes big shall grovv:
The stormes of anger vvaxing strong,
shall take them ere they knovv.
The iust shall ioy, it doth them good
that God doth vengeance take▪
And they shall vvash their feet in bloud
of them that him forsake.
Then shall the earth shevv forth & tell
that good men haue revvard:
And that a God on earth doth dvvell.
that iustice doth regard.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
SEnd ayde and saue me from my foes, O Lord I pray to thee:
〈♫〉
Defend & keepe me from all those that rise and striue vvith me, O Lord pre-
〈♫〉
serue me from those men, vvhose doings are not good: and set me sure and
〈♫〉
safe from them, that still thirst after bloud.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
SEnd ayde and saue me from my foes. O Lord I pray to thee:
〈♫〉
Defend & keepe me from all those that rise and striue vvith me. O Lord pre-
〈♫〉
serue me from those men, vvhose doings are not good: and set me sure and
〈♫〉
safe from them, that still thirst after bloud.

div.head: TENOR, or Playnsong.
div.p:
☞ 〈♫〉
SEnd ayde and saue me from my foes, O Lord I pray to thee:
☞ 〈♫〉
Defend & keepe me from all those that rise and striue vvith me. O Lord pre-
〈♫〉
serue me from those men, vvhose doings are not good: and set me sure and
〈♫〉
safe from them, that still thirst after bloud.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
SEnd ayde and saue me from my foes, O Lord I pray to thee:
〈♫〉
Defend & keep me from all those that rise and striue vvith me. O Lord pre-
〈♫〉
serue me from those men, vvhose doings are not good: and set me sure and
〈♫〉
safe from them, that still thirst after bloud.

lg.l: For loe they vvait my soule to take,
they rage against me still:
Yea for no fault that I did make,
I neuer did them ill.
They run, and doe themselues prepare,
vvhen I no vvhit offend:
Arise, and saue me from their snare,
and see vvhat they intend.
O Lord of hosts of Israel,
rise vp and strike all lands:
And pittie none that doe rebell,
and in their mischiefe stands.
At night they stir and seeke about,
as hounds they houle and grin:
And all the Citie cleane throughout,
from place to place they ren.
They spake of me vvith mouth alvvay,
but in their lips vvere svvords:
They greed my death▪ and then vvould say
vvhat, none can heare our vvords.
But Lord thou hast their vvayes espide,
and laught thereat apace:
The heathen folke thou shalt deride,
and mocke them to their face.
The strength that doth my foes vvithstand,
O Lord doth come of thee:
My God he is my helpe at hand,
a fort of fence to me.
The Lord to me doth shevv his grace
in great abundance still:
That I may see my foes in case,
such as my heart doth vvill.
Destroy them not at once O God,
lest it from minde doe fall:
But vvith thy strength driue them abroad
and so consume them all.
For their ill vvords & truthles tongue,
confound them in their pride:
Their vvicked othes vvith lyes & vvrong
let all the vvorld deride.
Consume them in thy vvrath O Lord,
that nought of them remaine:
That men may knovv throughout the vvorld
that Iacobs God doth raigne.
At euening they returne apace,
as dogs they grin and cry:
Throughout the streets in euery place,
they runne about and spie.
They seeke about for meat I say.
but let them not be fed:
Nor finde a house vvherein they may
be bold to put their head.
But I vvill shevv thy strength abroad
thy goodnesse I vvill praise:
For thou art my defence and aide
at need in all assayes.
Thou art my strength, thou hast me staid
O Lord I sing to thee:
Thou art my fort my strength and aide,
a louing God to me.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
O Lord thou didst vs cleane forsake, and scatteredst vs abroad:
〈♫〉
Such great displeasure thou didst take, returne to vs O God.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
O Lord thou didst vs cleane forsake, and scatteredst vs abroad:
〈♫〉
Such great displeasure thou didst take, returne to vs O God.

div.head: TENOR, or Playnsong.
div.p:
☞ 〈♫〉
O Lord thou didst vs cleane forsake, and scatteredst vs abroad:
☞ 〈♫〉
Such great displeasure thou didst take, returne to vs O God.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
O Lord thou didst vs cleane forsake, and scatteredst vs abroad:
〈♫〉
Such great displeasure thou didst take, returne to vs O God.

lg.l: Thy might did moue the land so sore,
that it in sunder brake:
The hurt thereof O Lord restore,
for it doth bovv and quake.
VVith heauy chance thou plaguest thus
the people that are thine:
And thou hast giuen vnto vs
a drinke of deadly vvine.
But yet to such as feare thy name,
a token shall ensue:
That they may triumph in the • ame,
because thy vvord is true.
So that thy might may keep and saue
thy flocke that fauour thee:
That they thy help at hand may haue,
O Lord grant this to me.
The Lord did speake from his ovvne place,
this vvas his ioyfull tale:
I vvill diuide Sichem by space,
and mete out Succoths vale.
Gilead is giuen to my hand,
Manasses mine beside:
Eph •• im the strength of all my Land,
my Lavv doth Iuda guide.
In Moab vvill I vvash my feet,
ouer Edom throvv my shoe:
And thou Palestine ought to seeke
for fauour me vnto.
But vvho vvill bring me at this tide,
vnto the Citie strong?
Or vvho to Edom vvil me guide,
so that I goe not vvrong:
VVilt thou O God vvhich didst forsake
thy folke, their land and coasts?
Our vvars in hand thou vvouldst not take
not vvalke among our hoasts.
Giue aide O Lord, and vs relieue
from them that vs disdaine:
The help that hoasts of men cau giue,
it is but all in vaine.
But through our God vve shall haue might
to take great things in hand:
He vvill tread dovvne and put to flight,
all those that thee vvithstand.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
REgard (O Lord) for I complaine, and make my sute to thee: Let
〈♫〉
not my vvords returne in vaine, but giue an eare to mee. From off the
〈♫〉
coasts and vtmost parts of all the earth abroad: in griefe and anguish of
〈♫〉
my heart, I cry to thee O God.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
REgard (O Lord) for I complaine, and make my sute to thee: Let
〈♫〉
not my vvords returne invaine, but giue an eare to mee. From off the
〈♫〉
coasts and vtmost parts of all the earth abroad: in griefe and anguish of
〈♫〉
my heart, I cry to thee O God.

div.head: TENOR, or Playnsong.
div.p:
☞ 〈♫〉
REgard (O Lord) for I complaine, and make my sute to thee: Let
〈♫〉
not my vvords returne in vaine, but giue an eare to me. From off the
〈♫〉
coasts and vtmost parts of all the earth abroad: in griefe and anguish of
☞ 〈♫〉
my heart, I cry to thee O God.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
REgard (O Lord) for I complaine, and make my sute to thee: Let
〈♫〉
not my vvords returne in vaine, but giue an eare to mee. From off the
〈♫〉
coasts and vtmost parts of all the earth abroad: in griefe and anguish of
〈♫〉
my heart, I cry to thee O God.

lg.l: Vpon the rocke of thy great povver,
my vvofull minde repose:
Thou art my hope my fort, and tovver,
my • ence against my foes.
VVithin thy tents I lust to dvvell,
for euer to indure.
Vnder thy vvings I knovv right vvell
I shall be safe and sure.
The Lord doth my desire regard,
and doth fulfill the same:
VVith godly gifts doth the revvard
all them that feare his name.
and so prolong his dayes:
That he from age to age shall raigne,
for euermore alvvayes.
That he may haue a dvvelling place
before the Lord for aye:
O let thy mercy, truth and grace
defend him from decay.
Then shall I sing for euer still,
vvith praise vnto thy name:
That all my vovves I may fulfill,
and daily pay the same.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
MY soule to God shall giue good heed, and him alone intend:

〈♫〉
For vvhy? my health and hope to speed, doth vvhole on him depend.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
MY soule to God shall giue good heed, and him alone intend:

〈♫〉
For vvhy? my health, and hope to speed, doth vvhole on him depend.

div.head: TENOR, or Playnsong.
div.l:
☞ 〈♫〉
MY soule to God shall giue good heed, and him alone intend:

〈♫〉
For vvhy? my health and hope to speed, doth vvhole on him depend.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
MY soule to God shall giue good heed, and him alone intend:

〈♫〉
For vvhy? my health and hope to speed, doth vvhole on him depend.

lg.l: For he alone is my defence,
my rocke of health, my aide:
He is my stay, that no pretence
shall make me much dismaid.
O vvicked folke, hovv long vvill ye
vse crafts? sure you must fall:
For as a rotten hedge ye be,
and like a tottering vvall.
VVhom God doth loue, ye seek alvvaies
to put him to the vvorse:
Ye loue tolye, vvith mouth ye praise,
and yet your heart doth curse.
Yet still my soule doth vvhole depend
on God my chiefe desire:
From all false feares me to defend,
none but him I require.
He is my rocke, my strength, my tovver,
my health is of his grace:
He doth support me, that no povver
can moue me out of place.
God is my glory and my health,
my soules desire and lust:
My fort, my strength, my stay, my vvealth,
God is my onely trust.
O haue your hope in him alvvay,
ye folke vvith one accord:
Poure out your hearts to him and say,
our trust is in the Lord.
The sonnes of men deceitfull are,
on ballance but a sleight:
VVith things most vaine doe them cōpare
for they can keepe no vveight.
Trust not in vvrong, robry or stealth,
let vaine delights be gone:
Though goods vvell got flovv in vvith vvealth,
set not your hearts thereon.
The Lord long sith one thing did tell,
vvhich here to minde I call:
He spake it oft, I heard it vvell,
that God alone doth all.
And thou O Lord art good and kinde,
thy mercy doth exceed:
So that all sorts vvith thee shall finde
according to their meed.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
O God my God I vvatch betime, to come to thee in haste:

〈♫〉
For vvhy? my soule and body both, doe thirst of thee to taste.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
O God my God I vvatch betime, to come to thee in haste:

〈♫〉
For vvhy? my soule and body both doe thirst of thee to taste.

div.head: TENOR, or Playnsong.
div.l:
☞ 〈♫〉
O God my God I vvatch betime, to come to thee in haste:

〈♫〉
For vvhy? my soule and body both doth thirst of thee to taste.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
O God my God I vvatch betime, to come to thee in haste:

〈♫〉
For vvhy? my soule and body both doe thirst of thee to taste.

lg.l: And in this barren vvildernesse,
vvhere vvaters there are none:
My flesh is parcht for thought of thee,
for thee I vvish alone.
That I might see yet once againe,
thy glory, strength and might:
As I vvas vvont it to behold,
vvithin thy Temple bright.
For vvhy thy mercies far furmount
this life and vvretched dayes:
My lips therefore shall giue to thee
due honour, land and praise,
And vvhilst I liue I vvill not faile
to vvorship thee alvvay.
And in thy name I shall lift vp
my hands vvhen I doe pray.
My soule is fild as vvith marrovv,
vvhich is both fat and svveet:
My mouth therefore shall sing such songs
as are for thee most meet.
VVhen as in bed I thinke on thee,
and eke all the night tide:
For vnder couert of thy vvings,
thou art my ioyfull guide.
My soule doth surely sticke to thee,
thy right hand is my povver.
And those that seeke my soule to stroy,
them death shall soone deuoure.
The svvord shall them deuoure each one,
their carkasses shall feed
The hungry Foxes vvhich doe run
their prey to seeke at need.
The King and all men shall reioyce,
that doe professe Gods vvord:
For lyers mouthes shall then be stopt,
vvhich haue the truth disturb'd.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
O Lord vnto my voyce giue eare, vvith plaints vvhen I doe pray:

〈♫〉
And rid my life and soule from feare of foes that threat to slay.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
O Lord vnto my voyce giue eare, vvith plaints vvhen I doe pray:

〈♫〉
And rid my life and soule from feare of foes that threat to slay.

div.head: TENOR, or Playnsong.
div.l:
☞ 〈♫〉
O Lord vnto my voyce giue eare, vvith plaints vvhen I doe pray:

〈♫〉
And rid my life and soule from feare of foes that threat to slay.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
O Lord vnto my voyce giue eare, vvith paines vvhen I doe pray:

〈♫〉
And rid my life and soule from feare of foes that threat to stay.

lg.l: Defend me from that fort of men▪
vvhich in deceits doe lurke:
And from the frovvning face of them
that all ill feates doe vvorke.
VVho vvhet their tongues as vve haue seene
men vvhet & sharp their svvords
They 〈◊〉 abroad their arrovves keene,
I meane most bitter vvords.
VVith priuie slights shoot they their shaft
the vpright man to hit:
The iust vnvvares to strike by craft,
they care or feare no vvhit.
A vvicked vvorke they haue decreed▪
in counsell thus they cry:
To vse deceit let vs not dread,
vvhat, vvho can it espie?
VVhat vvaies to hurt, they talke & muse
all times vvithin their heart:
They all consult vvhat feates to vse,
each doth inuent his part.
But yet all this shall not auaile
vvhen they thinke least vpon:
God vvith his darts shall sure assaile,
and vvound them euery one.
Their crafts & their ill tongues vvithal
shall vvorke themselues such blame:
That they vvhich then behold their fall,
shall vvonder at the same.
Then al that see shall knovv right vvel
that God this thing hath vvrought:
And praise his vvittie vvorks, and tell
vvhat he to passe hath brought.
Yet shall the iust in God reioyce,
still trusting in his might:
So shall they ioy vvith minde and voyce,
vvhose heart is pure and right.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
THY praise alone (O Lord) doth raigne in Sion thine ovvn hill:

〈♫〉
Their vovves to thee they doe maintaine, and their behests fulfill:

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
THy praise alone (O Lord) doth raigne in Sion thine ovvne hill:

〈♫〉
their vovves to thee they doe maintaine, and thy behests fulfill.

div.head: TENOR, or Playnsong.
div.l:
☞ 〈♫〉
THY praise alone (O Lord) doth raigne in Sion thine ovvn hill:

〈♫〉
Their vovves to thee they doe maintaine, and their behests fulfill:

div.head: BASSVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
THy praise alone (O Lord) doth raigne in Sion thine ovvne hill:

〈♫〉
Their vovves to thee they doe maintaine, and thy behests fulfill.

lg.l: For that thou dost their prayers heare,
and dost there to agree:
Thy people all both farre and neare,
vvith trust shall come to thee.
Our vvicked life so far exceeds,
that vve should fall therein:
But Lord forgiue our great misdeeds,
and purge vs from our sinne.
The man is blest vvhom thou dost chuse,
vvithin thy courts to dvvell:
Thy house and temple they doe vse,
vvith pleasures that excell.
Of thy great iustice heare vs God,
our health of thee doth rise:
The hope of all the earth abroad,
and the sea coasts likevvise.
VVith strength thou art beset about,
and compast vvith thy povver:
Thou makst the mountains strong & stout
to stand in euery shovver.
The svvelling seas thou dost assvvage,
and make their streames full still:
Thou dost restraine the peoples rage,
and rule them at thy vvill.
The folke that dvvell full far on earth,
shall dread the same to see:
VVhich morne & euening in great mirth
doe passe vvith praise to thee.
VVhen that the earth is chopt and dry,
and thirsteth more and more:
Then vvith thy drops thou dost apply,
and much increase her store.
The floud of God doth ouerflovv,
and so doth cause to spring:
The seed and corne vvhich men do sovv,
for he doth guide the thing.
VVith vvet thou dost her furrovves fill,
vvhereby her clods doe fall:
Thy drops to her thou dost distill,
and blesse her fruit vvithall.
Thou deckst the earth of thy good grace
vvith faire and pleasant crop:
Thy clouds distill their devv apace,
great plenty they doe drop.
VVhereby the desart shall begin
full great increase to bring:
The little hils doe ioy therein.
much fruit in them shall spring.
In places plaine the flocks shall feed
and couer all the earth:
The vallyes vvith corne shall so exceed,
that men shall sing for mirth.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
YEe men on earth in God reioyce, vvith praise set forth his name:

〈♫〉
Extoll his might vvith heart and voyce, giue glory to the same.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
YEe men on earth in God reioyce, vvith praise set forth his name:

〈♫〉
Extoll his might vvith heart and voyce, giue glory to the same.

div.head: TENOR, or Playnsong.
div.l:
☞ 〈♫〉
YEe men on earth in God reioyce, vvith praise set forth his name:

〈♫〉
Extoll his might vvith heart and voyce, giue glory to the same.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
YEe men on earth in God reioyce, vvith praise set forth his name:

〈♫〉
Extoll his might vvith heart and voyce, giue glory to the same.

lg.l: Hovv vvonderfull O Lord, say yee,
in all thy vvorks thou art▪
Thy foes for feare doe seeke to thee,
full sore against their heart.
All men that dvvell the earth throughout
doe praise the name of God:
The laud thereof the vvorld about,
is shevved and set abroad.
All folke come forth, behold and see
vvhat things the Lord hath vvrought:
Mark vvell the vvondrous vvorks that he
for man to passe hath brought.
He laid the sea like heapes on hye,
therein a vvay they had:
On foote to passe both faire and dry,
vvhereof their hearts vvere glad.
His might doth rule the vvorld alvvay,
his eyes all things behold:
All such as vvould him disobay,
by him shall be controld.
Yee people giue vnto your God
due laud and thankes alvvayes:
VVith ioyfull voyce declare abroad,
and sing vnto his praise.
VVhich doth indue our soules vvith life
and it preserues vvithall;
He stayeth our feete, so that no strife
can make vs slip or fall.
The Lord doth proue our deeds vvith fire,
if that they vvill abide:
As vvork-men doe vvhen they desire
to haue their mettals tride.
Although thou suffer vs so long
in prison to be cast:
And there vvith chaines & fetters strong,
to lie in bondage fast.
Although I say thou sufferest men,
on vs to ride and raigne:
Though vve through fire and vvater run
of very griefe and paine,
Yet sure thou dost of thy good grace
dispose it to the best.
And bringst vs out into a place,
to liue in vvealth and rest.
Vnto thy house resort vvill I,
to offer and to pray:
And there I vvill my selfe apply
my vovves to thee to pay.
The vovves that vvith my mouth I spake,
in all my griefe and smart:
The vovves I say vvhich I did make
in dolor of my heart.
Burnt offerings I vvill giue to thee,
of Oxen fat and Rammes,
None other sacrifice shall be,
of Bullocks, Goats, or Lambs.
Come forth & • earken here full soon,
all ye that feare the Lord:
VVhat he for his poore flocke hath done,
to you I vvill record.
Full oft I call vpon his grace,
this mouth to him doth cry:
And tho • my tongue make speed apace
to praise him by and by.
But if I feele my heart vvithin,
invvicked vvorkes reioyce:
Or if I haue delight in sinne,
God vvill not heare my voyce.
But surely God my voyce hath heard,
and vvhat I doe require:
My prayer he doth vvell regard,
and granteth my desire.
All praise to him that hath not put
nor cast me out of minde:
Nor yet his mercy from me shut,
vvhich I did euer finde.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
HAue mercy on vs Lord, and gr • nt to vs thy grace: To shevv
〈♫〉
to vs doe thou ac- cord, the brightnesse of thy face.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
HAue mercy on vs Lord, and grant to vs thy grace: To shevv
〈♫〉
to vs doe thou ac- cord, the brightnesse of thy face.

div.head: TENOR, or Playnsong.
div.p:
☞ 〈♫〉
HAue mercy on vs Lord, and grant to vs thy grace: To shevv
〈♫〉
to vs doe thou accord, the brightnesse of thy face.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
HAue mercy on vs Lord, and grant to vs thy grace: To shevv
〈♫〉
to vs doe thou accord, the brightnesse of thy face.

lg.l: That all the earth may knovv
the vvay to godly vvealth:
And all the nations on a rovv,
may see thy sauing health.
Let all the vvorld O God,
giue praise vnto thy name:
O let the people all abroad,
extoll and la • d the same.
Throughout the vvorld so vvide,
let all reioyce vvith mirth:
For thou vvith truth and right dost guide
the nations of the earth.
Let all the vvorld O God,
giue praise vnto thy name:
O let the people all abroad,
extoll and laud the same.
Then shall the earth increase,
great store of fr • it shall fall:
And then our God, the God of peace,
shall blesse vs eke vvithall.
God shall vs blesse I say,
aed then both farre and neare.
The folke throughout the vvorld alvvay
of him shall stand in feare.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
LEt God ari • e, and then his foes vvill turne themselues to flight:
〈♫〉
his enemies then vvill run abroad, and scatter out of sight. Aud as the
〈♫〉
fire doth melt the vvaxe, and vvinde blovv smoake avvay: So in the
〈♫〉
presence of the Lord, the vvicked shall decay.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
LEt God arise, and then his foes vvill turne themselues to flight:
〈♫〉
his enemies then vvill run abroad, and scatter out of sight. And as the
〈♫〉
fire doth melt the vvaxe, and vvinde blovv smoake avvay: So in the
〈♫〉
presence of the Lord, the vvicked shall decay.

div.head: TENOR, or Playnsong.
div.p:
☞ 〈♫〉
LEt God ari • e, and then his foes vvill turne themselues to flight:
☞ 〈♫〉
his enemies then vvill run abroad, and scatter out of sight, And as the
〈♫〉
fire doth melt the vvaxe, and vvinde blovv smoake avvay: So in the
〈♫〉
presence of the Lord, the vvicked shall decay.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
LEt God arise, and then his foes vvill turne themselues to flight:
〈♫〉
his enemies then vvill run abroad, and scatterout of sight. And as the
〈♫〉
fire doth melt the vvaxe, and vvinde blovv smoake avvay: So in the
〈♫〉
presence of the Lord, the vvicked shall decay.

lg.l: But righteous men before the Lord,
shall heartily re • oyce▪
They shall be glad and merry all,
and chearefull in their voyce.
Sing praise, sing praise vnto the Lord,
vvho rideth on the skie:
Extoll the name of Iah our God,
and him doe magnifie.
The same is he that is aboue
vvithin his holy place:
That father is of fatherlesse,
and iudge of vviddovves case.
Houses he giues, and issue both,
vnto the comfortlesse:
He bringeth bondmen out of thrall,
and rebels to distresse.
VVhen thou didst march before thy folke,
the Egyptians from among:
And broughtst thē through the vvildernes dovvn,
vvhich vvas both vvide & long.
The earth did quake, the raine pourde
heard vvere great claps of thunder:
The mount Sinai shooke in such sort,
as it vvould cleaue asunder.
Thine heritage vvith drops of raine,
abundantly 〈…〉
And if so be it barren vvaxt▪
by thee it vvas refresht.
Thy chosen flock doth there remaine,
thou hast preparde that place:
And for the poore thou dost prouide
of thine especiall grace.
God vvill giue vvomen causes iust
to magnifie his name:
VVhen as all people triumphs make,
and purchase brute and fame.
For puissant kings for all their povver
shall flye and take the foyle:
And vvomen vvhich remaine at home.
shall helpe to part the spoyle.
And though ye vvere as black as pots
your hevv shall passe the Doue:
VVhose vvings & feathers seeme to haue
• iluer and gold aboue.
VVhen in this land God shal triumph
ore Kings both hie and lovv:
Then shall it be like Salmon hill,
as vvhite as any snovv.
Though Basan be a fruitfull hill,
and is height others passe:
Yet Sion, Gods most holy hill,
doth • arre excell in grace▪
VVhy brag ye thus ye hils most hye,
and leape for pride together?
This hill of Sion God doth loue,
and there vvill dvvell for euer.
Gods army is tvvo millions
of vvarriours good and strong:
The Lord also in Sinai
is present them among.
Thou didst O Lord ascend on hye,
and captiue ledst them all:
VVhich in times past thy chosen flocke,
in prison kept and thrall.
Thou madest them tribute for to pay,
and such as did repine.
Thou didst subdue, that they might dvvel
in thy Temple diuine.
Novv praised be the Lord, for that
he poures on vs such grace:
From day to day he is the God
of our health and solace.
He is the God from vvhom alone
saluation commeth plaine:
He is the God by vvhom vve scape
all dangers, death, and paine.
Thus God vvill vvound his enemies head,
and breake the hairy scalpe
Of those that in their vvickednesse
continually doe vvalke.
From Basan I vvill bring, saith he,
my people and my sheepe:
And all mine ovvne as I haue done,
from danger of the deepe.
And make them • ip their feet in bloud
of those that hate my name,
And dogs shall haue their tongues imbrude
vvith licking of the same.
All men may see hovv thou O God,
thy enemies dost deface:
And hovv thou goest as God and King
into thy holy place.
The Singers goe before vvith ioy,
the Minstrels follovv after:
And in the midst the Damsels play,
vvith Timbrell and vvith Taber.
Novv in the congregation,
O Israel praise the Lord:
And Iacobs vvhole posteritie,
giue thanks vvith one accord.
Their chiefe vvas little Beniamin,
but Iuda made their hoast:
VVith Zabulon and Neptalim,
vvhich dvvell about their coast.
As God hath giuen povver to thee,
so Lord make firme and sure
The thing that thou hast vvrought in vs
for euer to endure.
And in thy temple gifts vvill vve
giue vnto thee (O Lord)
For thine vnto Ierusalem
sure promise made by vvord.
Yea, and strange Kings to vs subdude▪
shall doe like in those dayes:
I meane to thee they shall present
their gifts of laud and praise.
He shall destroy the spearemens ranks
their Calues and Buls of might:
And cause them tribute pay and daunt
all such as loue to fight.
Then shall the Lord of Egypt come,
and presents to him bring:
The Moores most black shal stretch their hands
vnto their Lord and king:
Therefore the kingdomes of the earth
giue praise vnto the Lord:
Sing Psalmes to God vvith one consent,
thereto let all accord.
VVho though he ride, and euer hath,
aboue the heauens bright:
Yet by his fearefull thunderclaps,
men may vvell knovv his might.
Therefore the strength of Israel
ascribe to God on hie:
VVhose might & povver doth far extend
aboue the cloudy skie.
O Lord thy holinesse and povver
is dread for euermore:
The God of Israel giues vs strength,
praised be God therefore.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
SAue me O God, and that vvith speed, the vvaters flovv full fast:
〈♫〉
So nie my soule doe they proceed, that I am sore agast. I sticke full
〈♫〉
deepe in filth and clay, vvhereas I feele no ground: I fall into such flouds
〈♫〉
I say, that I am like be drovvn'd▪

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
SAue me O God, and that vvith speed, the vvaters flovv full fast:
〈♫〉
So nie my soule doe they proceed, that I am sore agast. I sticke full
〈♫〉
deepe in filth and clay, vvhereas I feele no ground: I fall into such flouds
〈♫〉
I say, that I am like be drovvn'd▪

div.head: TENOR, or Playnsong.
div.p:
☞ 〈♫〉
SAue me O God, and that vvith speed, the vvaters flovv full fast:
〈♫〉
So nie my soule doe they proceed, that I am sore agast. I flicke full
〈♫〉
deepe in filth and clay, vvhereas I feele no ground: I fall into such flouds
〈♫〉
I say that I am like be drovvn'd.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
SAue me O God, and that vvith speed, the vvaters flovv full Fast:
〈♫〉
So nie my soule doe they proceed, that I am sore agast. I sticke full
〈♫〉
deepe in filth and clay, vvhereas I feele no ground: I fall into such flouds I say, that I am like be drovvn'd.

lg.l: VVith crying oft I faint and quaile,
my throat is hoarse and dry:
VVith looking vp my sight doth faile
for helpe of God on hie.
My foes that guiltlesse doe oppresse
my soule vvith hate are led;
In number sure they are no lesse
then hayres are on my head,
Though for no cause they vex me sore▪
they prosper, and are glad:
They doe compell me to restore
the things I neuer had.
VVhat I haue done for vvant of vvit,
thou Lord all times canst tell▪
And all the faults that I commit,
to thee are knovvne full vvell,
O God of hosts, defend and stay
all those that trust in thee:
Let no man doubt or shrinke avvay
for ought that chanceth me.
It is for thee, and for thy sake
that I doe beare this blame:
In spight of thee they vvould me make
to hide my face for shame.
My mothers sonnes, my bretheren all
forsake me on a rovv:
And as a stranger they me call,
my face they vvill not knovv
Vnto thy house such zeale I beare,
that it doth pine me much:
Their checks and taunts at thee to heare▪
my very heart doth grutch.
Though I doe fast my flesh to chast,
yea if I vveepe and mone:
Yet in my teeth this geare is cast,
they passe not thereupon.
If I for griefe and paint of heart,
in sackecloth vse to vvalke:
Then they anone vvill it peruert,
thereof they iest and talke.
Both hie and lovv, & all the throng
that sit vvithin the gate:
They haue me euer in their tongue,
of me they talke and prate.
The drunkards vvhich in vvine delight
it is their chiefe pastime
To seeke vvhich vvay to vvork me spight,
of me they sing and • ime.
But thee the vvhile O Lord I pray,
that vvhen it pleaseth thee:
For thy great truth thou • vilt alvvay
send dovvne thine aide to me.
Pluck thou my feet out of the mire,
from drovvning doe me keepe:
From such as ovve me vvrath and ire,
and from the vvaters deepe.
Lest vvith the vvaues I should be drovvnd,
and depth my soule deuoure
And that the pit should me confound,
and shut me in her povver.
O Lord of hosts to me giue eare,
as thou art good and kinde:
And as thy mercy is most deere,
Lord haue me in thy minde.
And doe not from thy seruant hide,
nor turne thy face avvay:
I am opprest on euery side,
vvith haste giue eare I say.
O Lord vnto my soule dravv nigh,
the same vvith ayde repose:
Because of their great tyranny,
acquite me from my foes.
That I abide rebuke and shame,
thou knovvest, and thou canst tell:
For those that seeke and vvork the same,
thou seest them all full vvell.
VVhen they vvith brags do breake my heart,
I seeke for helpe anone▪
But finde no friends to ease my smart,
to comfort me not one.
But in my meat they gaue me gall,
too cruell for to thinke▪
And gaue me in my thirst vvithall,
strong vinegar to drinke▪
Lord turne their table to a share,
to take themselues therein:
And vvhen they thinke full vvell to fare,
then trap them in the grin.
And let their eyes be darke and blind,
that they may nothing see?
Bovv dovvn their back, and do them bend
in thraldome for to be.
Poure out thy vvrath as hot as fire,
that it on them may fall:
Let thy displeasure in thine ire,
take hold vpon them all.
As desart dry their house disgrace,
their off-spring eke expell:
That none thereof possesse their place,
nor in their tents doe dvvell.
If thou dost strike the man to tame,
on him they lye full sore:
And if that thou doe vvound the same,
they seeke to hurt him more.
Then let them heap vp mischiefe still
sith they are all peruert:
That of thy fauour and goodvvill,
they neuer haue no part.
And dash them cleane out of the Booke
of life, of hope, of trust:
That for their names they neuer looke
in number of the iust.
Though I O Lord, vvith vvoe & griefe
haue beene full sore opprest:
Thy helpe shall giue me such reliefe,
that all shall be redrest.
That I may giue thy name the praise▪
and shevv it vvith a song:
I vvill extoll the same alvvayes,
vvith heartie thanks among.
VVhich is more pleasant vnto thee,
such minde thy grace hath borne,
Than either Oxe or Calfe can be,
that hath both hoofe and horne.
VVhen simple folke doe this behold,
it shall reioyce them sure:
All yee that seeke the Lord, behold,
your life for aye shall dure.
For vvhy? the Lord of hosts doth heare
the poore vvhen they complaine:
His prisoners are to him full deare,
he doth them not disdaine.
VVherefore the skie and earth belovv
the sea vvith floud and streame:
His praise they shall declare and shevv,
vvith all that liue in them.
For sure our God vvill Sion saue,
and Iudaes Citie build:
Much folke possession there shall haue,
her streets shall all be fild.
Her seruants seed shall keep the same
all ages out of minde:
And there all they that loue his name,
a dvvelling place shall finde,

div.head: CANTVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
O God to me take heed, of helpe I thee require: O Lord of
〈♫〉
hosts vvith haste make speed, helpe, helpe, I thee desire.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
O God to me teke heed, of help I thee require: O Lord of
〈♫〉
hosts vvith haste make speed, helpe, helpe, I thee desire.

div.head: TENOR, or Planysong.
div.p:
☞ 〈♫〉
O God to me take heed, of helpe I thee require: O Lord of
〈♫〉
hosts vvith haste make speed, helpe helpe I thee desire.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
O God to me take heed, of helpe I thee require: O Lord of
〈♫〉
hosts vvith haste make speed, helpe, helpe, I thee desire.

lg.l: VVith shame confound them all
that seeke my soule to spill:
Rebuke them backe vvith blame to fall,
that thinke and vvish me ill.
Confound them that apply
and seeke to vvorke me shame:
And at my harme doe laugh and cry,
so so, there goes the game.
But let them ioyfull be
in th •• vvi • h ioy and vvealth▪
VVhich onely trust and seeke to thee,
and to thy sauing health.
That they may say alvvayes,
in mirth and one accord,
All glory, honour, laud and praise,
be giuen to thee O Lord.
But I am vveake and poore,
come Lord, thine aid I lacke:
Thou art my stay and help, therefore
make speed and be not • lacke.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
MY Lord my God in all distresse, my hope is vvhole in thee:
〈♫〉
Then let no shame my soule oppresse, nor once take hold on mee.
〈♫〉
As thou art iust, defend me Lord, and rid me out of dread: Giue eare,
〈♫〉
and to my sute accord, and send me helpe at need.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
MY Lord my God in all distresse, my hope is vvhole in thee:
〈♫〉
Then let no shame my soule oppresse, nor once take hold on mee:
〈♫〉
As thou art iust defend me Lord, and rid me out of dread: Giue eare,
〈♫〉
and to my sute accord, and send me helpe at need.

div.head: TENOR or Playnsong.
div.p:
☞ 〈♫〉
MY Lord my God in all distresse, my hope is vvhole in thee:
〈♫〉
Then let no shame my soule oppresse, nor once take hold on mee
〈♫〉
As thou art iust, defend me Lord, and rid me out of dread: Giue eare,
〈♫〉
and to my sute accord, and send me helpe at need.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
MY Lord my God in all distresse, my hope is vvhole in thee:
〈♫〉
Then let no shame my soule oppresse, nor once take hold on mee.
〈♫〉
As thou art iust, defend me Lord, and rid me out of dread: Giue eare,
〈♫〉
and to my sute accord, and send me helpe at need.

lg.l: Be thou my rocke, to vvhom I may
for aid all times resort:
Thy promise is to helpe alvvay,
thou art my fence and fort.
Saue me my God from vvicked men,
and from their strength and povver:
From folke vniust, and eke from them
that cruelly deuoure.
Thou art my stay vvherein I trust,
thou Lord of hosts are he:
Yea, from my youth I had a lust,
still to depend o • thee.
Thou hast me kept euen from my birth
and I through thee vvas borne:
VVherfore I vvill thee praise vvith mirth
both euening and at morne.
As to a monster seldome s • ene,
much folke about me throng:
But thou art novv and still hast beene
my fence and aid most strong.
VVherfore my mouth no time shal lack
thy glory and thy praise:
And eke my tongue shall not be slacke
to honour thee alvvayes
Refuse me not O Lord I say,
vvhen age my limbs doth take:
And vvhen my strength doth vvaste avvay,
doe not my soule forsake.
Among themselues my foes inquire
to take me through deceit:
And they against me doe conspire,
that for my soule laid vvait.
Lay hand, and take him novv, they said,
for God from him is gone:
Dispatch him quite, for to his aid▪
ivvis there commeth none.
Doe not absent thy selfe avvay,
(O Lord) vvhen need shall be:
But that in time of griefe thou maist
vvith haste giue helpe to me.
VVith shame confound & ouerthrovv
all those that seeke my life:
Oppresse them vvith rebuke also▪
that faine vvould vvorke me strife,
But I vvill patiently abide
thy helpe at all assayes:
Still more and more each time and tide,
I vvill set forth thy praise.
My mouth thy iustice shall record,
thy daily helpe doth send:
But of thy benefits▪ O Lord,
I knovv no count nor end.
Yet vvill goe and seeke forth one,
vvith thy good helpe O God,
The sauing health of thee alone
to shevv and set abroad.
For of my youth thou tookst the • are,
and dost instruct me still:
Therefore thy vvonders to declare,
I haue great minde and vvill.
And as in youth from vvanton rage,
thou didst me keepe and stay:
Forsake me not vnto mine age,
and till my head be gray,
That I thy strength & might may shevv
to them that novv be here:
And that our seed thy povver may knovv
hereafter many a yeere.
O Lord thy iustice doth exceed,
thy doings all shall see:
Thy vvorkes are vvonderfull indeed,
oh, vvho is like to thee?
Thou mad'st me feele affliction sore,
and yet thou didst me saue:
Yea, thou didst make all • trife to cease,
and tookst me from the graue.
And thou mine honour dost increase,
my dignity maintaine:
Yea thou dost make all strife to ce • se,
and comfortst me againe.
Therefore thy faithfulnesse to praise,
I vvill vvith Viol sing:
My Harp shall sound thy laud alvvaies,
O Israels holy King.
My mouth vvill ioy vvith pleasant voyce,
vvhen I shall sing to thee:
And eke my soule vvill much reioyce,
for thou hast made me free.
My tongue thy vprightnes shal sound,
and speake it daily still:
For griefe & shame doe them confound,
that sought to vvorke me ill.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
LOrd giue thy iudgements to the King, therein instruct him vvell:

〈♫〉
And vvith his sonne that Princely thing, Lord let thy iustice dvvell.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
LOrd giue thy iudgements to the King, therein instruct him vvell:

〈♫〉
And vvith his Sonne that Princely thing, Lord let thy iustice dvvell.

div.head: TENOR, or Playnsong▪
div.l:
☞ 〈♫〉
LOrd giue thy iudgements to the King, therein instruct him vvell:

〈♫〉
And vvith his sonne that Princely thing, Lord let thy iustice dvvell.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
LOrd giue thy iudgements to the King, therein instruct him vvell:

〈♫〉
And vvith his Sonne that Princely thing, Lord let thy iustice dvvell.

lg.l: That he may gouerne vprightly,
and rule thy folke aright:
And so defend through equitie,
the poore that haue no might.
And let the mountaines that are hie▪
vnto their folke giue peace:
And eke let little hils apply,
in iustice to increase.
That he may helpe and ease the poore
vvith aide, and make them strong:
And eke destroy for euermore,
• all those that doe them vvrong.
And then from age to age shall they
regard and feare thy might:
So long as Sunne doth shine by day,
or else the Moone by night.
Lord make the King vnto the iust,
like raine to fields nevv movvne:
And like to drops that lay the dust,
and fresh the land nevv sovvne.
The iust shall flourish in his time,
and all shall be at peace:
Vntill the Moone shall cease to prime,
vvaste, change, and to increase.
He shall be Lord of sea and land,
from shore to shore throughout:
And from the flouds vvithin the land,
through all the earth about.
The people that in desarts dvvell,
shall kneele to him full thicke:
And all his enemies that rebell,
the earth and dust shall lick.
The Lords of all the Iles thereby,
great gifts to him shall bring:
The King of Saby and Araby,
giue many a costly thing.
All Kings shall seek vvith one accord,
in his good grace to stand:
And all the people of the vvorld,
shall serue him at his hand.
For he the needy sort doth saue,
that vnto him doe call:
And eke the simple folke that haue
no help of man at all.
He taketh pittie on the poore,
that are vvith need opprest:
He doth preserue them euermore,
and bring their soules to rest.
He shall redeem their life from dread,
from fraud, from vvrong, from might:
And eke the bloud that they shall bleed,
is precious in his sight.
But he shall liue, and they shall bring
to him of Sabaes gold:
He shall be honoured as a King,
and daily be extold.
The mighty mountaines of his land,
of corne shall beare such throng:
That it like Cedar trees shall stand
in Libanus full strong.
Their cities eke full vvel shall speed
the fruits thereof shall passe:
In plenty it shall farre exceed,
and spring as greene as grasse.
For euer they shall praise his name,
vvhile that the Sunne is light:
And think them happy through the same,
all folke shall blesse his might.
Praise ye the Lord of hosts and sing
to Israels God each one:
For he doth euery vvondrous thing,
yea, he himselfe alone.
And blessed be his holy name
all times eternally:
That all the earth may praise the same,
Amen, Amen, say I.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
HOvv euer it be, yet God is good, and kinde to Isra- el:
〈♫〉
And to all such as safely keepe their conscience pure and vvell.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
HOvv euer it be, yet God is good, and kinde to Isra- el:
〈♫〉
And to all such as safely keepe their conscience pure and vvell.

div.head: TENOR, or Playnsong.
div.p:
☞ 〈♫〉
HOvv euer it be, yet God is good, and kinde to Isra- el:
☞ 〈♫〉
And to all such as safely keepe their conscience pure and vvell.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
HOvv euer it be, yet God is good, and kinde to Isra- el:
〈♫〉
And to all such as safely keepe their conscience pure and vvell.

lg.l: Yet like a foole I almost slipt,
my feet began to slide:
And eke I vvist euen at a pinch
my steps began to glide.
For vvhen I savv such foolish men,
I grudg'd and did disdaine:
That vvicked men all things should haue
vvitho • t turmoyle or paine.
They neuer suffer plagues nor griefe,
as if death should them smite:
Their bodies are both stout and strong,
and euer in good plight▪
And free from all aduersitie,
vvhen other men be shent:
And vvith the rest they take no part
of plague or punishment.
Therefore presumption doth imbrace
their necks as doth a chaine:
And are euen vvrapt as in a robe,
vvith rapine and disdaine.
They are so fed, that euen for fat,
their eyes oft times out start:
And as for vvorldly goods, they haue
more then can vvish their heart.
Their life is most licentious,
boasting much of the vvrong
VVhich they haue done to simple men,
and euer pride among.
The heauens and the liuing Lord,
they spare not to blaspheme:
And prate they doe of vvorldly things,
no vvight they doe esteeme.
The people of God oft times turne back
to see their prosperous state:
And almost drinke the selfe same cup,
and follovv the same rate.
Hovv can it be that God, say they▪
should knovv and vnderstand
These vvorldly things, since vvicked men
be Lords of Sea and Land▪
For vve may see hovv vvicked men
in riches still increase:
Revvarded vvell vvith vvorldly goods,
and liue in rest and peace.
Then vvhy doe I from vvickednesse,
my fantasie refraine?
And vvash my hands vvith innocents,
and cleanse my heart in vaine?
And suffer scourges euery day,
as subiect to all blame.
And euery morning from my youth,
sustaine rebuke and shame?
And I had almost said as they
misliking mine estate:
But that I should thy children iudge,
as folke vnfortunate.
Then I bethought me hovv I might
this matter vnderstand:
But yet the matter vvas too great
for me to take in hand.
Vntill the time I vvent vnto
thy holy place, and then
I vnderstood right perfectly
the end of all these men.
And namely, hovv thou settest them
vpon a slippery place:
And at thy pleasure and thy vvill,
thou dost them all deface.
Then shall men muse at this strange sight,
to see hovv sodainly
They are destroid dispatcht, consumde,
and dead so horribly.
Much like a dream vvhen one avvakes
so shall their vvealth decay:
Their famous names in all mens sight
shall ebbe and passe avvay.
Yet thus my heart vvas grieued then,
my minde vvas much opprest:
So fond vvas I and ignorant,
and in this point a beast.
Yet neuerthelesse by my right hand
thou hold'st me alvvayes fast:
And vvith thy counsell dost me guide
to glory at the last.
VVhat thing is there that I can vvish
but thee in heauen aboue?
And in the earth there is nothing
like thee that I can loue.
My flesh and eke my heart doth faile,
but God doth faile me neuer:
For of my heart God is the strength,
my portion eke for euer.
And loe all such as thee forsake,
thou shalt destroy each one:
And those that trust in any thing
sauing in thee alone.
Therefore I vvill dravv neere to God,
and euer vvith him dvvell:
In God alone I put my trust,
thy vvonders vvill I tell.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
WHy art thou Lord so long from vs in all this danger deepe:

〈♫〉
VVhy doth thine anger kindle thus at thine ovvne pasture sheepe?

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
WHy art thou Lord so long from vs in all this danger deepe:

〈♫〉
VVhy doth thine anger kindle thus at thine ovvne pasture sheepe?

div.head: TENOR, or Playnsong.
div.l:
☞ 〈♫〉
WHy art thou Lord so long from vs in all this danger deepe:

〈♫〉
VVhy doth thine anger kindle thus at thine ovvne pasture sheepe?

div.head: BASSVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
WHy art thou Lord so long from vs in all this danger deepe:

〈♫〉
VVhy doth thine anger kindle thus at thine ovvne pasture sheepe?

lg.l: Lord call the people to thy thought,
