vvhich haue beene thine so long:
The vvhich thou hast redeemd & brought
from bondage sore and strong.
Haue minde I say, and thinke vpon,
remember it full vvell:
Thy pleasant place, thy mount Sion,
vvhere thou vvast vvont to dvvell.
Lift vp thy foote and come in haste,
and all thy foes deface:
VVhich novv at pleasure rob and vvaste,
vvithin thy holy place.
Amid the congregations all
thine enemies roare O God:
They set as signes on euery vvall,
their banners splaid abroad.
As men vvith axes hevv the trees,
that on the hils doe grovv:
so shine the bils and svvords of these
vvithin thy Temple novv.
The seeling savvde, the carued bords,
the goodly grauen stones,
VVith axes, hammers, bils and svvords,
they beate them dovvne at once.
Thy places they consume vvith flame,
and eke in all this toile,
The house appointed for thy name,
they raze dovvne to the soyle.
And thus they say vvithin their heart,
dispatch them out of hand:
Then burne they vp in euery place,
Gods houses through the land.
Yea, thou no signe of help dost send.
our Prophets all are gone:
To tell vvhen this our plague shall end,
among vs there is none.
VVhen vvilt thou Lord once end this shame
and cease thine enemies strong
Shall they alvvay blaspheme thy name,
and raile on thee so long?
VVhy dost vvith-dravv thy hand aback,
and hide it in thy lap?
O plucke it out and be not slacke
to giue thy foes a rap.
O God that art my King and Lord,
and euermore hast beene:
Yea, thy good grace throughout the vvorld
for our good help hath seene.
The seas that are so deepe and dead,
thy might did make them dry:
And thou didst breake the Serpents head,
and he therein did dye.
Yea, thou didst breake the heads so great,
of VVhales that are so fell:
And gau • st them to the folke to eate,
that in the desart dvvell.
• hou mad'st a spring of streames to rise
from rocks both hard and hye:
And eke thy hand hath made likevvise
deepe riuers to be dry.
Both day and eke the night are thine,
by thee they vvere begun:
Thou setst to serue vs vvith their shine,
the light and eke the Sunne.
Thou dost appoint the ends & coasts
of all the vvorld about:
Both Summer heats, and VVinters frosts,
thy hand hath found them out.
Thinke on O Lord, no time forget
thy foes that thee defame:
And hovv the foolish folke are set
to raile vpon thy name.
O let no cruell beasts deuoure
thy Turtle that is true:
Forget not alvvaies in thy povver,
the poore that much doe rue.
Regard thy couenant, and behold
thy foes possesse the land:
All sad and d • rke, forvvorne and old,
our realme as novv doth stand.
Let not the simple goe avvay
vvith disappointed shame:
But let the poore and needy aye
giue praise vnto thy name.
Rise Lord, let be by thee maintainde
the cause that is thine ovvne:
Remember hovv that thou blasphemde
art by the foolish one.
The voyce forget not of thy foes,
for the presuming hye
Is more and more increast of those
that hate thee spitefully.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
VN- to thee God vvill vve giue thanks, vve vvill giue thanks to thee:

〈♫〉
Sith thy name is so neare, declare thy vvondrous vvorkes vvill vve.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
VN- to thee God vvill vve giue thanks, vve vvill giue thanks to thee:

〈♫〉
Sith thy name is so neare, de- clare thy vvondrous vvorkes vvill vve▪

div.head: TENOR, or Playnsong.
div.l:
☞ 〈♫〉
VN- to thee God vvill vve giue thanks, vve vvill giue thanks to thee:

〈♫〉
Sith thy name is so neare, declare thy vvondrous vvorkes vvill vve.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
VN- to thee God vvill vve giue thanks, vve vvill giue thanks to thee:

〈♫〉
Sith thy name is so neare, declare thy vvondrous vvorks vvill vve.

lg.l: I vvill vprightly iudge vvhen get
conuenient time I may:
The earth is vveake, and all therein,
but I her pillers stay.
I did to the mad people say,
deale not so furiously:
And 〈◊〉 to the vngodly one • ,
set not your hornes on hye.
I said vnto them, set not vp
your raised hornes on hie:
And see that you doe vvith stiffe necke
not speake presumptuously.
For neither from the Easterne part▪
nor from the VVesterne side.
Nor from forsaken vvildernesse,
protection doth proceed:
For vvhy • the Lord our God he is
the righteous Iudge alone:
He putteth dovvne the one, and sets
another in the throne.
For vvhy? a cup of mighty vvine
is in the hand of God:
And all the mighty vvine therein▪
himselfe doth poure abroad.
As for the lees and filthy dregs
that doe remaine of it:
The vvicked of the earth shall drinke
and sucke them euery vvhit▪
But I vvill talke of God I say
of Iacobs God therefore:
And vvill not cease to celebrate
his praise for euermore.
In sunder breake the horne of all
vngodly men vvill I:
But then the hornes of righteous men
shall be exalted hye.

lg.head: Gloria Patri.
lg.l: To Father, Sonne and holy Ghost,
all glory be therefore:
As in beginning vvas, is novv,
and shall be euermore.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
TO all that novv in Iury dvvell, the Lord is clearely knovvn:

〈♫〉
His Name is great in Israel, a peo- ple of his ovvne.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
TO all that novv in Iury dvvell, the Lord is clearely knovvne:

〈♫〉
His name is great in Isra- el,
a people of his ovvne.

div.head: TENOR, or Playnsong.
div.l:
☞ 〈♫〉
TO all th • t novv in Iury dvvell, the Lord is clearely knovvne:

〈♫〉
His Name is great in Israel, a people of his ov • ne.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
TO all that novv in Iury dvvell, the Lord is clearely knovvn:

〈♫〉
His name is great in Isra- el, a people of his ovvne.

lg.l: At Salem he his tents hath pight,
to tarry there a space:
In Sion eke he doth delight
to make his dvvelling place.
And there he brake both shaft & bovv,
the svvord, the speare, the shield:
And brake the ray to ouerthrovv,
in battaile on the field.
Thou art more vvorthy honour (Lord)
more might in thee doth lye:
Then in the strongest in the vvorld▪
that rob on mountaines hie.
But novv the proud are spoyld through thee,
and they are fallne on sleepe:
Through men of vvar no helpe can be,
themselues they could not keepe.
At thy rebuke O Iacobs God.
vvhen thou didst them reproue:
As halfe asleepe their chariots stood,
no horsemen once did moue.
For thou art fearefull, Lord, indeed,
vvhat man the courage hath
To bide thy sight, and doth not dread,
vvhen thou art in thy vvrath?
VVhen thou dost make thy iudgements heard
from heauen through the ground:
Then all the earth full sore afraid,
in silence shall be found.
And that vvhen thou O God dost stand
in iudgement for to speake:
To saue the afflicted of the Land.
on earth that are full vveake.
The fury that in them doth raigne,
shall turne vnto thy praise:
Hereafter Lord doe thou restraine
their vvrath and threats alvvayes:
Make vovves & pay them to your God
ye folke that nigh him be:
Bring gifts all ye that dvvell abroad,
for dreadfull sure is he.
For he doth take both life & might
from Princes great of birth:
And full of terrour is his sight
to all the Kings on earth.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
I VVith my voyce to God did cry, vvith heart and hearty cheare: 〈♫〉
My voyce to God I lift on high, and he my sute doth heare, In time of
〈♫〉
griefe I sought to God, by night no rest I tooke: but stretcht my hands
〈♫〉
to him abroad, my soule comfort forsooke.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
I VVith my voyce to God doe cry, vvith heart and hearty cheare: 〈♫〉
My voyce to God I lift on high, and he my sute doth heare. In time of
〈♫〉
griefe I sought to God, by night no rest I tooke: but stretcht my hands
〈♫〉
to him abroad, my soule comfort forsooke.

div.head: TENOR, or Playnsong.
div.p:
☞ 〈♫〉
I VVith my voyce to God doe cry, vvith heart and hearty cheare: 〈♫〉
My voyce to God I lift on high and he my sute doth heare. In time of
☞ 〈♫〉
griefe I sought to God, by night no rest I tooke: but stretcht my hands
〈♫〉
to him abroad, my soule comfort forsooke.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
I VVith my voyce to God doe cry, vvith heart and hearty cheare: 〈♫〉
My voyce to God I lift on high, and he my sute doth heare. In time of
〈♫〉
griefe I sought to God, by night no rest I tooke: but stretcht my hands
〈♫〉
to him abroad, my soule comfort forsooke.

lg.l: VVhen I to thinke on God intend,
my trouble then is more
I spake, but could not make an end,
my breath vvas stopt so sore.
Thou holdst mine eyes alvvayes from rest
that I alvvayes avvake▪
VVith feare I am so sore opprest,
my speech doth me forsake.
The dayes of old in minde I cast,
and oft did thinke vpon
The times and ages that are past
full many yeares agone.
By night my songs I call to minde,
once made thy praise to shevv:
And vvith my heart much talke I finde,
my spirits doe search to knovv.
VVill God (said I) at once for all,
cast off his people thus?
So that henceforth no time he shall
be friendly vnto vs?
VVhat, is his goodnesse cleane decai •
for euer and a day?
Or is his promise novv delaid,
or doth his truth decay▪
And vvill the Lord our God forget
his mercies manifold?
Or shall his vvrath increase so hot,
his mercie to vvith-hold?
At last I said my vveaknesse is
the cause of my distrust:
Gods mighty hand can helpe all this,
and cha • ge it vvhen he list.
I vvill regard and thinke vpon
the vvorki • g of the Lord:
Of all his vvonders past and gone,
I gladly vvill record.
Yea, all his vvorks I vvill declare,
and vvhat he did deuise:
To tell his facts I vvill not spare,
and eke his counsell vvise.
Thy vvorks O Lord are all vpright,
and holy all abroad
VVhat one hath strength to match the might
of thee O Lord our God?
Thou art a God that oft dost shevv
thy vvonders euery houre:
And so dost make thy people knovv
thy vertue and thy povver.
And thine ovvn folke thou dost defend
vvith strength and stretched arme:
The sonnes of Iacob that descend,
and Iosephs seed from harme:
The vvaters Lord perceiued thee,
the vvaters savv thee vvell:
And they for feare aside did flee,
the depths on trembling fell.
The clouds that vvere both thick and black,
did raine full plenteously:
The thunder in the aire did crack,
thy shafts abroad did flye.
Thy thunder in the earth vvas heard,
thy lightning from aboue,
VVith flashes great made men afraid,
the earth did quake and moue.
Thy vvayes vvithin the sea doth lye,
thy pathes in vvaters deepe:
Yet none can there thy steps espye,
nor knovv thy pathes to keepe.
Thou leadst thy folke vpon the land,
as sheepe on euery side:
Through Moses & through Aarons hand,
thou didst them safely guide.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
ATtend my people to my Lavv, and to my vvords incline: My
〈♫〉
mouth shall speake strange parables, and sentences diuine, vvhich vvee
〈♫〉
our selues haue heard and learn'd, euen of our fathers old, and vvhich
〈♫〉
for our instruction, our fathers haue vs told.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
ATtend my people to my Lavv, and to my vvords incline: My
〈♫〉
mouth shall speake strange parables, and sentences diuine, vvhich vve
〈♫〉
our selues haue heard and learn'd, euen of our fathers old, and vvhich
〈♫〉
for our instruction, our fathers haue vs told.

div.head: TENOR, or Playnsong.
div.p:
☞ 〈♫〉
ATtend my people to my Lavv, and to my vvords incline▪ My
☞ 〈♫〉
mouth shall speake strange parables, and sentences diuine, vvhich vvee
〈♫〉
our selues haue heard and learn'd, euen of our fathers old, and vvhich
〈♫〉
for our instruction, our fathers haue vs told.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
ATtend my people to my Lavv, and to my vvords incline: My
〈♫〉
mouth shall speake strange parables, and sentences diuine, vvhich vvee
〈♫〉
our selues haue heard and learn'd, euen of our fathers old, and vv • ich
〈♫〉
for our instruction, our fathers haue vs told.

lg.l: Because vve should not keepe it close
from them that should come after:
VVho should Gods povver to their race praise,
and all his vvorks of vvonder.
To Iacob he commandement gaue,
hovv Israel should liue:
VVilling our fathers should the same
vnto their children giue.
That they and their posteritie,
that vvere not sprung vp tho,
Should haue the knovvledge of the lavv,
and teach their seed also
That they may haue the better hope
in God that is aboue:
And not forget to keepe his lavves,
and his precepts in loue.
Not being as their fathers vvere,
rebelling in Gods sight:
And vvould not frame their vvicked hearts
to knovv their God aright.
Hovv vvent the people of Ephraim,
their neighbours for to spoyle:
Shooting their darts the day of vvar,
and yet they tooke the foyle?
For vvhy? they did not keepe vvith God
the couenant that vvas made:
Nor yet vvould vvalk or lead their liues
according to his trade.
But put into obliuion,
his counsell and his vvill:
And all his vvorkes most magnifique,
vvhich he declared still.
VVhat vvonders to our forefathers
did he himselfe disclose:
In Egypt land vvithin the field
that call'd is • haneos?
He did diuide and cut the sea,
that they might passe at once.
And made the vvaters stand as still
as doth an heape of stones.
He led them secret in a cloud
by day vvhen it vvas bright▪
And in the night vvhen darke it vvas,
vvith fire he gaue them light.
He brake the rocks in vvildernesse,
and gaue the people drinke:
As plentifull, as vvhen the deeps
doe flovv vp to the brinck.
He drevv out riuers out of rocks,
that vvere both dry and hard:
Of such abundance▪ that no flouds
to them might be compar'd.
Yet for all this against the Lord
their sinne they did increase:
And stirred him that is most high,
to vvrath in vvildernesse.
They tempted him vvithin their harts,
like people of mistrust:
Requiring such a kinde of meat
as serued to their lust.
Saying vvith murmuration,
in their vnfaithfulnesse:
VVhat? can this God prepare for vs
a feast in vvildernesse?
Behold, he strake the stony rock,
and flouds forthvvith did flovv:
But can he novv giue to his folke
both bread and flesh also▪
VVhen God heard this, he vvaxed vvroth
vvith Iacob and his seed:
So did his indignation
on Israel proceed.
Because they did not faithfully
beleeue, and hope that he
Could alvvaies help and succour them
in their necessitie.
VVherfore he did command the clouds
forthvvith they brake in sunder.
And raind dovvn Manna for them to eate▪
a food of mickle vvonder.
VVhen earthly men vvith Angels food
vvere fed at their request:
He bad the East vvinds blovv avvay,
and brought in the Southvvest.
And raind dovvne flesh as thicke as dust,
and Fovvle as thicke as sand:
VVhich he did cast amid the place
vvhere all their tents did stand.
Then did they eate exceedingly,
and all men had the •• fils:
Yet more and more they did desire
to serue their lusts and vvils.
But as the meat vvas in their mouths,
his vvrath vpon them fell,
And slevv the flovver of all their youth
and choise of Israel.
Yet fell they to their vvonted sinne,
and still they did him grieue:
For all the vvonders that be vvrought,
they vvould not him belieue.
Their dayes therefore he shortened,
and made their honour vaine:
Their yeeres did vvaste and passe avvay
vvith terror and vvith paine.
But euer vvhen he plagued them,
they sought him by and by:
Remembring that he vvas their strength,
their help, and God most hie.
Though in their mouthes they did but glose
and flatter vvith the Lord:
And vvith their tongues, & in their harts
dissembled euery vvord.
For vvhy? their hearts vvere nothing bent
to him, not to his trade:
Nor yet to keepe, or to performe
the couenant that vvas made.
Yet vvas he still so mercifull,
vvhen they deseru'd to dye:
That he forgaue them their misdeeds,
and vvould not them destroy▪
Yea many a time he turnd his vvrath,
and did himselfe aduise:
And vvould not suffer all his vvhole
displeasure to arise.
Considering that they vvere but flesh,
and euen as a vvinde
That passeth avvay, and cannot vvell
returne by his ovvne kinde.
Hovv often times in vvildernesse,
did they the Lord prouoke?
Hovv did they stir and moue the Lord
to plague them vvith his stroke?
Yet did they turne againe to sinne,
and tempted God eftsoone,
Prescribing to the holy Lord
vvhat things they vvould haue done.
Not thinking of his hand and povver,
no • of the day vvhen he
Deliuered them out of the hands
of the fierce enemy.
Nor • ovv he vvrought his miracles,
as they themselues beh • ld
In Egypt, and the vvonders that
he did in Zoan field.
Nor hovv he turned by his povver,
their vvaters into bloud:
That no man might receiue his drinke
at riuer or at floud.
Nor hovv he sent them svvarmes of Flyes
vvhich did them fore annoy:
And fild their country full of Frogs,
vvhich did their land destroy.
Nor hovv he did commit their fruits
vnto the Caterpiller:
And all the labour of their hands
he gaue to the Grashopper.
VVith hailstones he destroid their vines
so that they vvere all lost:
And not so much as vvilde Fig-trees▪
but he consum'd vvith frost.
And yet vvith hailstones once againe
the Lord their cattell smo • e:
And all their flocks & heards likevvise,
vvith thunderbolts full hot.
He cast vpon them in his ire,
and in his fury strong
Displeasure, vvrath a • d euill spirits
to trouble them among.
Then to his vvrath he made a vvay,
and spared not the least:
But gaue vnto the pestilence,
the man and eke the beast.
He strake also the first borne all
that vp in Egypt came:
And all the chiefe of men and beasts
vvithin the tents of Ham.
But as for all his ovvne deare folke,
he did preserue and keepe,
And carried them through vvildernesse▪
euen like a flocke of sheepe.
VVithout all feare both safe & sound
he brought them out of thrall:
VVhereas theis foes vvith rage of sea
vvere ouervvhelmed all.
And brought them out into the coasts
of his ovvne holy land:
Euen to the mount vvhich he had got
by his strong arme and hand.
And there cast out the heathen folke,
and did their land diuide:
And in their tents he set the tribes
of Israel to abide.
Yet for all this, their God most hye
they stird and tempted still:
And vvould not keepe his testament,
nor yet obey his vvill.
But as their fathers turned backe,
euen so they vvent astray:
Much like a bovv that vvould not bend,
but slip and start avvay.
And grieu'd him vvith their hil altars,
vvith offerings and vvith fire,
And vvith their Idols vehemently
prouoked him to ire.
Therevvith his vvrath began againe
to kindle in his breast:
The naughtinesse of Israel
he did so much detest.
Then he forsooke th • Tabernacle
of Silo, vvhere he vvas
Right conuersant vvith earthly men,
euen as his dvvelling place.
Then suffered he his might & povver
in bondage for to stand:
And gaue the honor of his Arke
into his enemies hand.
And did commit them to the svvord,
vvroth vvith his heritage:
The young men vvere deuourde vvith fire
Maides had no marriage.
And vvith the svvord the Priests also
did perish eueryone▪
And not a vviddovv left aliue
their death for to bemone.
And then the Lord began to vvake
like one that slept a time:
And as a valiant man of vvar,
refreshed after vvine,
VVith Emrods in their hinder parts,
he strake his enemies all:
And put them then vnto a shame
that vvas perpetuall.
Then he the tent and tabernacle
of Ioseph did refuse:
As for the tribe of Ephraim,
he vvould in no vvise chuse.
But chose the tribe of Iehuda,
vvhereas he meant to dvvell:
Euen the noble Mount Sion,
vvhich he did loue so vvell.
VVhereas he did his Temple build,
both sumptuously and sure:
Like as the earth vvhich he hath made
for euer to endure.
Then chose he Dauid him to serue,
his people for to keepe:
VVhich he tooke vp and brought avvay,
euen from the folds of sheepe.
As he did follovv the Evves vvith yong▪
the Lord did him aduance:
To feed his people Israel,
and his inheritance.
Thus Dauid vvith a faithfull heart,
his flocke and charge did feed:
And prudently vvith all his povver
did gouerne them indeed.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
O Lord the Gentiles doe inuade thine heritage to spoyle:
〈♫〉
Ierusalem an heape is made, thy temple they defile.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
O Lord the Gentiles doe inuade thine heritage of spoyle:
〈♫〉
Ierusalem an heape is made, thy temple they defile.

div.head: TENOR▪ or Playnsong.
div.p:
☞ 〈♫〉
O Lord the Gentiles doe inuade thine heritage to spoyle▪
☞ 〈♫〉
Ierusalem an heape is made, thy temple they defile.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
O Lord the Gentiles doe inuade thine heritage of spoyle:
〈♫〉
Ierusalem an heape is made, thy temple they defile.

lg.l: The bodies of thy Saints so deare,
abroad to birds they cast:
The flesh of them that doe thee feare,
the beasts deuoure and vvaste.
Their bloud throughout Ierusalem,
as vvater spilt they haue:
So that there is not one of them
to lay their dead in graue.
Thus are vve made a laughing stock
almost the vvorld throughout:
The enemies at vs iest and mocke,
vvhich dwell our coasts about.
VVilt thou O Lord thus in thine ire
against vs euer fume?
And shevv thy vvrath as hot as fire,
thy folke for to consume?
Vpon those people poure the same
vvhich did thee neuer knovv:
All realmes vvhich call not on thy name,
consume and ouerthrovv.
For they haue got the vpper hand,
and Iacobs seed destroyd:
His habitation and his land,
they haue left vvaste and void.
Beare not in minde our former faults,
vvith speed some pitty shevv:
And aid vs Lord in all assaults,
for vve are vveake and lovv.
O God that giuest all health and grace,
on vs declare the same:
VVeigh not out vvorks, our sinnes deface,
for honour of thy name.
VVhy shall the vvicked still alvvay
to vs as people dumbe:
In thy reproach reioyce and • ay,
vvhereis their God become?
Require O Lord as thou seest good,
before our eyes and sight,
Of all those folke thy seruants bloud,
vvhich they spilt in despight.
Receiue into thy sight in haste,
the clamor, griefe, and vvrong
Of such as are in prison cast,
sustaining irons strong.
Thy force and strength to celebrate,
Lord set them out of band:
VVhich vnto death are destinate,
and in their enemies hand.
The nations vvhich haue been so bold
as to blaspheme thy name:
Into their laps vvith seauen fold,
repay againe the same.
So vve thy folke and pasture sheepe,
vvill praise thee euermore:
And teach all ages for to keepe
for thee like praise in store.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
THou Heard that Israel dost keepe, giue eare and take good heed:
〈♫〉
vvhich leadest Ioseph like a sheepe, and dost him vvatch and feed.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
THou Heard that Israel dost keepe, giue eare and take good heed
〈♫〉
vvhich leadest Ioseph like a sheepe, and dost him vvatch and feede.

div.head: TENOR, or Playnsong.
div.p:
☞ 〈♫〉
THou Heard that Israel dost keepe, giue eare and take good heed,
〈♫〉
vvhich leadest Ioseph like a sheepe, and dost him vvatch and feed.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
THou Heard that Israel dost keepe, giue eare and take good heed▪
〈♫〉
vvhich leadest Ioseph like a sheepe, and dost him vvatch and feed.

lg.l: Thou Lord I say vvhose seat is set
on Cherubins most bright,
Shevv forth thy selfe, and doe not let
send dovvne thy beames of light,
Before Ephraim and Beniamin,
Manasses eke likevvise,
To shevv thy povver doe thou begin,
come help vs Lord, arise.
Direct our hearts vnto thy grace,
conuert vs Lord to thee:
Shevv vs the brightnesse of thy face,
and then full safe are vve.
Lord God of hosts of Israel,
hovv long vvilt thou (I say)
Against thy folke in anger svvell,
and vvilt not heare them pray.
Thou dost them feed vvith sorrovves deepe▪
their bread vvith teares they eate:
And drinke the teares that they do vvee •
in measure full and great.
Thou hast vs made a very strife
to those that dvvell about:
And that our foes doe loue of life,
they laugh and iest it out.
O take vs Lord vnto thy grace,
conuert our mindes to thee:
Shevv forth to vs thy ioyfull face,
and vve full safe shall be.
From Egypt vvhere it grevv not vvell,
thou broughtst a Vine full deere:
The heathen folke thou didst expell,
and thou didst plant it there.
Thou didst prepare for it a place,
and set her rootes full fast,
That it did grovv and spring apace,
and fild the land at last.
The hils vvere couered round about
vvith shade that from it came:
And eke the Cedars hie and stout,
vvith branches of the same.
VVhy then didst thou her vvall destroy?
her hedge pluckt vp thou hast,
That all the folke that passe thereby,
thy Vine may spoile and vvast.
The Bore out of the vvood so vvilde,
doth dig and roote it out:
The furious beasts out of the fields,
deuoure it all about.
O Lord of hosts returne againe,
from heauen looke betime
Behold, and vvith thy help sustaine
this poore vineyard of thine.
Thy plant I say, thine Israel,
vvhom thy right hand hath set:
The same vvhich thou didst loue so vvell
O Lord doe not forget.
They lop and cut it dovvne apace,
they burne it eke vvith fire:
And through the frovvning of thy face,
vve perish in thine ire.
Let thy right hand be vvith them novv
vvhom thou hast kept so long:
And vvith the sonne of man, vvhom thou
to thee hast made so strong.
And so vvhen thou hast set vs free,
and saued vs from shame,
Then vvill vve neuer fall from thee,
but call vpon thy name.
O Lord of hosts of thy good grace,
conuert vs vnto thee:
Behold vs vvith a pleasant face,
and then full safe are vve.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
BE light and glad in God reioyce, vvhich is our strength and stay:
〈♫〉
Be ioyfull and lift vp your voyce to Iacobs God I say. Prepare your
〈♫〉
instruments most meet, some ioyfull Psalme to sing: Strike vp vvith
〈♫〉
Harp and Lute so svveet, on euery pleasant string.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
BE light and glad, in God reioyce, vvhich is our strength and stay:
〈♫〉
Be ioyfull and lift vp your voyce to Iacobs God I say. Prepare your
〈♫〉
instruments most meet, some ioyfull Psalme to sing. Strike vp vvith
〈♫〉
Harp and Lute so svveet, on euery pleasant string.

div.head: TENOR, or Playnsong.
div.p:
☞ 〈♫〉
BE light and glad, in God reioyce, vvhich is our strength and stay:
〈♫〉
Be ioyfull and lift vp your voyce to Iacobs God I say. Prepare your
〈♫〉
instruments most meet, some ioyfull Psalme to sing: Strike vp vvith
〈♫〉
Harp and Lute so svveet, on euery pleasant string.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
BE light and glad, in God reioyce, vvhich is our strength and stay:
〈♫〉
Be ioyfull aud lift vp your voyce to Iacobs God I say. Prepare your
〈♫〉
instruments most meet, some ioyfull Psalme to sing. Strike vp vvith
〈♫〉
Harp and Lute so svveet, on euery pleasant string.

lg.l: Blovv as it vvere in the nevv Moone,
vvith Trumpets of the best;
As it is vsed to be done
at any solemne feast.
For this is vnto Israel
a statute and a trade,
A lavv that must be kept full vvell,
vvhich Iacobs God hath made.
This lavv vvith Ioseph vvas decreed
vvhen he from Egypt came:
That as a vvitnesse, all his seed
should still obserue the same.
VVhen God I say had thus prepar'd,
to bring him from the land,
Whereas the speech vvhich he had heard,
he did not vnderstand.
I from his shoulders tooke, saith he,
the burthen cleane avvay:
And from the furnace set him free
from burning bricke of clay.
VVhen thou in griefe didst cry and call
I holpe thee by and by:
And I did ansvver thee vvithall,
in thunder secretly.
Yea, at the vvaters of discord
I did thee tempt and proue:
VVhereas the goodnesse of the Lord
vvith muttering thou didst moue.
Heare O my folke, O Israel,
and I assure it thee,
Regard and mark my vvords full vvell,
if thou vvilt cleaue to me.
Thou shalt no God in thee reserue,
of any land abroad:
Nor in no vvise to bovv or serue
a strange or forraine God.
I am the Lord thy God, and I
from Egypt set thee free:
Then aske of me abundantly,
and I shall giue it thee.
And yet my people vvould not heare
my voyce vvhen that I spake:
Nor Israel vvould not obay,
but did me quite forsake.
Then did I leaue them to their vvill,
in hardnesse of their heart:
To vvalke in their ovvne counsell still,
themselues they might peruert.
O that my people vvould haue heard
the vvords that I did say:
And eke that Israel vvould regard
to vvalke vvithin my vvay.
Hovv soone vvould I confound their foes,
and bring them dovvn full lovv:
And turne my hand vpon all those
that vvould them ouerthrovv?
And they that at the Lord doe rage,
as slaues should seeke him till▪
But of his folke the time and age
should flourish euer still.
I vvould haue fed them vvith the crop
and finest of the vvheat:
And made the rocke vvith hony drop.
that they their fils should ea • e.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
AMid the prease vvith men of might, the Lord himselfe did stand:

〈♫〉
To plead the cause of truth and right, vvith Iudges of the land.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.l: AMid the prease vvith men of might, the Lord himselfe did stand:

〈♫〉
To plead the cause of truth and right, vvith Iudges of the land.

div.head: TENOR, or Playnsong.
div.l:
☞ 〈♫〉
AMid the prease vvith men of might, the Lord himselfe did stand:

〈♫〉
To plead the cause of truth and right, vvith Iudges of the land.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
AMid the prease vvith men of might, the Lord himselfe did stand:

〈♫〉
To plead the cause of truth and right, vvith Iudges of the land.

lg.l: Hovv long (saith he) vvill ye proceed,
false Iudgement to avvard?
And haue respect for loue of meede,
the vvicked to regard?
VVhereas of due you should defend
the father lesse and vveake:
And vvhen the poore man doth contend,
in iudgement iustly speake.
If ye be vvise, defend the cause
of poore men in their right:
And rid the needy from the clavves
of tyrants force and might.
But nothing vvill they knovv or learn,
in vaine to them I talke:
They vvill not see or ought discerne,
but still in darkenesse vvalke.
For loe, euen novv the time is come
that all things fall to nought:
And likevvise lavves both all and some,
for gaine are sold and bought.
I had decreed it in my sight,
as Gods to take you all:
And children of the most of might,
for loue I did you call.
But notvvithstanding ye shall dye
as men, and so decay:
O Tyrants I shall you destroy,
and plucke you quite avvay.
Vp Lord, & let thy strength be knovvne,
and iudge the vvorld vvith might:
For vvhy? all nations are thine ovvne,
to take them as thy right.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
DOe not O God refraine thy tongue, in silence doe not stay:

〈♫〉
VVith-hold not Lord thy selfe so long, nor make no more delay.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
DOe not O God refraine thy tongue, in silence doe not stay:

〈♫〉
VVith-hold not Lord thy selfe so long, nor make no more delay.

div.head: TENOR, or Playnsong.
div.l:
☞ 〈♫〉
DOe not O God refraine thy tongue, in silence doe not stay:

〈♫〉
VVith-hold not Lord thy selfe so long, nor make no more delay.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
DOe not O God refraine thy tongue, in silence doe not stay:

〈♫〉
VVith-hold not Lord thy selfe so long, nor make no more delay.

lg.l: For vvhy, behold thy foes, and see
hovv they doe rage and cry:
And those that beare an hate to thee,
hold vp their heads on hie.
Against thy folke they vse decoit,
and craftily they enquire:
For thine elect to lye in vvait,
their counsell doth conspire.
Come on, say they, let vs expell,
and plucke these folke avvay:
So that the name of Israel
may vtterly decay.
They all conspire vvithin their hearts,
hovv they may thee vvithstand:
Against the Lord to take a part
they are in league and hand
The tents of all the Edomites,
the Israelites also:
The Haggarens and Moabites,
vvith diuers other moe.
G • bal vvith Ammon, and likevvise,
doth Amalock conspire:
The Philistines against thee rise,
vvith them that dvvell at Tyre.
And Assur eke is vvell apaid
vvith them in league to be:
And doth become a fence and aid
to Lots posteritie.
As thou didst to the Midiani • es,
so serue them Lord each one:
As to Siser and to Iabin
beside the brooke K • son.
VVhom thou in Endor didst destroy,
and vvaste them through thy might:
That they like doung on earth did lie,
and that in open sight.
Make them novv & their Lords appear
like Zeb and Oreb then:
As Zeba and Zalmana vvere
the Kings of Madian:
VVhich said, let vs throughout the land
in all the coasts abroad
Possesse, and take into our hand
the fayre houses of God.
Turne them O God vvith stormes as fast
as vvheeles that haue no stay:
Or like as chaffe vvhich men doe cast
vvith vvindes to flye avvay.
Like as the fire with rage and fume,
the mightie forrests spils:
And as the flame doth quite consume
the mountaines and the hils.
So let the tempest of thy wrath
vpon their necks be laid:
And of the stormie wind and showre,
Lord make them all afraid.
Lord bring them all I thee desire
to such rebuke and shame:
That it may cause them to enquire,
and learne to seeke thy name,
And let them euermore daily
to shame and slander fall:
And in rebuke and obloquie
to perish eke withall
That they may know and feele full wel,
that thou art called Lord:
And that alone thou dost excell,
and raigne throughout the world.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
HOvv pleasant is thy dvvelling place O Lord of hosts to mee?

〈♫〉
The tabernacles of thy grace, hovv pleasant Lord they be?

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
HOw pleasant is thy dwelling place, O Lord of hosts to me?

〈♫〉
The tabernacles of thy grace, how pleasant Lord they be?

div.head: TENOR, or Playnsong.
div.l:
☞ 〈♫〉
HOvv pleasant is thy dvvelling place, O Lord of hosts to mee?

〈♫〉
The tabernacles of thy grace, hovv pleasant Lord they be.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
HOw pleasant is thy dwelling place, O Lord of hosts to mee?

〈♫〉
The tabernacles of thy grace, how pleasant Lord they be:

lg.l: My soule doth long full sore to goe
into thy courts abroad▪
My heart doth lust, my flesh also
in thee the liuing God.
The Sparrovves finde a roome to rest,
and saue themselues from vvrong:
And eke the Svvallovv hath a nest
vvherein to keepe her young.
These birds full night thine altar may
haue place to set and sing:
O Lord of hosts thou art (I say)
my God and eke my King.
Oh they be blessed that may dvvell
vvithin thy house alvvayes:
For they all times thy facts doe tell,
and giue thy name the praise.
Yea happy sure likevvise are they,
vvhose stay and strength thou art:
VVhich to thy house doe minde the vvay,
and seeke it in their heart.
As they go through the vale of teares,
they dig vp fountaines still.
That as a spring it all appeares,
and thou their pits dost fill.
From strength to strength they vvalke full fast
no faintnes there shall be:
And so the God of Gods at last
in Sion they doe see.
O Lord of hosts to me giue heed,
and heare when I doe pray:
And let it through thine eares proc • ed,
O Iacobs God I say.
O Lord our shield, of thy good grace
regard and so draw neere:
Regard I say, behold the face
of thine anointed deare.
For why? within thy courts one day
is better so abide,
Then other where to keepe or stay
a thousand dayes beside,
Much rather would I keepe a doore
within the house of God:
Then in the tents of wickednesse
to settle mine aboad.
For God the Lord, light and defence,
will grace and worship giue:
And no good thing will he with-hold
from them that purely liue.
O Lord of hosts that man is blest,
and happie sure is he:
That is perswaded in his breast
to trust all tunes in thee.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
THou hast beene mercifull indeed, O Lord vnto thy land: For
〈♫〉
thou restoredst Iacobs seed from thraldome out of band.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
THou hast beene mercifull indeed, O Lord vnto thy land: For
〈♫〉
thou restoredst Iacobs seed from thraldome out of band,

div.head: TENOR, or Playnsong.
div.p:
☞ 〈♫〉
THou hast beene mercifull indeed, O Lord vnto thy land: For
☞ 〈♫〉
thou restoredst Iacobs seed from thraldome out of band.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
THou hast beene mercifull indeed, O Lord vnto thy land: For
〈♫〉
thou restoredst Iacobs seed from thraldome out of band.

lg.l: The wicked wayes that they were in
thou didst them cleane remit:
And thou didst hide thy peoples sin,
full close thou coueredst it.
Thine anger eke thou didst as • wage,
that all thy wrath was gone:
And so didst turne thee from thy • age,
with them to be at one.
O God our health, doe now conuert
thy people vnto thee:
Put all thy wrath from vs apart,
and angry cease to be.
Why shall thine anger neuer end,
but stil proceed on vs?
And shall thy wrath it selfe extend
vpon all ages thus?
Wilt thou not rather turne therefore
and quicken vs, that we
And all thy folke may euermore
be glad and ioy in thee.
O Lord on vs doe thou declare
thy goodnesse to our wealth:
Shew forth to vs and doe not spare,
thine aid and sauing health.
I will hearke what God saith, for he
speakes to his people peace:
And to his Saints that neuer they
returne to foolishnesse.
For why? his helpe is still at hand
to such as doe him feare
Whereby great glory in the land
shall dwell and flourish there.
For truth and mercie there shall meet
in one to take their place▪
And peace shall iustice with kisse greet,
and there they shall embrace.
As truth from earth shall spring apace
and flourish pleasantly▪
So righteousnesse shall shew her face▪
and looke from heauen hie.
Yea, God himselfe shall take in hand
to giue vs each good thing:
And through the coasts of all our Land
the earth 〈◊〉 fruits shall •• ing.
Before his face shall iustice goe
〈◊〉 like a guide or stay:
He shall direct his steps also,
and keepe them in the way.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
LOrd bow thine eare to my request, and heare me by and by:
〈♫〉
with grieuous paine and griefe opprest full poore and weake am I.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
LLord bow thine eare to my request and heare me by and by▪
〈♫〉
with grieuous paine and griefe opprest full poore and weake am I.

div.head: TENOR, or Playnsong.
div.p:
☞ 〈♫〉
LOrd bow thine eare to my request, and heare me by and by:
〈♫〉
with grieuous paine and griefe opprest full poore and weake am I.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
LOrd bow thine eare to my request, and heare me by and by:
〈♫〉
with grieuous paine and griefe opprest full poore and weake am I.

lg.l: Preserue my soule because my wayes
and doings holy be:
And saue thy seruant O my Lord,
that puts his 〈◊〉 in thee.
Thy mercy Lord on me expresse,
defend me eke withall▪
For through the day I doe not cease
on thee to cry and call.
Comfort O Lord thy seruants soule,
that now with paine is pinde:
For vnto thee Lord I extoll
and • ift my soule and mind.
For thou art good and • ount • full,
thy gifts of grace are free:
And eke thy mercie plentifull▪
to all that call on thee.
O Lord likewise when I doe pray
regard and giue an eare:
Marke well the words that I doe say
and all my prayers heare.
In tune when trouble doth me moue,
to thee I doe complaine:
For why I know and well doe proue,
thou answerest me againe.
Among the Gods, Lord there is none
with thee to be compar'd:
And none can doe as thou alone,
the like hath not beene heard.
The Gentiles and the people all,
which thou didst make and frame:
Before thy face on knees shall fall
and glorifie thy name.
For why? thou art so much of might,
all power is thine owne:
Thou workest wonders still in sight,
for thou art God alone.
O teach me Lord thy way, and I
shall in thy truth proceed:
O ioyne my heart to thee so • e,
that i • thy Name may dread
To the • my God will I giue praise,
with all my heart (O Lord)
And glorifie thy Name alwayes,
for euer through the world.
For why? thy mercy shew'd to me
• s great and doth excell:
Thou • erst my soule at libertie
out from the lowe • hell▪

O Lord the proud against me 〈◊〉
▪
and heapes of men of might▪
They se • ke my soule and in no wise
will haue thee in their sight.
Thou Lord art mercifull and meele •
full slacke and slow to wrath:
Thy goodnesse is full great, and eke
thy truth no measure hath.
O turne to me and mercie grant.
thy strength to me apply:
O helpe and saue thine owne seruant,
thine handmaids sonne am I.
On me some signe off • uou • shew,
that all my foes may see,
And be asham'd because Lord thou
dost help and comfort me.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
THat Citie shall full well endure, her ground-work still doth stay:

〈♫〉
Vpon thy holy hill full sure it can no time decay.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
THat Citie shall full well endure, her ground-work still doth stay:

〈♫〉
Vpon thy holy hill full sure, it can no time decay.

div.head: TENOR, or Playnsong.
div.l:
☞ 〈♫〉
THat Citie shall full well endure, her ground-work still doth stay:

〈♫〉
Vpon the holy hill full sure it can no time decay.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
THat Citie shall full well endure, her ground-work still doth stay

〈♫〉
Vpon thy holy hill full s •• e, it can no time decay.

lg.l: God loues the 〈◊〉 of 〈◊〉 best,
his grace doth there abide:
He loues them more then all the rest
of Iacobs tents beside
For glorious things reported be
in Sion and abroad:
Great things I say are said of thee
thou citie of our God▪
On Rahab I will cast an eye,
and beare in mind the same:
And Babilon shall eke apply
and learne to know thy nam • .
Loe • alestine and Tyre also,
with I • hiope likewise.
A people old full long agoe
were borne, and there did rise.
Of Sion they shall say abroad
that diuers men of • ame:
Haue there sprung vp, and the high God
hath founded fast the same.
In their records to them it shall
through Gods deuise appeare,
Of Siou that the chiefe of all
had his beginning there.
The trumpetters with such as sing
therein great plentie be:
My fountaines and my pleasant springs
are compast all in thee.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
LOrd God of health the hope and stay thou art alone to mee:

〈♫〉
I call and cry throughout the day and all the night to thee.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
LOrd God of health the hope and stay thou art alone to mee

〈♫〉
I call and cry throughout the day and all the night to thee.

div.head: TENOR, or Playnsong.
div.l:
☞ 〈♫〉
LOrd God of health the hope and stay thou art alone to mee:

〈♫〉
I call and cry throughout the day and all the night to thee.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
LOrd God of health the hope and stay thou art alone to mee:

〈♫〉
I call and cry throughout the day and all the night to thee.

lg.l: O let my prayers soone ascend
vnto thy sight on h • e:
Incline thine eare (O Lord) intend
• nd hearken to my cry,
For why my soule with woe is fild,
and doth in trouble dwell:
My life and breath almost doth yeeld
and draweth 〈◊〉 to he • l▪
I am esteem'd as one of them
that in the pit doe fall:
And made as one among those men
that haue no strength at all.
As one among the dead, and free
from things that here remaine:
It were more ease for me to bee
with them the which are slaine,
As those that lie in graue I say.
whom thou hast cleane forgot:
The which th • e hand hath cut away
and thou regardst them not.
Yea, like to one shut vp full sure
within the lower put:
In places darke and all obscure,
and in the depth of it.
Thine anger and thy wrath likewise
full sore on me doth lie:
And all thy stormes against me rise
my soule to vexe and tr • e.
Thou puts my friends far off from me,
and mak • st them hate me sore:
I am shut vp in prison fast,
and can come forth no more.
My sight doth fa • le through griefe and woe
I call to thee O God:
Throughout the day, my hands also
to thee I stretch abroad.
Dost thou vnto the dead decl • re
thy wondrous works of fame?
Shall dead to l • fe againe • estore
and praise thee for the same?
Or shall thy l • uing kindnesse, Lord,
be preached in the graue?
Or shall with them that are destroy'd
thy truth her honour haue?
Shall they that lie in darke full low
of all thy wonders wot?
Or there shall they thy iustice know
where all things are forgot?
But I O Lord to thee alway
doe cry and call apace:
My prayer eke ere it be day
shall come before thy face.
Why dost thou Lord abhorre my soule,
in griefe that seeketh thee:
And now O • ord why dost thou hide
thy face away from me▪
I am afflict as dying still,
from youth this many a yeere:
Thy terrours which doe vexe me still
with troubled mind I beare.
The furies of thy wrathfull rage,
full sore vpon me fall▪
Thy terrours eke doe not asswage,
but me oppresse withall.
All day they compasse me about,
as water at the tide:
And all at once with streames full stout
beset me on each side.
Thou settest far from me my friends,
and louers euery one:
Yea, and mine old acquaintance all
out of my sight are gone.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
TO sing the mercies of the Lord my tongue shall neuer spare:

〈♫〉
And with my mouth from age to age thy truth I will declare.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
TO sing the mercies of the Lord my tongue shall neuer spare:

〈♫〉
And with my mouth from age to age thy truth I will declare.

div.head: TENOR, or Playnsong.
div.l:
☞ 〈♫〉
TO sing the mercies of the Lord my tongue shall neuer spare:

〈♫〉
And with my mouth from age to age thy truth I will declare.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
TO sing the mercies of the Lord my tongue shall neuer spare.

〈♫〉
And with my mouth from age to age thy truth I will declare.

lg.l: For I haue said that mercie shall
for euermore remaine:
In that th • u dost the heauens stay
thy truth appeareth plaine▪
To mine elect • s • ith God) I made
a couenant and behest:
My seruant Dauid to perswade,
I swore and did protest.
Thy seed for euer I will stay,
and stabli • h it full fast:
And 〈◊〉 vphold thy throne alway,
from age to age to last.
The heauens shew with 〈◊〉 and mi • th
thy wond • ous works O • ord:
Thy Sa • nts within thy Church on earth
thy fa • th and truth • ecord.
Who with the Lord is equall then
in a • l the clouds ab • o • d?
Among the sonnes of all the Gods
what one is like our God?
God in assembly of his Saints
is greatly to be dread:
And ouer all that dwell about,
in terrour to be had.
Lord God of hosts, in all the world
what one is like to thee?
On euery side most mightie Lord,
thy truth is seene to be.
The raging sea by thine aduice,
thou rulest at thy will:
And when the waues thereof arise
thou mak'st them calme and still.
And Egypt Lord thou hast subdude▪
and thou hast it destroyd:
Yea, thou thy foes with mighty a • me
hast scattered all abroad.
The heauens are thine & still haue bin,
likewise the earth and Land:
The world and all that is therein
thou foundedst with thy hand.
Both North and South, with East and West
thy selfe didst make and frame:
Both Tabor Mount and eke Hermon
reioyce and praise thy Name.
Thine arme is strong and ful of power,
all might therein doth lie:
The strength of thy right hand each houre
thou liftest vp on hie.
In righteousnesse and equitie
thou hast thy seat and place:
Mercie and truth is still with thee,
and goe before thy face.
That folke is blest that know'th aright
thy present power O God,
For in the fauour of thy sight▪
they walke full safe abroad.
For in thy name throughout the day
they ioy and much reioice:
And through thy righteousnesse haue they
a pleasant fame and noyse.
For why? their glorie, strength and aide,
in thee alone doth • e:
Thy goodnesse eke that hath vs staid
shall lift our hornes on hie.
Our strength that doth defend vs well,
the Lord to vs doth bring:
The holy one of Israel,
he is our strength and King,
Sometime thy will vnto thy Saints,
in vision thou dost show:
And thus then didst thou say to them,
thy mind to make them know.
A man of might I haue erect
your King and guide to be:
And set vp him whom I elect
among the folke to me.
My seruant Dauid I appoint,
whom I haue searched out:
And with my holy oile anoint
him King of all the rout.
For why? my hand is readie still
with him for to remaine:
And with mine arme also I will
him strengthen and sustaine.
The enemies shall not him oppresse,
they shall him not deuoure:
Ne yet the sonnes of wickednesse
on him shall haue no power.
His foes likewise I will destroy
before his face in sight:
And those that hate him I will plague,
and strike them with my might.
My truth and mercie eke withall
Shall still vpon him lie:
And in my name his borne eke shall
be lifted vp on hie.
His Kingdome I will set to be
vpon the sea and land:
And eke the running flouds shall be
embrace with his right hand.
He shall depend with all his heart
on me, and thus shall say:
My father and my God thou art,
my rocke of health and stay.
As one first borne I will him take
of all on earth that springs:
His might and honour I shall mak •
aboue all worldly Kings.
My mercie shall be with him still,
as I my selfe haue told:
My faithfull couenant to fulfill,
my mercie I will hold.
And eke his seed I will sustaine
for euer strong and sure:
So that his seat shall still remaine
while heauen and earth endure.
If that his sonnes forsake my law,
and so begin to swerue.
And of my iudgments haue no awe,
nor will not them obserue:
Or if they doe not vse aright
my statutes to them made:
And set all my commandements light,
and will not keepe my trade.
Then with the rod will I begin
their doings to amend:
And so with scourging for their sinne
when that they doe offend.
My mercie yet and my goodnesse
I will not take him fro:
Nor handle him with craftinesse,
and so my truth forgoe.
But sure my couenant I will hold
with all that I haue spoke:
No word the which my lips haue told
shall alter or be broke.
Once sware I by my hol • nesse,
and that pe • forme will I,
With Dauid I will keepe promise
to him I will not lie.
His seed for euermore shall raigne
and eke his throne of might
As doth the Sunne it shall remaine
for euer in my sight.
And as the Moone within the skie
for euer standeth fast:
A faithfull witnesse from on hie,
so shall his kingdome last.
But now (O Lord) thou dost reiect,
and now thou changest cheare:
Yea, thou art wroth with thine elect,
thine owne anointed dea • e.
The couenant with thy seruant made
Lord thou hast quite vndone:
And downe vpon the ground also
hast cast his royall crowne.
Thou pluckst his hedges vp with might,
his wals thou dost con • ound.
Thou beat • st eke his bulwarks downe,
and breakst them to the ground,
That he is sore destroide and torne
of commers by throughout:
And so is made a mocke and scorne
to all that dwell about.
Thou their right hand hast lifted vp
that him so sore annoy▪
And all his foes that him deuoure,
loe▪ thou hast made to ioy.
His sword edge thou didst take away
that should his foes withstand:
To him in war • e no victorie
thou giu'st, no • vpper hand.
His glorie thou dost also wast▪
his throne, his ioy and mirth:
By thee is ouerthrowne and cast
full low vpon the earth
Thou hast cut off, and made full short
his youth and lusty dayes:
And rais'd of him an ill report,
with shame and great dispraise.
How long away from me, O Lord,
for euer wilt thou turne?
And shall thine anger still alway
as fire consume and burne?
O call to mind, remember then
my time consumeth fast:
Why hast thou made the sonnes of men
as things in vaine to wast?
What man is he that liueth here
and death shall neuer see
Or from the hand of hell his soule
shall he deliuer free:
Where is O Lord, thine old goodnesse,
so oft declard'd beforne
Which by thy truth and vprightnesse
to Dauid thou hast sworne?
The great rebukes to mind I call
that on thy seruants lie:
The railing of thy people all
borne in my b • est • aue I.
Wherewith O Lord thine enemies
blasphemed haue thy name:
The steps of thine anointed one
they cease not to defame.
All praise to thee O Lord of hosts,
both now and eke for aye:
Through skie and earth and all the coasts,
Amen, Amen, I say.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
THou Lord hast beene our sure defence, our place of ease and rest:

〈♫〉
In all times past, yea, so long since as cannot be exprest.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
THou Lord hast beene our sure defence, our place of ease and rest:

〈♫〉
In all times past, yea, so long since as cannot be exprest.

div.head: TENOR, or Plainsong.
div.l:
☞ 〈♫〉
THou Lord hast beene our sure defence, our place of ease and rest

〈♫〉
In all times past, yea, so long since as cannot be exprest.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
THou Lord hast beene our sure defence, our place of ease and rest

〈♫〉
In all times past, yea, so long since as cannot be exprest.

lg.l: Ere there was made mountaine or hill,
the earth and all abroad:
From age to age and alwayes still
for euer thou art God.
Thou grindest man through griefe and paine
to dust or clay, and then,
And then thou saiest againe, returne
againe ye sonnes of men,
The lasting of a thousand yeere,
what is it in thy sight?
As yesterday it doth appeare,
or as a watch by night.
So soone as thou dost scatter them,
then is their life and trade
All as a sleepe, and like the grasse,
whose beauty soone doth fade.
which in the morning shines full bright
but fadeth by and by:
And is cut downe ere it be night,
all w • thered, dead and dry.
For through thine anger we consume,
our might is much decaid▪
And of thy feruent wrath and fume
we are full sore afraid.
The wicked workes that we haue wrought
thou setst before thine eye▪
Our p • iuy faults, yea, eke our thoughts
thy countenance doth spye.
For through thy wrath our dayes doe waste,
thereof doth nought remaine:
Our yeeres consume as words or blasts,
and are not cald againe.
Our time is threescore yeeres and ten
that we doe liue on mould▪
If one see fourescore, surely then
we count him wondrous old.
Yet of this time the strength and age
the which we count vpon:
Is nothing else but painfull griefe,
and we as blasts are gone.
Who once doth know what strength is there,
what might thine anger hath?
Or in his heart who doth thee feare
according to thy wrath?
Instruct vs Lord to know and try
how long our dayes remaine:
That then we may our hearts apply
true wisedome to attaine.
Returne O Lord, how long wilt thou
• o • th on in wrath proceed?
Shew fauour to thy se • uants now,
and helpe them at their need.
Refresh vs with thy mercie soone▪
and then our ioy shall be▪
All times so long as life doth last
in heart reioyce shall we.
As thou hast plagued vs before,
now also make vs glad▪
And for the yeeres wherein full sore
affliction we haue had.
O let thy worke and power appeare
and on thy seruants light:
And shew vnto thy children d • ere
thy glory and thy might.
Lord let thy grace and glory stand
on vs thy seruants thus:
Confirme the workes we take in hand,
Lord prosper them to vs.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
HEE that within the secret place of God most hye doth dwell:

〈♫〉
In shadow of the mightiest grace, at rest will keepe him well.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
HEE that within the secret place of God most hie doth dwell:

〈♫〉
In shadow of the mightiest grace at rest will keepe him well.

div.head: TENOR or Playnsong.
div.l:
☞ 〈♫〉
HEE that within the secret place of God most hie doth dwell:

〈♫〉
In shadow of the mightiest grace, at rest will keepe him well.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
HEE that within the secret place of God most hye doth dwell:

〈♫〉
In shadow of the mightiest grace at rest will keepe him well

lg.l: Thou art my hope and my strong hold,
I to the Lord will say:
My God he is, in him will I,
my whole affiance stay.
He shall defend thee from the snare,
the which the hunter laid:
And from the deadly plague and care,
whereof thou art afraid.
And with his wings shall couer thee,
and k • epe thee safely there▪
His faith and truth thy fence shall bee,
as sure as shield and speare.
So that thou shalt not need I say
to feare or be affright:
Of all the shafts that flye by day,
nor terrors of the night.
Nor of the plague that priuily
doth walke in darke to fast▪
Nor yet of that which doth destroy
and at noone dayes doth waste.
Yea at thy side as thou dost stand,
a thousand dead shall be▪
Ten thousand eke at thy right hand,
and yet thou shalt be free.
But thou shalt see it for thy part,
thine eyes shall well regard:
That euen like to their desert,
the wi • ked haue reward.
For why? O Lord I onely 〈◊〉 ,
to stay my hope on thee:
And in the highest I put my trust,
my su • e defence is he.
Thou shalt not need none ill to feare,
with thee it shall not mell:
Nor yet the plague shall once come neare
the house where thou dost dwell.
For why? vnto his Angels all,
with charge commanded he,
That still in all thy wayes they shall
preserue and prosper thee.
And in their hands shall thee beare vp,
still waiting thee vpon:
So that thy foot shall neuer chance
• o spurne at any stone.
Vpon the Lyon thou shalt goe,
the Adder fell and long:
And tread vpon the Lyons young,
with Dragons stout and strong.
For he that trusteth vnto mee,
I will dispatch him quite:
And him defend, because that hee
doth know my name a • ight.
When he for health on me doth cry,
an answere I will giue▪
And from his griefe take him will I,
in glory for to liue.
With length of yeares, and dayes of wealth
I will fulfill his time▪
The goodnesse of my sauing health
I will declare to him.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
IT is a thing both good and meet to praise the highest Lord:

〈♫〉
And to thy name, O thou most high to sing with one accord.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
IT is a thing both good and meet to prayse the highest Lord

〈♫〉
And to thy name, O thou most high to sing with one accord.

div.head: TENOR or Playnsong.
div.l:
☞ 〈♫〉
IT is a thing both good and meet to praise the highest Lord:

〈♫〉
And to thy name, O thou most high to sing with one accord.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
IT is a thing both good and meet to praise the highest Lord:

〈♫〉
And to thy name, O thou most high to sing with one accord.

lg.l: To shew the kindnesse of the Lord
betime, ere day be light:
And eke declare his truth abroad
when it doth draw to night.
Vpon ten stringed instruments,
on Lu • e and Harpe so sweet:
With all the mirth you can inuent
on instruments most meet.
For thou hast made me to reioyce
in things so wrought by thee:
And I haue ioy in heart and voice
thy handle worke to see.
O Lord how glorious and how great
are all thy workes so stout:
So deeply are thy counsels set
that noue can try them out.
The man vnwise hath not the wit
this geare to passe to bring:
And all such fooles are nothing fit
to vnderstand this thing,
When so the wicked at their will
as grasse doe spring full fast▪
They, when they flourish in their ill,
for euer shall be wast.
But thou art mightie Lord most high,
yea, thou dost raigne therefore:
In euery time etenally,
both now and euermore.
For why O Lord behold and 〈◊〉 ,
behold my foes I say:
How all that worke iniquitie
shall perish and decay.
But thou like as an Vnicorne
shalt lift mine horne on hie,
With fresh and new prepared oile
thine ointed King am I.
And of my foes before mine eies
shall see the fall and shame:
Of all that vp against me rise
mine eares shall heare the same.
The • ust shall flourish vp on hie,
as Date trees bud and blow:
And as the Cedars multiply
in Libanus that grow.
For the • are planted in the place
and dwelling of our God:
Within his courts they spring apace
and flourish all abroad.
And in their age much fruits shall spring,
both fat and well be seene:
And pleasantly both bud and spring
with boughes and branches greene.
To shew that God is good and iust,
and vpright in his will:
He is my rocke, my hope and trust,
in him there is no ill▪

div.head: CANTVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
THe Lord as king, aloft doth raigne in glory goodly dight: And
〈♫〉
he to shew his strength and maine hath girt himselfe with might.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
THe Lord as king aloft doth raigne in glory goodly dight: And
〈♫〉
he to shew his strength and maine hath girt himselfe with might.

div.head: TENOR, or Playnsong.
div.p:
☞ 〈♫〉
THe Lord as king aloft doth raigne in glory goodly dight▪ And
〈♫〉
he to shew his strength and maine hath girt himselfe with might.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
THe Lord as king aloft doth raigne in glory goodly dight▪ And
〈♫〉
he to shew his strength and maine hath girt himselfe with might.

lg.l: The Lord likewise the earth hath made
and shaped it full sure:
No might can make it moue o • fade,
at stay it doth endure.
Ere that the world was made or wrought,
thy seat was set before:
Beyond all time that can be thought,
thou hast beene euermore.
The flouds O Lord the flouds doe rise,
they 〈◊〉 and make a noise:
The flouds I say did enterprise
and lifted up their voice.
Yea, though the stormes arise in sight
though sea doe rage and swell:
The Lord is strong and more of might▪
for he on hie doth dwell.
And looke what promise he doth make
his houshold to defend
For iust and true they shall it take
all times without an end.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
O Lord thou dost reuenge all wrong, that office longs to thee▪

〈♫〉
Sith vengeance doth belong to thee declare that all may see.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
O Lord thou dost reuenge all wrong, that office longs to thee:

〈♫〉
Sith vengeance doth belong to thee declare that all may see.

div.head: TENOR, or Playnsong.
div.l:
☞ 〈♫〉
O Lord thou dost reuenge all wrong, that office longs to thee:

〈♫〉
Sith vengeance doth belong to thee, declare that all may see.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
O Lord thou dost reuenge all wrong, that office longs to thee:

〈♫〉
Sith vengeance doth belong to thee declare that all may see.

lg.l: Set forth thy selfe, for thou of right▪
the earth dost iudge and guide:
Re • ard the proud and men of might,
according to their pride,
How long shall wicked men beare s • ay
with l • fting vp their voice?
How long shall wicked men I say,
thus 〈◊〉 and reioyce?
How long shall they with brags bu • st out
and proudly prate their fill?
Shall they reioyce that be so stout,
whose workes are euer ill?
Thy flocke O Lord, thine heritage
they spoile and vexe full so • e.
Against thy people they doe • age
still daily more and more.
The widdowes which are comfortlesse,
and strangers they destroy,
They s •• y the children f • therlesse,
and none doe put them by.
And when they take these things in hand
this talke they haue of thee:
Can Iacobs God this vnderstand?
〈◊〉 , no he cannot see.
O folke vnwise and people rude,
some knowledge now discerne▪
Yee fooles among the multitude
at length begin to learne.
The Lord which made the eare of man
he needs of • ight must heare:
He made the eyes, 〈◊〉 things must then
before his sight appeare.
The Lord doth all the world correct,
and make them vnderstand▪
Sh •• l he not then your deeds detect?
how can you 〈◊〉 his h • nd?
The Lord doth know the thoughts of man
his heart he seeth full plaine:
The Lord I say mens thoughts doth scan
and findeth them but vaine:
But Lord that man is happy sure,
whom thou dost keepe in awe:
And through correction dost procure
to teach him in thy Law.
Whereby he shall in quiet rest
in time of trouble sit:
When wicked men shall be supprest,
and fall into the pit.
For sure the Lord will not refuse
his people for to take:
His heritage whom he did chuse,
he will no time forsake.
Vntill that iudgement be decreed
to iustice to conue • t▪
That all may follow her with speed,
that are of vpright heart.
But who vpon my part shall stand
against the wicked traine?
Or who shall • id me from their hands
that wicked workes maintaine.
Except the Lord had beene mine aid
mine enemies to repell:
My life and soule had now beene laid
almost as low as hell.
When I did say my foot doth slide,
and I am like to fall:
Thy goodnesse Lord did so prouide
to stay me vp withall.
When with my selfe I mused much,
and could no comfort find:
Then Lord thy goodnesse did me touch,
and that did ease my mind,
Wilt thou inhaunt thy selfe, and draw
with wicked men to sit?
Which with pretence in stead of Law
much mischiefe doe commit.
For they consult against the life
of righteous men and good:
And in their counsell they are rise
to shed the guiltlesse bloud.
But yet the Lord he is to mee
a strong defence or locke:
He is my God to him I flie,
he is my strength and rocke.
And he shall cause their mischiefes all
themselues for to annoy:
And in their malice they shall fall,
our God shall them destroy.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
O Come, let vs lift vp our voyce and sing vnto the Lord: In him
〈♫〉
our rocke of health, reioyce let vs with one accord.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
O Come, let vs lift vp our voyce, and sing vnto the Lord, In him
〈♫〉
our rocke of health, reioyce let vs with one accord.

div.head: TENOR, or Plainsong.
div.p:
☞ 〈♫〉
O Come, let vs lift vp our voyce, and sing vnto the Lord▪ In him
☞ 〈♫〉
our rocke of health, reioyce let vs with one accord.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
O Come, let vs lift vp our voyce, and sing vnto the Lord: In him
〈♫〉
our rock of health, reioyce let vs with one accord.

lg.l: Yea, let vs come before his face,
to giue him thankes and praise
In singing Psalmes vnto his grace,
let vs be glad alwayes.
For why • the Lord he is no doubt
a great and mightie God:
A King aboue all Gods throughout
in all the world abroad.

The secrets of the earth so deep •
▪
and corners of the Land▪
The tops of hils that are so sleepe
he hath them in his hand.
The sea and waters all are his
for he the same hath wrought:
The earth, and all that therein is
his hand hath made of nought.
Come, let vs bow and praise the Lord,
before him let vs fall:
And kneele to him with one accord,
the which hath made vs all.
For why? he is the Lord our God,
for vs he doth prouide:
We a • e his flocke, he doth vs feed,
his sheepe, and he our guide.
To day if ye his voyce will heare,
then harden not your heart:
As ye with giudging many a yeere
prouokt me in desa • t.
Whereas you • fathers tempted me,
my power for to proue:
My wondrous works when they did see,
yet still they would me moue.
Twice twenty yeares they did me grieue,
and I to them did say.
They erre in heart and not beleeue,
they haue not knowne my way.
Wherefore I sware when that my wrath
was kindled in my brest:
That they should neuer tread the path,
nor enter in my rest.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
SIng ye with praise vnto the Lord new songs of ioy and mirth:

〈♫〉
Sing vnto him with one ac- cord all people on the earth.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
SIng ye with prayse vnto the Lord new songs of ioy and mirth:

〈♫〉
Sing vnto him with one accord all people on the earth.

div.head: TENOR, or Playnsong.
div.l:
☞ 〈♫〉
SIng ye with prayse vnto the Lord new songs of ioy and mirth:

〈♫〉
Sing vnto him with one accord all people on the earth.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
SIng ye with praise vnto the Lord new songs of ioy and mirth

〈♫〉
Sing vnto him with one accord all people on the earth.

lg.l: Yea, sing vnto the Lord I say,
praise yee his holy name:
Declare and shew from day to day
saluation by the same.
Among the heathe • eke declare
his honour round about:
To shew his wo • ders do • not spare
in all the world throughout.
For why? the Lord is much of might,
and worthy prayse alway:
And he is to be dread of right
aboue all Gods I say.
For all the Gods of heathen fol •• ,
are I do •• that will • ade:
But yet our God, he is the Lord
that hath the heauens made.
All praise and honour eke doe dwell
for aye before his face:
Both power and might likewise excell
within his holy place.
Ascribe vnto the Lord alway,
ye people of the world,
All might and worship eke, I say
ascribe vnto the Lord.
Ascribe vnto the Lord also,
the glory of his name:
And eke vnto his courts doe goe
with gifts vnto the s • me.
Fall downe and worship ye the Lord,
within his Temple bright:
Let all the people of the world
be fearefull at his sight.
Tell all the World, be not agast,
the Lord doth raigne aboue:
Yea, he hath set the earth so fast,
that it can neuer moue.
And that it is the Lord alone
that rules with Princely might:
To iudge the nations euery one▪
with equitie and right:
The heauens shall great ioy begin,
the earth shall eke reioyce:
The Sea with all that is therein,
shall shout and make a noyse.
The field shall ioy and eu • ry thing
that springeth on the earth:
The wood and euery tree shall sing
with gladnesse and with mirth.
Before the presence of the Lord
and comming of his might:
When he shall iustly iudge the world,
and rule his folke aright.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
THe Lord doth raigne, wherat the earth may ioy with pleasant voyce:

〈♫〉
And eke the Isles with ioyfull mirth may triumph and reioyce.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
THe Lord doth raign, wherat the earth may ioy with pleasant voyce:

〈♫〉
And eke the Isles with ioyfull mirth may triumph and reioyce.

div.head: TENOR, or Playnsong.
div.l:
☞ 〈♫〉
THe Lord doth raigne, wherat the earth may ioy with pleasant voice:

〈♫〉
And eke the Isles with ioyfull mirth may triumph and reioyce.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
THe Lord doth raign, wherat the earth may ioy with pleasant voyce.

〈♫〉
And eke the Isles with ioyfull mirth may triumph and reioyce.

lg.l: Both clouds and darknesse eke doe swell
and round about him beat:
Yea, • ight and iustice euer dwell,
and bide about his seat.
Yea, fire and heat at once doe run
and goe before his face:
Which shall his foes and enemies burne
abroad in euery place.
His lightnings eke full bright did blaze,
and to the world appeare:
Whereat the earth did looke and gaze,
with dread and deadly feare.
The •• ls like waxe did melt in sight,
and presence of the Lord:
They f • ed before the rulers might
which guideth all the world,
The heauens eke declare and shew
his iustice all abroad:
That all the world may see and know
the glory of our God.
Confusion sure shall come to such
as worship Idols vaine:
And eke to those that glory much,
d • mbe pictures to maintaine.
For all the Idols of the world,
which they as Gods doe call
Shall feele the power of the Lord
and downe to him shall fall.
With ioy shall Sion heare this thing,
and Iuda shall reioyce:
For at thy iudgements they shall sing,
and make a pleasant noyse.
That thou O Lord art set on hie
in all the earth abroad:
And art exalted wondrously,
aboue each other God,
All ye that loue the Lord doe this,
hate all things that are ill▪
For he doth keepe the soules of his
from such as would them spill.
And light doth spring vp to the iust
with pleasure for his part:
Great ioy with gladnesse, mirth and • ust,
to them of vpright heart.
Ye righteous in the Lord reioyce,
his holinesse proclaime▪
Be thankfull eke with heart and voyce,
and mindfull of the same.

div.head: Psalme 98.
div.byline: Tho. R • uens. B. of M.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
O Sing yee now vnto the Lord a new and pleasant song: For
〈♫〉
he hath wrought throughout the world his wonders great and strong.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
O Sing ye now vnto the Lord a new and pleasant song: For
〈♫〉
he hath wrought throughout the world his wonders great and strong.

div.head: TENOR, or Playnsong.
div.p:
☞ 〈♫〉
O Sing ye now vnto the Lord a new and pleasant song: For
〈♫〉
he hath wrought throughout the world his wonders great and strong.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
O Sing ye now vnto the Lord a new and pleasant song: For
〈♫〉
he hath wrought throughout the world his wonders great and strong.

lg.l: With his right hand full worthily
he doth his foes deuoure:
And get himselfe the victory
with his owne arme and power▪
The Lord doth make the people know
his sauing health and might:
The Lord doeh eke his iustice shew,
in all the heathens sight.
His grace and truth to Israel
in mind he doth record:
That all the earth may see right well
the goodnesse of the Lord.
Be glad in him with ioyfull voice,
all people on the earth:
Giue thankes to God, sing and reioyce
to 〈◊〉 with ioy and mirth.
Vpon the Harpe vnto him sing,
giue thankes to him with Psalmes:
Reioyce before the Lord our King,
with Trumpets and with Shalmes.
Yea, let the Sea with all therein,
with ioy both roare and swell:
The earth likewise let it begin.
with all that therein dwell.
And let the flouds reioyce their fils
and clap their hands apace:
And eke the mountaines and the hils
before the Lord his face.
For he shall come to iudge and try
the world and euery wight:
And rule the people mightily
with iustice and with right.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
THE Lord doth raigne although at it, the people rage full sore:

〈♫〉
Yea, he on Cherubins doth sit, though all the world doe roare.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
THe Lord doth raigne although at it the people rage full sore:

〈♫〉
Yea, he on Cherubins doth sit, though all the world doe roare.

div.head: TENOR or Playnsong.
div.l:
☞ 〈♫〉
THE Lord doth raigne although at it, the people rage full sore

〈♫〉
Yea, he on Cherubins doth sit, though all the world doe roare.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
THe Lord doth raigne although at it the people rage full sore:

〈♫〉
Yea, he on Cherubins doth sit, though all the world doe roare.

lg.l: The Lord that doth in Sion dwell,
is high and wondrous great:
Aboue all folke he doth excell,
and he aloft is set.
Let all men prayse thy holy Name,
for it is fearefull sure:
And let them magnifie the same
that holy is and pure.
The princely power of our King
doth loue iudgement and right:
Thou rightly rulest euery thing
in Iacob, through thy might.
To prayse the Lord our God deuise,
all honor to him doe:
Before his footstoole doe likewise,
for he is holy too.
Moses, Aaron and Samuell▪
as Priests on him did call:
When they did pray he heard them well
and gaue them answere all.
Within the cloud to them he spake,
then did they labour still:
To keepe such Lawes as he did make
and pointed them vntill
O Lord our God thou didst them heare,
and answeredst them againe:
Thy mercy did on them appeare,
their deeds didst not maintaine.
O laud and praise our God and Lord
within his hol • hill:
For why? our God throughout the world
is holy euer still.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
AL people that on earth do dwel sing to the Lord with chearful voice

〈♫〉
Him serue with feare, his praise forth tell, come ye before him and reioyce.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
AL people that on earth do dwel sing to the Lord with chearful voice:

〈♫〉
Him serue with feare, his praise forth tell, come ye be-fore him and reioyce.

div.head: TENOR, or Playnsong.
div.l:
☞ 〈♫〉
AL people that on earth do dwel, sing to the Lord with chearful voice

〈♫〉
Him serue with feare, his praise forth tell, come ye before him and reioyce▪

div.head: BASSVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
AL people that on earth do dwel sing to the Lord with chearful voice

〈♫〉
Him serue with feare, his praise forth tell, come ye be- fore him & re-ioyce.

lg.l: The • ord ye know is God indeed:
without our aide he did vs make:
We are his flocke he doth vs feed,
and for his sheepe de doth vs take.
O enter then his gates with prayse,
approach with ioy his 〈◊〉 vnto:
Prayse, laud and blesse his name alwayes
for it is seemely so to doe.
For why? the Lord our God is good,
his mercy is for euer sure.
His truth at all times firmely stood,
and shall from age to age endure.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
IN God the Lord be glad and light, praise him throughout the earth:

〈♫〉
Serue him and come before his fight with singing and with mirth.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
IN God the Lord be glad and light, praise him, throughout the earth:

〈♫〉
Serue him and come before his sight with singing and with mirth.

div.head: TENOR, or Playnsong.
div.l:
☞ 〈♫〉
IN God the Lord be glad and light, praise him throughout the earth

〈♫〉
Serue him and come before his sight, with singing and with mirth

div.head: BASSVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
IN God the Lord be glad and light, praise him throughout the earth:

〈♫〉
Serue him and come before his sight with sin • ing and with mirth,

lg.l: Know that the Lord our God he is,
he did vs make and keepe:
Not we our selues: for we are his
owne folke and pasture sheep,
O goe into his gates alwayes,
giue thankes within the same.
Within his Courts set forth his prayse,
and laud his holy name.
For why? the goodnesse of the Lord
for euermore doth raigne:
From age to age throughout the world
his truth doth still remaine.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
I Mercy will and iudgement sing, O Lord God vnto thee: And
〈♫〉
wisely doe in perfect way vntill thou come to mee.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
I Mercy will and iudgement sing, O Lord God vnto thee: And
〈♫〉
wisely doe in perfect way vntill thou come to mee:

div.head: TENOR, or Playnsong.
div.p:
☞ 〈♫〉
I Mercy will and iudgement sing, O Lord God vnto thee: And
〈♫〉
wisely doe in perfect way vntill thou come to me.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
I Mercy will and iudgement sing O Lord God vnto thee: And,
〈♫〉
wisely doe in perfect way vntill thou come to mee.

lg.l: And in the midst of thy house walke
in purenesse of my spirit:
And I no kind of wicked thing
will set before my sight.
I hare their workes that fall away,
it shall not clea • e to me.
From me shall part the froward heart,
none euill will I see,
Him will I slay that slandereth
• us neighbour priu • ly:
The lofty heart I cannot beare,
nor him that looketh hie.
Mine eyes shall be on them within
the land that faithfull be:
In perfect way who walketh shall
be seruant vnto me.
I will no guilefull person haue
within my house to dwell:
And in my presence he shall not
remayne that lies doth tell.
Betimes I will destroy euen all
the wicked of the land:
That I may from Gods citie cut
the wicked workers hand.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
O Heare my prayer Lord, and let my cry come vnto thee:
〈♫〉
In time of trouble doe not hide thy face away from me.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
O Heare my prayer Lord, and let my cry come vn-to thee:
〈♫〉
In time of trouble doe not hide thy face away from mee.

div.head: TENOR, or Palynsong.
div.p:
☞ 〈♫〉
O Heare my prayer Lord, and let my cry come vnto thee:
☞ 〈♫〉
In time of trouble doe not hide thy face away from me.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
O Heare my prayer Lord, and let my cry come vnto thee:
〈♫〉
In time of trouble doe not hide thy face away from mee.

lg.l: Incline thine eares to me, make hast
to heare me when I call:
For as the smoake doth fade, so doe
my dayes consume and fall.
And as a harth my bones are burnt,
my heart is smitten dead:
And withers as the grasse, that I
forget to eate my bread.
By reason of my groning voice
my bones cleaue to my skin:
As Pellican in wildernesse
such case now am I in.
And as an Owle in desart is,
loe I am such a one:
I watch and as a Spa • row on
the house top am alone.
Loe daily in reproachfull wise
mine enemies doe me scorne:
And they that doe against me rage,
against me they haue sworne.
Surely with ashes as with bread
my hunger I haue fild:
And mingled haue my drinke with teares
that from mine e • es haue stild,
Because of thy displeasure Lord,
thy wrath and thy disdaine:
For thou hast lifted me aloft,
and cast me downe againe.
The dayes wherein I passe my life
are like the fleeting shade:
And I am withered like the grasse,
that soone away doth fade.
But thou O Lord for euer dost
remaine in steady place:
And thy remembrance euer doth,
abide from race to race.
Thou wilt a • ise, and mercy thou
to Sion wilt extend:
The time of mercy, now the time
foreset is come to end.
For euen in the stones thereof
thy seruants doe delight:
And on the dust thereof they h •• e
compassion in their sprite.
Then shall the heathen people feare
the Lords most holy Name:
And all the Kings on earth shall dread
thy glory and thy fame.
Then when the Lord, the mighty God
againe shall Sion reare:
And then when he most nobly in
his glory shall appeare.
To prayer of the desolate,
when he himselfe shall bend:
When he shall not disdaine vnto
their prayers to attend.
This shall be written for the age
that after shall succeed:
The people yet vncreated,
the Lords renowne shall spread.
For he from his high Sanctuary
hath looked downe below:
And out of heauen hath the Lord
beheld the earth also.
That of the mourning captiue he
might heare the wofull cry:
And that he might deliuer those
that damned are to die.
That they in Sion may declare
the Lords most holy Name:
And in Ierusalem set forth
the prayses of the same.
Then when the people of the Land,
and Kingdomes with accord
Shall be assembled for to doe
their seruice to the Lord.
My former force and strength he hath
abated in the way▪
And shorter he hath cut my dayes,
thus I therefore did say.
My God, in midst of all my dayes,
now take me not away:
Thy yeares endure eternally,
from age to age for aye.
Thou the foundation of the earth
before all times hast laid:
And Lord the heauens are the worke
which thine owne hand • haue made.
Yea, they shall perish and decay,
but thou shalt tarrie still:
And they shall all in time waxe old,
euen as a garment will.
Thou as a garment shalt them change▪
and changed shall they be:
But thou dost still abide the same,
thy yeares doe neuer flee.
The children of thy seruants shall
continually endure:
And in thy sight their happy seed
for euer shall stand sure.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
MY soule giue laud vnto the Lord, my sprite shall doe the same:
〈♫〉
And all the secrets of my heart praise ye his holy name. Giue thanks
〈♫〉
