to God for all his gifts, shew not thy selfe vn- kinde: And suffer not his
〈♫〉
benefits to slip out of thy minde.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
MY soule giue laud vnto the Lord, my sprite shall doe the same:
〈♫〉
And all the secrets of my heart praise ye his holy name. Giue thankes
〈♫〉
to God for all his gifts, shew not thy selfe vnkinde: And suffer not his
〈♫〉
benefits to slip out of thy minde.

div.head: TENOR or Playnsong.
div.p:
☞ 〈♫〉
MY soule giue laud vnto the Lord, my sprite shall doe the same:
☞ 〈♫〉
And all the secrets of my heart praise yee his holy name. Giue thankes
〈♫〉
to God for all his gifts, shew not thy selfe vnkind: And suffer not his
〈♫〉
benefits to slip out of thy minde.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
MY soule giue laud vnto the Lord, my sprite shall doe the same:
〈♫〉
And all the secrets of my heart prayse ye his holy name, Giue thankes
〈♫〉
to God for all his gifts, shew not thy selfe vnkinde: And suffer not his
〈♫〉
benefits to slip out of thy minde.

lg.l: That gaue thee pardon for thy faults,
and thee restorde againe:
For all thy weake and fraile disease,
and heal'd thee of thy paine.
That did redeeme thy life from death,
from which thou couldst not flee:
His mercy and compassion both
he did extend to thee.
That fild with goodnesse thy desire,
and did prolong thy youth:
Like as the Eagle casts her bill:
whereby her age renewth.
The Lord with iustice doth repay
all such as be opprest:
So that their sufferings and their wrongs
are turned to the best.
His wayes and his commandements
to Moses he did show:
His counsels and his valiant acts
the Israelites did know.
The Lord is kind and mercifull,
when sinners doe him grieu •
The slowest to conceiue a wrath,
and readiest to forgiue.
He chides vs not continually,
though we be full of strife:
Nor keeps our faults in memory
for all our sinfull life.
Nor yet according to our sinnes
the Lord doth vs regard:
Nor after our iniquities
he doth not vs reward.
But as the space is wondrous great
twixt earth and heauen aboue:
So is his goodnesse much more large
to them that doe him loue,
God doth remoue our sinnes from vs
and our offences all:
As farre as is the Sun rising
full distant from his fall.
And looke what pitty parents deer
vnto their children beare:
Like pitty beares the Lord to such,
as worship him in feare▪
The Lord that made vs knowes our shape,
our mould and fashion iust:
How weake and fraile our nature is,
and how we be but dust.
And how the time of mortall men
is like the withering hay▪
Or like the flower right faire in field,
that fadeth soone away.
Whose glosse and beauty stormy windes
doe vtterly disgrace:
And make that after their assaults,
such blossomes haue no place.
But yet the goodnesse of the Lord
with his shall euer stand:
Their childrens children doe receiue
his righteou snesse at hand.
I meane, which keepe his couenant
with all their whole desire:
And not forget to doe the thing
that he doth them require.
The heauens hie are made the seat
and footstoole of the Lord:
And by his power imperiall
he gouernes all the world.
Ye angels which are great in power▪
prayse ye and blesse the Lord:
Which to obey and doe his will
immediatly accord.
Ye noble hosts and ministers
cease not to laud him still:
Which ready are to execute
his pleasure and his will.
Yea, all his works in euery place,
prayse ye his holy name:
My heart, my mind, and eke my soule,
p •• yse ye also the same▪

div.head: CANTVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
MY soule praise the Lord, speake good of his name▪ O Lord our
〈♫〉
great God how dost thou appeare? So passing in glory, that great is thy
〈♫〉
fame: honour and maiestie in thee shine most cleare.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
MY soule praise the Lord, speake good of his name. O Lord our
〈♫〉
great God, how dost thou appeare? So passing in glory, that great is thy
〈♫〉
fame: honour and maiestie in thee shine most cleare.

div.head: TENOR, or Playnsong.
div.p:
☞ 〈♫〉
MY soule praise the Lord, speake good of his name. O Lord our
〈♫〉
great God, how dost thou appeare? So passing in glory, that great is thy
〈♫〉
fame honour and maiestie in thee shine most cleare.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
MY soule praise the Lord, speake good of his name▪ O Lord our
〈♫〉
great God, how dost thou appeare? So passing in glory, that great is thy
〈♫〉
fame: honour and maiestie in thee shine most cleare.

lg.l: With light as a robe
thou hast thee beclad
Whereby all the earth
thy greatnesse may see,
The heauen in such sort
thou also hast spread:
That it to a curtaine
compared may be.
His chamber beames lie
in the clouds full • ure:
Which as his chariot
are made him to beare.
And there with much swiftnesse
his course doth endure.
Vpon the wings riding
of wind in the ayre.
He maketh his spirits
as Heralds to goe:
And lightnings to serue,
We see also prest:
His will to accomplish,
they run too and fro:
To saue and consume things,
as seemeth him best.
He groundeth the earth,
so firmely and fast:
That it once to moue
none shall haue such power.
The deepe a faire couering,
for it made thou hast:
Which by his owne nature
the hils would deuoure.
But at thy rebuke
the waters doe •• ee
And so giue due place,
thy word to obey:
At thy voice of thunder
so fearefull they be:
That in their great raging
they hast soone away.
The mountaines full hie
they then vp ascend:
If thou doe but speake
thy word they fulfill:
So likewise the wa • es
most quickly descend,
Where thou them appointest▪
remaine they doe still.
Their bounds thou hast set,
how farre they shall run,
So as in their rage
not that passe they can:
For God hath appointed
they shall not returne,
The earth to destroy more
which made was for man▪
He sendeth the springs
to strong streames and lakes,
Which run doe full swift
among the huge hils.
Where both the wild Asses
their thirst oft times slakes,
And beasts of the mountaines
thereof drinke their fil • .
By these pleasant springs,
of fountaines full faire
The fowles of the ayre
abide shall and dwell:
When moued by nature
to hop here and there,
Among the greene branches
their songs shall excell.
The mountaines to moist
the clouds he doth vs • :
The earth with his workes
is wholly repleat:
So as the brute cartell
he doth not refuse:
But grasse doth prouide them,
and hearbe for mans meate▪
Yea, bread, wine and oyle
he made for mans sake,
His face to refresh
and heart to make strong:
The Cedars of Lyban
this great Lord did make:
Which trees he doth nourish
that grow vp so long.
In these may birds build,
and make there their nest▪
In fine trees the Storkes
remaine and abide:
The high hils are succou •
for wild Goats to rest:
And eke the rocks stony
for Conies to hide▪
The Moone then is set
her seasons to run,
The dayes from the nights
thereby to discerne:
And by the ascending
also of the Sunne.
The cold from heat •• way▪
thereby we doe learne.
When darknesse doth come
by Gods will and power,
Then creepe forth doe all
the beasts of the wood.
The Lions range roaring,
their prey to deuoure:
But yet it is thou Lord,
which giuest them food.
As soone as the Sun
is vp, they retire,
To 〈◊〉 their dens,
then are they full faine.
That man to his worke may,
as right doth require:
Till night come and call him
to take rest againe.
How sundry, O Lord,
are all thy workes found?
With wisdome full great
they are indeed wrought.
So that the whole world
of thy prayse doth sound,
And as for thy riches
they passe all mens thought.
So in the great Sea,
which large is and broad:
Where things that creep swarme▪
and beasts of each sort.
There both mighty ships saile,
and some lie at road:
The Whales huge and monstrous
there also doe sport.
All things on thee wait,
thou dost them relieue.
And thou in due time▪
full well dost them feed.
Now when it doth please thee,
the same so to giue:
They gather full gladly
those things which they need.
Thou openest thy hand
and they find such grace:
That they with good things
are filled we see:
But sore are they troubled
if thou turne thy face:
For if thou their breath take,
vile dust then they be.
Againe when thy spirit
from thee doth Proceed:
All things to appoint,
and what shall ensue.
Then are they created,
as thou hast decreed:
And dost by thy goodnesse
the dry earth renue.
The prayse of the Lord
for euer shall last:
Who may in his works,
by right well reioyce.
His looke can the earth make
to tremble full fast:
And likewise the mountaines,
to smoke at his voice.
To this Lord and God
sing will I alwayes:
So long as I liue
my God prayse will I:
Then am I most certaine
my words shall him please:
I will reioyce in him,
to call him will I cry.
The sinners, O Lord,
consume in thine ire:
And eke the peruerse
them root out with shame.
But as for my soule now,
let it still desire,
And say with the faithfull,
prayse ye the Lords name.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
GIue prayses vnto God the Lord, and call vpon his name:
〈♫〉
Among the people eke declare his workes to spread his fame. Sing
〈♫〉
yee vnto the Lord I say, and sing, vnto him praise: And talke of all the
〈♫〉
wondrous workes that he hath wrought alwayes.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
GIue prayses vnto God the Lord and call vpon his name:
〈♫〉
Among the people eke declare his works to spread his fame. Sing
〈♫〉
yee vnto the Lord I say, and sing vnto him praise: And talke of all the
〈♫〉
wondrous workes, that he hath wrought alwayes.

div.head: TENOR, or Plainsong.
div.p:
☞ 〈♫〉
GIue prayes vnto God the Lord, and call vpon his name:
〈♫〉
Among the people eke declare his works to spread his fame. Sing
〈♫〉
ye vnto the Lord I say, and sing vnto him praise▪ And talke of all the
〈♫〉
wondrous works, that he hath wrought alwayes.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
GIue prayses vnto God the Lord, and call vpon his name:
〈♫〉
Among the people eke declare his workes to spread his fame▪ Sing
〈♫〉
yee vnto the Lord I say, and sing vnto him praise: And talke of all the
〈♫〉
wondrous workes, that he hath wrought alwayes.

lg.l: Inhonour of his holy name,
reioyce with one accord:
〈◊〉 let the he •• ts also reioyce
of them that seeke the Lord:
Seeke ye the Lord and seeke the strength
of his eternal might:
And seek his face continually
and presence of his sight.
The wondrous works that he hath done
keepe still in mindfull heart:
N • let the iud • ements of his mouth
out of your minde depart.
Ye that of faithfull Abraham.
his seruant are the seed:
Ye his elect, the children that
of Iacob doe proceed.
For he, he onely is I say,
the mightie Lord our God:
And his most rightfull iudgements are
through all the earth abroad.
His promise and his couenant,
which he hath made to his:
He hath remembred euermore,
to thousands of degrees.
The couenant which he hath made
with Abraham long agoe:
And faithfull oath which he hath sworne
to Isaack also.
And did confirme the same for law,
that Iacob should obey:
And for eternall couenant
to Israell for aye.
When he thus said, loe I to you
all Canaan land will giue:
The lot of your inheritance,
wherein your seed shall liue.
Although their number at that time
did very small appeare:
Yea, very small, and in the land
they then but strangers were.
While yet they walkt from land to land,
without a sure aboad:
And while from sundry kingdomes they
did wander all abroad.
And wrong at no oppressors hand
he suffered them to take:
But euen the great and mightie Kings
reproued for their sake.
And thus he said, touch ye not those
that mine anointed be:
Ne doe the Prophets any harme
that doe pertaine to me.
He calde a dea • th vpon the land,
of bread he stroy'd the store:
But he against their time of need,
had sent a man before.
Euen Ioseph which had once been sol • ,
to liue a slaue in woe:
Whose feet they hurt in stockes, whose soule
the iron pierc't also.
Vntill the time came when his cause
was knowne apparantly:
The mightie word of God the Lord
his faultlesse truth did trie.
The King sent and deliuered him
from prison where he was:
The ruler of the people then
did freely let him passe.
And ouer all his house he made
him Lord to beare the sway:
And of his substance made him haue
the rule and all the stay.
That he might to his will instruct
the Princes of the land:
And wisdomes lo • e his ancient men
might teach to vnderstand:
Then into the Egyptian land
came Israel also.
And Iacob in the land of Ham,
did liue a stranger tho.
His people he exc • edingly
in number made to flow:
And ouer all their enemies
in strength he made them grow.
Whose heart he turn'd that they with hate
his people did intreat:
And did his seruants wrongfully
abuse, with false deceit.
His faithfull seruant Moses then,
and Aaron whom he chose:
He did command to goe to them,
his message to disclose.
The wondrous message of hi • signes
amongst them they did shew:
And wonders in the land of Ham
then did they worke also.
Darknesse he sent, and made it darke,
in stead of brighter day:
And vnto his commission
they did not disobey.
He turn'd their waters into bloud,
he did their fishes slay:
Their land brought frogges, euen in the place
where their King Pharaoh lay.
He sp • ke, and at his voice there came
great swannes of noysome flies:
And all the quarters of their land
were fild with crawling lice.
He gaue them cold and stony haile
in stead of milder raine:
And fiery flames within their land,
he sent vnto their paine.
He smote the vines and all the trees
whereon their figs did grow:
And all the trees within their coasts
downe did he ouerthrow.
He snake, then Caterpillers did
and Grashoppers abound:
Which eat the grasse in all their land
and fruit of all their ground.
The first begotten in the land
eke daily did he • inite:
Yea, the beginning and first fruit
of all their strength and might.
With gold and siluer he them brought
from Egypt land to passe:
And in the number of the Tribes
no feeble one there was.
Egypt was glad and ioyfull then,
when they did thence depart:
For terrour and the feare of them
was fallen vpon their heart.
To shroude them from the parching heate
a cloud he did display:
And fire he sent to giue them light,
when night had hid the day.
They asked and he caused Quailes
to raine at their request:
And fully with the bread of heauen
their hunger he represt.
He opened then the stony rockes
and water gushed out▪
And in the dry and parched ground •
like riuers ran about.
For of his holy couenant
aye mindfull was he tho:
Which to his seruant Abraham
he plighted long agoe.
He brought his people forth with mi • th
and his elect with ioy:
Out of the cruell land where they
had liu'd in great annoy.
And of the heathen men he gaue
to them the fruitfull land:
The labours of the people eke
they tooke into theer hand.
That they his holy statutes might
obserue for euermore:
And faithfully obay his lawes,
praise ye the Lord therefore.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
PRayse ye the Lord, for he is good, his mercy dures for aye:
〈♫〉
Who can expresse his noble acts, or all his praise display?

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
PRayse ye the Lord, for he is good, his mercy dures for aye▪
〈♫〉
Who can expresse his noble acts, or all his praise display?

div.head: TENOR, or Playnsong.
div.p:
☞ 〈♫〉
PRayse yee the Lord, for he is good, his mercy dures for aye:
☞ 〈♫〉
Who can expresse his noble acts, or all his praise display?

div.head: BASSVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
PRayse yee the Lord, for he is good, his mercy dures for aye:
〈♫〉
Who can expresse his noble acts, or all his praise display?

lg.l: They blessed are that iudgement keepe,
and iustly doe alway:
With fauour of thy people Lord,
remember me I pray,
And with thy sauing health, O Lord,
vouchsafe to visit me:
That I the great felicitie
of thine elect may see.
And with thy peoples ioy I may
a ioyfull mind possesse:
And may with thine inheritance
a glorying heart expresse.
Both we and eke our fathers all
haue sinned euery one▪
We haue committed wickednesse,
and lewdly we haue done.
The wonders great which thou O Lord,
hast done in Egypt land:
Our fathers though they saw them all
yet did not vnderstand.
Nor yet thy mercies multieude
did keepe in thankful mind:
But at the sea▪ yea, the red sea,
rehelled most vnkind.
Neuerthelesse he saued them
for honour of his name:
That he might make his power knowne
and spread abroad his fame.
The red sea he did then rebuke,
and forthwith it was dride:
And as in wildernesse, so through
the deepe he did them guide.
He sau'd them from the cruell hand
of their despitefull foe:
And from the enemies hand he did
de •• uer them also.
The Waters their oppressous whelmd,
not one was left aliue:
Then they beleeu'd his words & praise
in song they did him giue.
But by and by vnthankfully
his words they cleane forgat:
And for his counsell and his la ••
they did neglect to waite.
But • usted in the wildernesse
with fond and greedie lust:
And in the desart tempted God,
the stay of all their trust.
And then their wanton minds defire
he suffered them to haue:
But wasting leannes • e therewithall
into their soules he gaue.
Then when they lodged in their tent,
at Moses they did g • utch:
Aaron the holy of the Lord
so did they enuy much.
Therefore the earth did open wide,
and Dathan did deuoure:
And all Abirams company
did couer in that houre.
In their assemblies kindled was
the hot consuming fire:
And wasting flame did the • burne vp
the wicked in his ire.
Vpon the hill of Horeb they
an Idoll ca • fe did frame:
And there the molten Image they
did worship of the same.
Into the likenesse of a calfe
that feedeth on the grasse:
Thus they their glory turnde, and all
their honour did deface.
And God their onely Sauiour
vnkindly they forgot:
Which many great and mightie thing •
in Egypr land had wrought.
And in the land of Ham for them
most wondrous things had done:
And by the red sea dreadfull things
performed long agone.
Therefore for their so shewing them
forgetfull and vnkind,
To bring destruction on them all
he purposde in his minde.
Had not his chosen Moses stood
before him in the breake,
To turne his wrath lest he on them
with slaughter should him wreake.
They did despise the pleasant land
that he behight to giue:
Yea, and the words that he had spoke
they did no whit beleeue.
But in their tents with grudging heart,
they wickediy repinde:
Nor to the voice of God the Lord
they gaue an hearkening mind,
Therefore against them lifted he
his strong reuenging hand
Them to destroy in wildernesse,
ere they should see the land.
And to destroy their seed among
the Nations with his rod:
And through the countries of the world
to scatter them abroad.
To Baal Peor then they did
adioyne themselues also:
And ate the offerings of the dead,
so they forsooke him tho.
Thus with their owne inuentions
his wrath they did prouoke:
And in his so inkindled wrath,
the plague vpon them broke,
But Phine • s stood vp with zeale
the sinners vile to slay:
And iudgement he did execute,
and then the plague did stay.
It was imputed vnto him
for righteousnesse that day:
And from thence forth so counted is
from race to race for aye.
At wate • s' eke of Meribah
they did him a • gry make:
Yea, so farie forth that Moses was
then punisht for their sake.
Because they vext his spirit so sore,
that in impatient heat.
His lips spake vnaduisedly,
his feruour was so great.
Nor as the Lord commanded them
they • lue the people tho.
But were among the heathen mixt,
and learn'd their workes also.
And did their Idols serue, which were
their ruine and decay:
To fiends their sons and daughters they
did offer vp and slay:
Yea, with vnkindly murdering knife
the guiltlesse bloud they spilt:
Yea, their owne sons & daughters bloud
without all cause of guilt.
Whom they to Canaan Idols then
offred with wicked hand:
And so with bloud of innocents
defiled was their land.
Thus were they stained with the worke▪
of their owne filthy way:
And with their owne inuentions
a whoring they did stray.
Therefore against his people was
the Lords wrath kindled sore:
And euen his owne inheritance
therefore he did abhorre▪
Into the hands of heathen men
he gaue them for a pray:
And made their foes their Lords, whom they
w • r • forced to obey.
Yea, and their hatefull enemie
opprest them in the la • d:
And they were humbly made to stoope
as subiect to their hand:
Full oftentimes from thrall had hee
d • liuered them before:
〈◊〉 with their counsels they to wrath
prouokt him euermore.
Therefore they by their wickednesse
were brought full low to he:
Yet when he saw them in distresse,
he hea • kned to their cry.
He cald to minde his couenant,
which he them had swore:
And by his mercies multitude,
repented him therefore.
And fauour he them made to find
before the sight of those
That led them captiue from their land,
when earst they were their foes.
Saue vs O Lord that art our God,
saue vs O Lord we pray:
And from among the heathen folke
Lord gather vs away.
That we may spread the noble prayse
of thy most holy name:
That we may glory in rhy prayse,
and sounding of rhy fame.
The Lord the God of Israel
be blest for euermore:
Let all the people say, Amen:
prayse ye the Lord therefore.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.p:
☞ 〈♫〉
GIue thanks vnto the Lord our God, for gracious is he: And
〈♫〉
that his mercy hath no end all mortall men may see.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
GIue thanks vnto the Lord our God, for gracious is hee: And
〈♫〉
that his mercy hath no end all mortall men may see.

div.head: TENOR, or Playnsong.
div.p:
〈♫〉
GIue thanks vnto the Lord our God, for gracious is hee: And
〈♫〉
that his mercy hath no end all mortall men may see.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
GIue thanks vnto the Lord our God, for gracious is he: And
〈♫〉
that his mercy hath no end all mortall men may see.

lg.l: Such as the Lord redeemed hath,
with thanks should prayse his name:
And shew how they from foes were freed
and how he wrought the same.
He gathered them forth of land •
that lay so farre about:
From East to West, from North to South,
his hand did finde them out.
They wandered in the wildernesse,
and strayed from the way:
And found no C • tie where to dwell,
that serue might for their stay.
Whose thirst and hunger was so great
in those desarts so voyde:
That faintnesse did them sore assault▪
and eke their soule annoid.
Then did they cry in their distresse
vnto the Lord for ayde:
Who did remoue their troublous state
according as they prayed.
And by that way that was most right
he led them like a guide:
That they might to a citie goe,
and there also abide.
Let men therefore before the Lord
confesse his kindnesse then:
And shew his wonders that he doth
before the sonnes of men.
For he the empty soule sustaind,
whom thirst had made to fa • nt:
The hungry soule with goodnesse fed,
and did them eke acquaint.
Such as doe dwell in darknesse deep,
where they of death doe wa • te:
Fast bound to tast such troublous stormes
as iron chaines doe threat.
For they against the Lords owne words,
they sought for to rebell:
Esteeming light his counsels hie,
which doe so farre excell.
But when he humbled them full low,
then they fell downe with griefe:
And none was found so much to help,
whereby to get reliefe.
Then did they cry in their distresse,
vnto the Lord for aide:
Who did remoue their troublous state,
according as they praide.
For he from darknes out them brought
and from deaths dreadfull shade:
Bursting with force the iron bands,
which did before them lade.
Let men therefore before the Lord
confesse his kindnesse then:
And shew his wonders that he doth
before the sonnes of men.
For he threw downe the gates of brasse
and brake them with strong hand:
The iron bars he smote in two,
nothing could him withstand.
The foolish folke great plagues doe feele,
and cannot from them wend:
But heape vp moe to those they haue,
because they doe offend.
Their soules so much did loath all meat
that none they could abide
Whereby death had them almost caught,
as they full truly tride,
Then d • d they cry in their distresse
vnto the Lord for aide:
Who did remoue their troublous state,
according as they praide.
For he then sent to them his word,
which health did soone restore:
And brought them from those dangers deepe
wherein they were before.
Let men therefore before the Lord,
confesse his kindnesse then:
And shew the wonders that he doth
before the sonnes of men.
And let them offer sacrifice
with thankes and also feare:
And speake of all his wondrous workes,
with glad and ioyfull cheere.
Such as in ships or brittle Barks,
into the Seas descend:
Their merchandise through fearefull floud;
to compasse and to end.
These men are forced to behold
the Lords workes what they be:
And in the dangerous deepe the same
most meruailous they see.
For at his word the stormy winde
ariseth in a rage:
And stirreth vp the singes so
as nought can them asswage.
Then are they lifted vp so hie,
the clouds they seeme to gaine:
And plunging downe the depth vntill
their soules consume with paine.
And like a drunkard to and fro,
now here, now there they reele:
As men with feare, of wit bereft,
or had of sence no feele.
Then did they cry in their distresse
vnto the Lord for aide:
Who did remoue their troublous state
according as they prayed.
For with his wrath the Lord doth make
the sturdie stormes to cease:
So that the great waues from their • age
are brought to rest and peace.
Then are men glad when rest is come,
which they so much doe craue:
And are by him in hauen brought▪
which they so faine would haue.
Let men therefore before the Lord
confesse his kindnesse then:
And shew the wonders that he doth
before the sonnes of men.
Let them in presence of the folke
with praise extoll his name:
And where the Elders doe conuent,
let them there doe the same.
For running flouds to dry desart,
he doth oft change and turne:
And drieth vp as it were dust
the springing well and bourne.
A fruitfull land with ple • sure deckt
full barraine he doth make:
When on their sins which dwell therein
he doth iust vengeance take.
Againe the wildernesse full rude,
he maketh fruit to beare:
With pleasant springs of waters cleere
though none before were.
Wherein such hungry soules are set,
as he doth freely chuse:
That they a Citie may them build,
to dwell in for their vse.
That they may sow their pleasant land,
and Vineyards also plant:
To yeeld them fruit of such increase,
as none may seeme to want.
They multiply exceedingly,
the Lord doth blesse them so:
Who doth also their brute beasts make,
by numbers great to grow.
But when the faithfull are low brought
by the oppressors stout:
And minish doe through many plagues,
that compasse them about.
Then doth he Princes bring to shame
which did them sore oppresse:
And likewise caused them to er • e,
within the wildernesse.
But yet the poore he raiseth vp,
out of his troubles deepe:
And oft times doth his traine augment,
much like a flocke of sheepe.
The righteous shall behold this sight,
and also much reioyce▪
Whereas the wicked and peruerse,
with griefe shall stop their voice.
But who is wise that now full well
he may these things record?
For certainly such shall perceiue
the kindnesse of the Lord.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
O God my heart prepared is, and eke my tongue is so:

〈♫〉
I will aduance my voyce in song, and giuing praise al- so.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
O God my heart prepared is, and eke my tongue is so,

〈♫〉
I will aduance my voyce in song, and giuing praise also.

div.head: TENOR or Playnsong.
div.l:
☞ 〈♫〉
O God my heart prepared is, and eke my tongue is so:

〈♫〉
I will aduance my voyce in song, and giuing prayse al-so.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
O God my heart prepared is and eke my tongue is so

〈♫〉
I will aduance my voyce in song, and giuing praise also.

lg.l: Awake my Violl and my Harpe,
sweet melody to make:
And in the morning I my selfe
right early will awake.
By me among the people Lord,
still praysed shalt thou be:
And I among the heathen folke
will sing O Lord to thee.
Because thy mercy Lord is great
aboue the heauens hie:
And eke thy truth doth • each the clouds
within the lofty skie.
Aboue the starry heauens hiet
exalt thy selfe O God:
And Lord display vpon the earth
thy glory all abroad.
That thy deerely beloued may
be set at libertie:
Helpe O my God with thy right hand,
and hearken vnto me.
God in his holinesse hath spoke,
wherefore my ioyes abound:
S • chem I will diuide, and mete
the vale of Succoth ground.
And Gilead shall be mine owne,
Manasses mine shall be:
My head strength Ephraim, and law
shall Iuda giue for me.
Moab my wash-pot, and my shoe
on Edom will I throw:
Vpon the land of Palestine,
in triumph will I goe.
Who shall into the Citie strong
be guide to conduct me:
Or how by whom to Egypt land,
conueyed shall I be?
Is it not thou O God which late
hast vs forgotten quite?
And thou O Lord which with our hoast
didst not goe forth to fight?
Giue vs O Lord thy sauing aide,
when troubles doe assaile:
For all the helpe of men is vaine,
and can no whit auaile.
Through God we shall doe valiant acts▪
and worthy of renowne:
He shall subdue our enemies,
yea, he shall tread them downe.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
IN speechlesse silence doe not hold, O God, thy tongue alwayes:

〈♫〉
O God, euen thou (I say, that art the God of all my prayse▪

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
IN speechlesse silence doe not hold, O God, thy tongue alwayes:

〈♫〉
O God, euen thou (I say) that art the God of all my praise.

div.head: TENOR or Playnsong.
div.l:
☞ 〈♫〉
IN speechlesse silence doe not hold, O God▪ thy tongue alwayes

〈♫〉
O God, euen thou (I say) that art the God of all my praise.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
IN speechlesse silence doe not hold, O God, thy tongue alwayes:

〈♫〉
O God, euen thou (I say) that art the God of all my praise.

lg.l: The wicked tongue and guilefull mouth,
on me disclosed be:
And they with false and lying tongue
haue spoken vnto me.
They did beset me round about
with words of hatefull spight:
Without all cause of my desert
against me they did fight.
For my good will they were my foe • ,
but then gan I to pray:
My good with ill, my f • iendlinesse
with hate they did repay.
Set thou the wicked ouer him,
to haue the vpper hand:
At his right hand eke suffer thou
his hatefull • oe to stand.
When he is iudged, let hi • then
conde • ned be therein▪
And let the prayer that he make,
be turned into sinne.
Few be his dayes his charge also
let thou another take:
His children let be f • therlesse,
his wife a widdow make.
Let his off-spring be vagabond • ,
to beg and seeke their bread:
Wandring out of the wasted place
where earst they haue beene fed.
Let couetous extortioners
catch all his goods and store:
And let the strangers spoile the 〈◊〉
of 〈◊〉 his toyle before.
Let there be none to pittie him▪
let there be none at all
That on his children fathe • less •
will let their mercie fall.
And so let his posteritie
for euer be destroyd:
Thei • name ou • blotted in the age
that after shall succ • ed.
Let not his fathers wickednesse
from Gods remembra • ce fall
And let thou not his • others sinne
be done away at all.
But in the p • esence of the Lord
let them remaine for aye
That from the earth their memory
he may cut cleane away.
Sith mercy he forgat to shew,
but did pursue with spight:
The troubled ma • , and thought to stay
the wofull hearted wight.
As he did cursing loue, it shall
betide vnto him so:
And as he did not blessing lo • e,
it shall be farie him f • o.
As he with cursing clad himselfe,
so it like water shall
Into his bowels, and like o • le
into his bones befall.
As garments let it be to him,
to couer him for aye.
And as a girdle wherewith he
shall girded be alway.
Loe, let this s • me be from the Lord
the gu •• don of my foe:
Yea, and of those that euill speak •
against my soule also.
But thou O Lord that art my God,
deale thou I say with me▪
After thy name deliuer me,
for good thy mercies be.
Because in depth of great distresse,
I needy am and poore:
And eke within my pained brest
my heart is wounded sore.
Euen so doe I depart away,
as doth declining shade:
And as the Grashopper, so I
am shaken off and fade▪
With fasting long from needfull food
enfeebled are my knees:
And all her fatnesse hath my 〈◊〉
enforced beene to leese.
And I also a vi • e reproach,
to them was made to be:
And they that did vpon me looke,
did shake their heads at me.
But thou O Lord that a • t my God
mine aide and succour be:
According to thy mercie Lord
saue and deliuer me.
And they shall know there by that this.
Lord is thy mighty hand:
And that thou, thou hast done 〈◊〉 Lord,
so shall they vnderstand.
Although they curse with spite, yet thou.
shalt blesse with louing voice:
They shall arise and come to shame,
thy seruant shall reioyce.
Let them be clothed all with shame▪
that enemies are to me:
And with confusion as a cloake
eke couered let them be.
But greatly I will with my mouth
giu • thankes vnto the Lord:
And I among the multitude
his praises will record.
For he with helpe at his right hand.
will stand the poore man by:
To saue him from the man that would
• ondemne his soule to die

div.head: CANTVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
THE Lord did say vnto my Lord; sit thou on my right hand:

〈♫〉
Till I haue made thy foes a stoole, whereon thy feet may stand.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
THE Lord did say vnto my Lord, sit thou on my right hand:

〈♫〉
Till I haue made thy foes a stoole, whereon thy feet shall stand.

div.head: TENOR, or Playnsong.
div.l:
☞ 〈♫〉
THE Lord did say vnto my Lord, sit thou on my right hand:

〈♫〉
Till I haue made thy foes a stoole, whereon thy feete may stand.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
THE Lord did say vnto my Lord, sit thou on my right hand:

〈♫〉
Till I haue made thy foes a stoole, whereon thy feete shall stand.

lg.l: The Lord shall out of Sion send
the scepter of thy might:
Amid thy mortall foes be thou,
the ruler in their sight.
And in the day on which thy raigne
and power they shall see:
Then hereby free-will offerings shall
the pople offer thee.
Yea, with an holy worshipping
then shall they offer all:
Thy birth dew is the dew that doth
from wombe of morning fall.
The Lord hath sworne and neuer will
repent what he doth say:
By the order of Melchisedech,
thou art a Priest for aye.
The Lord thy God on thy right hand
that standth for thy stay:
Shall wound for thee the stately Kings,
vpon his wrathfull day.
The heathen he shall iudge and fill
the place with bodies dead:
And ouer diuers countries shall
in sunder smite the head.
And he shall drinke out of the brooke,
that runneth in the way:
Therefore he shall lift vp on hie
his royall head that day.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
WIth heart I doe accord to praise and laud the Lord, in pre-
〈♫〉
sence of the iust: For great his workes are found, to search them such
〈♫〉
are bound, as doe him loue and trust▪ His workes are glorious, also his
〈♫〉
righteousnesse it doth endure for e- uer. His wondrous workes he would
〈♫〉
we still remember should, his mercy fayleth ne- uer.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
WIth heart I doe accord to praise and laud the Lord, in pre-
〈♫〉
sence of the iust: For great his workes are found, to search them such
〈♫〉
are bound, as doe him loue and trust. His workes are glorious also his
〈♫〉
righteousnesse it doth endure for euer. His wondrous works he • would
〈♫〉
we still remember should, his mercy faileth ne- uer.

div.head: TENOR, or Faburden.
div.p:
〈♫〉
WIth heart I doe accord to praise and laud the Lord▪ in pre-
〈♫〉
sence of the iust: For great his works are found, to search them such
〈♫〉
are bound, as doe him loue and trust, His workes are glorious, also his
☞ 〈♫〉
righteousnesse it doth endure for euer. His wondrous works he would
〈♫〉
we still remember should, his mercy faileth neuer.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
WIth heart I doe accord, to prayse and laud the Lord, in pre-
〈♫〉
sence of the iust: For great his works are found, to search them such
〈♫〉
are bound, as doe him loue and trust, His workes are glorious, also his
righteousnesse it doth endure for euer. His wondrous workes hee would
〈♫〉
we still remember should, his mer- cy faileth neuer.

lg.l: Such as to him loue beare
A portion full faire
He hath vp for them laid▪
For this they shall well find
He will them haue in minde▪
And keepe them as he said.
For he did not disdaine
His workes to shew them plaine
By lightnings and by thunders:
When he the heathens land
Did giue into their hand
Where they beheld his wonders.
Of all his workes ensu • th
Both iudgement▪ right and truth▪
whereto his statutes tend.
They are decreed sure,
For euer to endure,
Which equitie doth end:
Redemption he gaue
His people for to saue.
And hath also required
His promise not to faile,
But alwayes to preu • le:
His holy name be feared.
Who so with, heart full faine
True wisedome would attaine,
The Lord feare and obey:
Such as his lawes doe keepe
Shall knowledge haue full deepe:
His prayse shall last for aye.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
THe man is blest that God doth feare, And that his lawe; doth
〈♫〉
loue indeed: His seed on earth God will vpreare, And blesse such as from him
〈♫〉
proceed: His house with good he will fulfill: His righteousnes endure shal still.

div.head: Psalme 103.
MEDIVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
THe man is blest that God doth feare, And that his lawes doth
〈♫〉
loue indeed: His seed on earth God will vpreare, And blesse such as from him
〈♫〉
proceed: His house with good he will fulfill: His righteousnes endure shall still.

div.head: TENOR, or Farburden.
div.p:
☞ 〈♫〉
THe man is blest that God doth feare, And that his lawes doth
〈♫〉
loue indeed: His seed on earth God will vpreare, And blesse such as from him
〈♫〉
proceed: His house with good he will fulfill: His righteousnes endure shall still.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
THe man is blest that God doth feare. And that his lawes doth
〈♫〉
loue indeed: His seed on earth God will vpreare, And blesse such as from him
〈♫〉
proceed: His house with good he will fulfill: His righteousnes endure shall still.

lg.l: Vnto the righteous doth arise
In trouble ioy, in darknesse light:
Compassion is in his eyes:
And mercy alwayes in his sight.
Yea, pittie moueth such to • end.
He doth by iudgement things expend,
And surely such shall neuer faile,
For in remembrance had is he,
No tydings ill can make him quaile.
Who in the Lord sure hope doth see.
His heart is firme, his feare is past,
For he shall see his foes downe cast.
He did well for the poore prouide,
His righteousnesse shall still remaine:
And his estate with praise abide,
Though that the wicked man disdaine.
Yea, gnash his teeth thereat shall he
And so consume his state to see.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
YE children which do serue the Lord, prayse ye his name with one ac-
〈♫〉
cord: Yea, blessed be alwayes his name, who from the rising of the Sun,
〈♫〉
till it returne where it begun, is to be praised with great fame, The Lord
〈♫〉
all people doth surmount, as for his glory we may count, aboue the hea-
〈♫〉
uens hie to be, with God the Lord who may compare, whose dwellings
〈♫〉
in the heauens are? of such great power and force is he.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
YE children which do serue the Lord, prayse ye his name with one ac-
〈♫〉
cord: Yea, blessed, be alwayes his name, who from the rising of the Sun,
〈♫〉
till it returne where it begun, is to be praised with great fame. The Lord
〈♫〉
all people doth surmount, as for his glory we may count, aboue the hea-
〈♫〉
uens hie to be, with God the Lord, who may compare, whose dwellings
〈♫〉
in the heauens are? of such great power and force is he.

div.head: TENOR, or Playnsong.
div.p:
☞ 〈♫〉
YE children which doe serue the Lord, praise ye his name with one ac-
〈♫〉
cord: Yea, blessed be alwayes his name, who from the rising of the Sun
〈♫〉
till it returne where it begun, is to be praised with great fame. The Lord
〈♫〉
all people doth surmount, as for his glory we may count, aboue the hea-
〈♫〉
uens hie to be, with God the Lord who may compare, whose dwellings in
〈♫〉
the heauens are? of such great power and force is he?

div.head: BASSVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
YE children which do serue the Lord, praise ye his name with one ac-
〈♫〉
cord, Yea, blessed be alwayes his name, who from the rising of the Sun,
〈♫〉
till it returne where it begun, is to be praised with great fame. The Lord
〈♫〉
all people doth surmount, as for his glory we may count, a-boue the
〈♫〉
heauens hie to be, with God the Lord who may compare, whose dwellings
〈♫〉
in the heauens are? of such great power and force is hee.

lg.l: He doth abase himselfe we know,
Things to behold both here below,
And also in hea • en aboue,
The needy out of dust to draw,
And eke the poore which helpe none sa •
His onely marcie did him • ous
And so him s • t in high degree,
With Princes of great dignitie,
That rule his people with great fame.
The barren he doth make to beare,
And with great ioy her fruit to reare,
Therefore praise yee his holy Name.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
WHen Israel by Gods addresse, from Pharaohs land was bent:

〈♫〉
And Iacobs house the strangers left, and in the same traine went.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
WHen Israel by Gods addresse, from Pharaohs land was bent:

〈♫〉
And Iacobs house the strangers left, and in the same traine went.

div.head: TENOR, or Playnsong.
div.l:
☞ 〈♫〉
WHen Israel by Gods addresse, from Pharaohs land was bent:

〈♫〉
And Iacobs house the strangers left, and in the same traine went.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
WHen Israel by Gods addresse, from Pharaohs land was bent:

〈♫〉
And Iacobs house the strangers left, and in the same traine went.

lg.l: In Iud • God his glory shew'd,
his holinesse most bright:
So did the Israetites declare
his kingdome, power, and might.
The sea i • saw, and sodainly
as all amaz'd did •• ie
The roa • ing st • eames of Iordans ffoud
reculed backwardly.
As Rams afraid the mountaines skipt,
their strength did them forsake:
And as the silly trembling Lambs
their tops did beate and shake.
What aild thee sea as all amaz'd,
so sudunly to flie:
Ye rowling waues of Iordans floud,
why ran ye backwardly?
Why shooke ye hils as Rams afraid?
why did your strength so shake?
Why did your tops as trembling Lambs
for feare quiuer and quake 〈◊〉
O earth confesse thy soueraigne Lord,
and dread his mighty hand:
Before the face of Iacobs God
feare ye both sea and land
I meane the God which from hard rocks
doth cause maine flouds appeare:
And from the stony flint did make
gush out the fountaines cleare.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
NOt vn-to vs Lord, not to vs, but to thy name giue praise:

〈♫〉
Both for thy mercy and thy truth, that are in thee alwayes.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
NOt vnto vs Lord, not to vs, but to thy name giue prayse:

〈♫〉
Both for thy mercy and thy truth, that are in thee alwayes.

div.head: TENOR or Playnsong.
div.l:
☞ 〈♫〉
NOt vnto vs Lord, not to vs, but to thy name giue prayse,

〈♫〉
Both for thy mercie and thy truth, that are in thee alwayes.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
NOt vnto vs Lord, not to vs, but to thy name giue prayse,

〈♫〉
Both for thy mercy and thy truth, that are in thee alwayes.

lg.l: Why shall the heathen scorners say,
where is their God become?
Our God in heauen is, and what
he will, that hath he done.
Their Idols siluer are and gold,
workes of mens hands they be:
They haue a mouth, and do not speake,
and eyes and doe not see
An • they haue eares • oyn'd to their heads,
and doe not heare at all:
Aud noses eke they formed haue,
and doe not smell withall.
And hands they haue and handle not▪
and feet and doe not goe:
A throat they haue, yet through the same,
they make no sound to blow.
Those that make them, are like to th • n
and those whose trust they be:
O Israel trust in the Lord,
their help and shield is he.
O Aarons house trust in the Lord
their help and shield is he:
Trust ye the Lord that feare the Lord
their helpe and shield is he:
The Lord hath mindfull beene of vs,
and will vs blesse also:
Oh Israels and on Aarons house
his blessing he will shew.
Them that be fearers of the Lord,
the Lord will saue them all:
Euen he will blesse them euery one,
the great and eke the small.
To you (I say) the hung Lord,
will multiply his grace:
To you, and to the children that
shall follow of your race,
Ye are the blessed of the Lord,
euen of the Lord I say,
Which both the heauen and the earth
hath made and set in stay.
The heauens, yea, the heauens hie,
belong vnto the Lord:
The earth vnto the sonnes of men
he gaue of free accord.
They that be dead, doe not with praise
set forth the Lords renowne,
Nor any that into the place
of silence doe goe downe.
But we will praise the Lord our God
from henceforth and for aye:
Sound ye the prayses of the Lord,
prayse yee the Lord I say.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
I Loue the Lord, because my voyce and prayer heard hath hee.

〈♫〉
When in my dayes I cald on him, he bow'd' his eare to me.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
I Loue the Lord, because my voyce and prayer heard hath he

〈♫〉
When in my dayes I cald on him, he bow'd his eare to me.

div.head: TENOR, or Playnsong.
div.l:
☞ 〈♫〉
I Loue the Lord because my voyce and prayer heard hath hee:

〈♫〉
When in my dayes I cald on him, he bow'd his eare to me.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
I Loue the Lord because my voyce and prayer heard hath hee:

〈♫〉
When in my dayes I cald on him, he bow'd his eare to mee.

lg.l: Euen when the snares of cruell death
about beset me round:
When paines of hell me caught, and when
I woe and sorrow found.
Vpon the name of God the Lord,
then did I call and say:
Deliuer thou my soule O Lord,
I doe thee humbly pray.
The Lord is very mercifull,
and iust he is also:
And in our God compassion,
doth plentifully flow.
The Lord in safetie doth preserue,
all those that simple be:
I was in wofull miserie,
and he relieued me.
And now my soule sith thou art saf • ,
returne vnto thy rest:
For largely loe the Lord to thee,
his bountie hath exprest.
Because thou hast deliuered,
my soule from deadly thrall:
My moistned eyne from mournfull teares
my sliding feete from fall.
Before the Lord I in the land
of life will walke therfore:
I did beleeue therefore I spake,
for I was troubled sore.
I said in my distresse and feare,
that all men lyers be:
What shall I pay the Lord for all
his benefits to me?
The wholsome cup of sauing health
I thankefully will take:
And on the Lords name I will call,
when I my prayer make.
I to the Lord will pay the vowes,
that I haue him behight:
Yea, euen at this present time,
in all the peoples sight.
Right deare and precious in his sight,
the Lord doth aye esteeme
The death of all his holy ones,
what euer men doe deeme.
Thy seruant Lord thy seruant loe,
I doe my selfe confesse:
Sonne of thy handmaid, thou hast broke
the bonds of my d • stresse.
And I will offer vp to thee
a sacrifice of prayse:
And I will call vpon the name
of God the Lord alwayes.
I to the Lord will pay the vowes,
that I haue him behight:
Yea, euen at this present time,
in all the peoples sight.
Yea, in the courts of Gods own house,
and in the midst of thee,
O thou Ierusalem I say,
wherefore the Lord praise yee.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
O All ye nations of the world, praise ye the Lord alwayes: And
〈♫〉
all ye people euery where set forth his noble praise.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
O All ye nations of the world, prayse ye the Lord alwayes: And
〈♫〉
all ye people euery where, set forth his noble prayse.

div.head: TENOR, or Playnsong.
div.p:
☞ 〈♫〉
O All ye nations of the world, praise ye the Lord alwayes: And
☞ 〈♫〉
all ye people euery where set forth his noble praise.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
O All ye nations of the world, prayse ye the Lord alwayes: And
〈♫〉
all ye people euery where set forth his noble praise.

lg.l: For great his kindnesse is to vs, his truth endures for aye:

div.head: CANTVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
O Giue ye thanks vnto the Lord, for gracious is hee: Because
〈♫〉
his mercy doth endure for euer towards thee.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
O Giue ye thanks vnto the Lord, for gracious is he: Because
〈♫〉
his mercy doth en- dure for euer towards thee.

div.head: TENOR or Playnsong.
div.p:
☞ 〈♫〉
O Giue ye thanks vnto the Lord, for gracious is hee: Because
〈♫〉
his mercy doth endure for euer towards thee.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
O Giue ye thankes vnto the Lord, for gracious is he: Because
〈♫〉
his mercy doth endure for euer towards thee.

lg.l: Let Israel confesse and say,
his mercy dures for aye
Now let the house of Aaron say
his mercy dures for aye.
Let all that feare the Lord our God,
euen now confesse and say,
The mercy of the Lord our God
endureth still for aye.
In trouble and in heauinesse
vnto the Lord I cry'd:
Which louingly heard me at large,
my sute was not deuide.
The Lord himselfe is on my side,
I will not stand in doubt,
Nor feare what man can doe to me,
when God stands me about.
The Lord doth take my pa • t with them
that helpe to succour me:
Therefore I shall see my desire,
vpon mine enemie.
Better it is to trust in God,
then in mans mortall seed:
Or to put confidence in Kings,
or Princes in their need:
All nations haue enclosed me
and compassed me round:
But in the name of God will I
mine enemies confound.
They kept me in on euery side,
they kept me in I say:
But through the Lords most mighty name
I shall worke their decay.
They came about me all like Bees,
but yet in the Lords name
I quencht their thornes that were on fire
and will destroy the same.
Thou hast with force thrust sore at me,
that I indeed might fall:
But through the Lord I found such helpe,
that they were vanquisht all:
The Lord is my defence and strength,
my ioy, my m •• th and song:
Hee is become for me indeed,
a Sauiour most strong.
The right hand of the Lord our God
doth bright to passe great things:
He causeth voyce of ioy and health
in righteous mens dwellings.
The right hand of the Lord doth bring
most mighty things to passe:
His hand hath the preheminence,
his force is as it was.
I will not dye but euer liue
to vtter and declare
The Lord his might and wondrous power
his workes and what they are.
The Lord himselfe hath chastened,
and hath corrected mee:
But hath not giuen me ouer yet
to death as ye may see.
Set open vnto me the gates
of truth and righteousnesse:
That I may enter into them
the Lords prayse to confesse.
This is the gate euen of the Lord,
which shall not so be shut:
But good and righteous men alway
shall enter into it.
I will giue thanks to thee O Lord,
because thou hast heard me:
And art become most louingly
a Sauiour vnto me.
The stone which ere this time among
the builders was refus'd.
Is now become the corner stone
and chiefely to be vs'd.
This was the mightie worke of God,
this was the Lords owne fact:
And it is merueilous to behold
with eyes that noble act.
This is the ioyfull day indeed,
which God himselfe hath wrought,
Let vs be glad and ioy therein,
in heart, in minde and thought.
Now helpe vs Lord, and prosper vs
we wish with one accord:
Blessed be he that comes to vs,
in the name of the Lord.
God is the Lord that shew'th vs light
• inde ye therefore with cord
Your sacrifice to the altar,
and giue thankes to the Lord.
Thou art my God I will confesse,
and render thanks to thee:
Thou art my God and I will praise
thy mercies towards me.
O giue yee thankes vnto the Lord
for gracious is he:
Because his mercy doth endure,
for euer towards mee.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
BLessed are they that perfect are, and pure in minde and heart:
〈♫〉
Whose liues and conuersa- tion from Gods lawes neuer start. Blessed are
〈♫〉
they that giue themselues his statutes to obserue: Seeking the Lord with
〈♫〉
all their heart, and neuer from him swerue.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
BLessed are they that perfect are, and pure in minde and heart:
〈♫〉
Whose liues and conuer- sa- ti- on from Gods lawes neuer start. Blessed are
〈♫〉
they that giue themselues his sta- tutes to obserue: Seeking the Lord with
〈♫〉
all their heart, and neuer from him swerue.

div.head: TENOR, or Playnsong.
div.p:
☞ 〈♫〉
BLessed are they that perfect are, and pure in minde and heart,
〈♫〉
Whose liues and conuersation from Gods lawes neuer start. Blessed are
〈♫〉
they that giue themselues his statutes to obserue: Seeking the Lord with
〈♫〉
all their heart, and neuer from him swerue.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
BLessed are they that perfect are, and pure in minde and heart:
〈♫〉
Whose liues and conuersation from Gods lawes neuer start. Blessed are
〈♫〉
they that giue themselues his statutes to obserue: Seeking the Lord with
〈♫〉
all their heart, and neuer from his swerue.

lg.l: Doubtlesse such men goe not astray,
nor doe no wicked thing:
Which stedfastly walke in his pathes,
without any wandring.
It is thy will and commandement,
that with attentiue heed:
Thy noble and diuine precepts,
we learne and keepe indeed.
Oh would no God it might thee please
my wayes so to addresse:
That I might both in heart and voyce,
thy lawes keepe and confesse.
So should no shame my life attaint,
whil'st I thus set nine eies:
And bend my minde alwayes to muse
on thy sacred decrees.
Then will I prayse with vpright heart
and magnifie thy name:
When I shall learne thy iudgements iust,
and likewise proue the same.
And wholly will I giue my selfe,
to keepe thy lawes most right:
Forsake me not for euer Lord,
but shew thy graee and might.
By what meanes may a yong man best
his life learne to amend?
If that he marke and keepe thy word,
and therein his time spend.
Vnfainedly I haue thee sought,
and thus seeking abide:
O neuer suffer me O Lord,
from thy precepts to slide.
Within my heart and secret thoughts,
thy word I haue hid still:
That I might uot at any time,
offend thy godly will.
We magnifie thy name O Lord,
and praise thee euermore:
Thy statutes of most worthy fame
O Lord teach me therefore.
My lips haue neuer ceast to preach,
and publish day and night:
Thy iudgements all which did proceed
from thy mouth full of might.
Thy testimonies and thy wayes,
please me no lesse indeed.
Then all the treasures of the earth,
which worldlings make their meede.
Of thy precepts I will still muse,
and thereto frame my talke:
As at a marke so will I aime,
thy wa • es how I may walke
My onely ioy shall be so fixt,
and on thy lawes so set:
That nothing can me so farre blind,
that I thy word forget.
Grant to thy seruant now such grace
as may my life prolong:
Thy holy word then will I keepe
both in my heart and tongue.
Mine eyes which were d • m and shut vp
so open and make bright:
That of thy law and meruailous workes
I may haue the cleere fight.
I am a stranger in this earth,
wandring now here now there:
Thy word therefore to me disclose,
my footsteps for to cleere.
My soule is rauisht with desire,
and neuer is at rest:
But seekes to know thy iudgements hie,
and what may please thee best.
The proud men and malitious,
thou hast destroyde each one:
And cursed are such as doe not
thy hests attend vpon.
Lord turne from me rebuke and shame,
which wicked men conspire:
For I haue kept thy couenants,
with zeale as hot as fire.
The princes great in counsell sate,
and did against me speake:
But then thy seruant thought how he
thy statutes might not breake.
For why? thy couenants are my ioy,
and my great hearts solace:
They serue instead of counsellers,
my matters for to passe.
I am alas as brought to graue,
and almost turn'd to dust:
Restore therefore my life againe,
as thy promise is iust.
My wayes when I acknowledged,
with mercie thou didst heare:
Heare now eftsoone and me instruct
thy lawes to loue and feare.
Teach me once throughly for to know
thy precepts and thy lore.
Thy workes then will I meditate,
and lay them vp in store.
My soule I feele so sore opprest,
that it melteth for griefe:
According to thy word therefore
hast Lord to send reliefe.
From lying and dece • tfull lips,
set thy grace me defend:
And that I may learne thee to loue
thy holy law me send.
The way of truth both strait and sure
I haue chosen and found:
I set thy iudgements me before
which keepe me safe and sound.
Since then (O Lord) I forc'd my selfe
thy couenants to embrace:
Let me therefore haue no rebuke,
nor check in any case.
Then will I run with ioyfull cheare
where thy word doth me call:
When thou hast set my heart at large,
and rid me out of thrall.
Instruct me Lord in the right trade
of thy statutes diuine:
And it to keepe euen to the end
my heart I will encline.
Grant me the knowledge of thy law
and I shall it obey:
With heart and minde and all my might,
I will it keepe I say.
In the right path of thy precepts,
guide me Lord I require:
None other pleasure doe I wish,
nor greater thing desire.
Incline mine heart thy lawes to keepe
and couenants to embrace:
And from all filthy auarice,
Lord shield me with thy grace,
From vaine desires and worldly lusts
turne backe mine eies and sight:
Giue me the spirit of life and power
to walke thy waies aright.
Confirme thy gracious promise Lord
which thou hast made to me:
Which am thy seruant and doe loue
and feare nothing but thee.
Reproach and shame which I doe feare
from me O Lord expell:
For thou doest iudge with equitie,
and therein dost excell.
Behold my hearts desire is bent
thy lawes to keepe for aye:
Lord strengthen me so with thy grace,
that it performe I may.
Thy mercies great and manifold
let me obtaine O Lord:
Thy sauing health let me enioy,
according to thy word.
So shall I stop the slandrous mouths
of lewd men and vniust:
For in thy faithfull promises
stands my comfort and trust.
The word of truth within my mouth
let euer still be prest:
For in thy iudgements wonderfull
my hope doth stand and rest.
And whilst that breath within my brest
doth naturall life preserue:
Yea▪ till this world shall be dissolu'd,
thy law will I obserue.
So walke will I as set at large,
and made free from all dread:
Because I sought how for to keepe
thy precepts and thy reed.
Thy noble acts I will describe,
as things of most great fame:
Euen before Kings I will them blaze,
and shrinke no whit for shame.
I will reioyce then to obey
thy worthy hests and will:
Which euermore I haue lou'd best,
and so will loue them still.
My hand will lift I to thy lawes,
which I haue dearely sought:
And practise thy commandements,
in will, in deed, and thought.
Thy promise which thou madst to me
thy seruant Lord remember:
For therein haue I put my trust,
and confidence for euer.
It is my comfort and my ioy,
when troubles me assaile:
For were my life not by thy word,
my life would soone me faile.
The proud & such as God contemne,
still made of me a scorne.
Yet would I not thy law forsake,
as he that were forlorne.
But call to minde Lord thy great workes
shew'd to our fathers old:
Whereby I felt my ioy surmount,
my griefe an hundreth fold.
But yet alas for feare I quake.
seeing how wicked men
Thy law forsooke and did procure
thy iudgements who knowes when?
And as for me I fram'd my songs,
thy statutes to exalt:
When I among the strangers dwelt,
and thoughts gan me assault.
I thought vpon thy name O Lord,
by night when others sleepe:
As for thy law I also kept,
and euer will it keepe.
This grace I did obtaine because
thy couenants sweet and deare
I did embrace, and also keepe
with reuerence and with feare.
O God, which art my part and lot,
my comfort and my stay:
I haue decreed and promised,
thy law to keepe alway.
Mine earnest heart did humbly sue
in presence of thy face:
As thou therefore hast promised,
Lord graunt me of thy grace.
My life I haue examined,
and tride my secret heart:
Which to thy statutes caused me
my feete straight to conuert.
I did not stay nor linger long,
as they that sloathfull are:
But hastily thy lawes to keepe,
I did my selfe prepare.
The cruell bands of wicked men,
haue made of me their pray:
Yet would I not thy law forget,
nor from thee goe astray.
Thy righteous iudgements towards me
so great is and so hie:
That euen at midnight I will rise,
thy name to magnifie.
Companion am I to all them;
which feare thee in their heart:
And neither will for loue nor dread,
from thy commandements start.
Thy mercies Lord most plentifull
doe all the world fulfill:
Oh teach me how I may obey
thy statutes and thy will.
According to thy promise Lord,
so hast thou with me dealt:
For of thy grace in sundry sorts,
haue I thy seruant felt.
Teach me to iudge alwayes aright,
and giue me knowledge sure:
For certainely beleeue I doe,
that thy precepts are pure.
Ere thou didst touch me with thy rod,
I err'd and went astray:
But now I keepe thy holy word,
and make it all my stay.
Thou art both good and gracious,
and giuest most liberally:
Thine ordinances how to keepe,
therefore O Lord teach me.
The proud and wicked men haue forg'd
against me many a lye,
Yet thy commandements still obserue,
with all my heart will I.
Their hearts are swolne with worldly wealth
as grease so are they fat:
But in thy law doe I delight,
and nothing seeke but that.
O happy time may I well say,
when thou didst me correct:
For as a guide to learue thy lawes,
thy rod did me direct:
So that to me thy word and law,
is dearer manifold:
Then thousands great of siluer and gold
or ought that can be told.
Seeing thy hands hane made me Lord,
to be thy creature:
Grant knowledge likewise how to learne
to put thy lawes in vre.
So they that feare thee shall reioyce,
when euer they me see:
Because I haue learn'd by thy word,
to put my trust in thee.
When with thy rod the world is plagued,
I know the cause is ink:
So when thou dost orrect me Lord,
the cause iust needs be must.
Now of thy goodnesse I thee pray,
some comfort to me send:
As thou to me thy seruant hast,
so from all ill me shend.
Thy tender mercies poure on mee,
and I shall surely liue:
For ioy and consolation both,
thy sawes to me doe giue.
Confound the proud whose false pretence,
is me for to destroy.
But as for me thy hests to know,
I will my selfe imploy.
Who so with reuerence doe thee feare
to me let them retire:
And such as doe thy conenants know,
and them alone desire.
My heart without all wauering,
let on thy lawes be bent:
That no confusion come to me,
whereby I should be shent.
My soule doth faint and ceaseth not
thy sauing health to • aue:
And for thy words sake still I trust,
my hearts desire to haue.
Mine eyes doe faile with looking for
thy word, and thus I say:
O when wilt thou me comfort Lord?
why dost thou thus delay?
As a skin bottle in the smoake,
so am I pa • cht and dride:
Yet will I not out of my heart
let thy commandements slide.
Alas how long shall I yet liue,
before I see the houre:
That on my foes which me torment,
thy vengeance thou wilt poure?
Presumptuous men haue digged pits
thinking to make me sure:
Thus contrary against thy law,
my hurt they doe procure.
But thy commandements are all true,
and causelesse they me grieue:
To thee therefore I doe complaine,
that thou mightst me relieue.
Almost they had me cleane destroyd,
and brought me quite to ground▪
Yet by thy statutes I abode,
and therein succour found.
Restore me Lord againe to life,
for thy mercies excell:
And so shall I thy couenants keepe,
till death my life expell.
In heauen Lord where thou dost dwell
thy word is stablisht sure,
And shall for all eternity,
fast grauen there indure.
From age to age thy truth abides,
as doth the earth witnesse:
Whose ground worke thou hast laid so sure,
as no tongue can expresse.
Euen to this day we may well see,
how all things perseuere:
According to thy ordinance,
for all things thee reuere.
Had it not beene that in thy law,
my soule had comfort sought:
Long time ere now in my distresse,
I had beene brought to nought.
Therefore I will thy precepts aye,
in memory keepe fast:
By them thou hast my life restord,
when I was at last cast.
No wight to me can title make,
for I am onely thine:
Saue me therefore for to thy lawes
mine eares and heart encline.
The wicked men doe seeke my bane,
and therefore lye in wait:
But I the while considered
thy noble acts and great.
I see nothing in this wide world,
at length which hath not end:
But thy commandements and thy word,
beyond all end extend.
What great desire, and feruent loue
doe I beare to thy law?
All the day long my whole deuise
is onely on thy law.
Thy word hath taught me farre to passe,
my foes in policy:
For still I keepe it as a thing
of most excellency.
My teachers which did me instruct,
in knowledge I excell:
Because I doe thy couenants keepe,
and them to others tell.
In wisedome I doe passe also,
the auncient men in deede:
And all because to keepe thy lawes,
I held it aye best reede.
My feete I haue refrained eke
from euery euill way:
Because that I continually
thy word might keepe I say.
I haue not swe •• 'd from thy iudgements,
nor vet shronke any dell:
For why? thou hast me taught thereby
to liue godly and well.
O Lord how sweet vnto my tast
finde I thy words alway:
Doubtlesse no hony in my mouth,
feele ought so sweet I may.
Thy lawes haue me such wisedome learn'd,
that vtterly I hate
All wicked and vngodly waies,
in euery kinde of • ate.
Euen as a lanterne to my feete,
so doth thy word shine bright:
And to my pathes where euer I goe,
it is a flaming light.
I haue both sworne and will performe
most certainely doubtlesse:
That I will keepe thy iudgements iust,
and them in life expresse.
Affliction hath me sore opprest,
and brought me to deaths doore:
O Lord as thou hast promised,
so me to life restore.
The offerings which with heart and voice
most franckly I thee giue,
Accept, and teach me how I may
after thy iudgements liue.
My soule is aye so in my hand,
that dangers me assaile:
Yet doe I not thy law forget,
nor it to keepe will faile.
Although the wicked lay their net •
to catch me at a bay:
Yet did I not from thy precepts
once swe • ue or goe astray.
Thy lawes I haue so claim'd alway
as mine owne heritage:
And why? for therein I delight,
and set my whole courage.
For euermore I haue beene bent,
thy statutes to fulfill:
Euen so likewise vnto the end
I will continue still.
The crafty thoughts & double hearts
I doe alwayes detest:
But as for thy law and precepts,
I count them euer best.
Thou art my hid and secret place,
my shield of strong defence:
Therefore I haue thy promises,
lookt for with patience.
Goe to therefore yee wicked men,
depart from me anone:
For the commandements will I keepe,
of God my Lord alone.
As thou promis'd so performe,
that death me not assaile:
Nor let my hope abuse me so,
that through distrust I quaile.
Vphold me and I shall be safe,
for ought they doe or say:
And in thy statutes pleasure •• ke
will I both night and day.
Thou hast trod such vnder thy feet,
as doe thy statutes breake:
For naught auailes their subtilty
their counsell is but weake.
Like drosse thou casts the wicked out
where euer they • oe or dwell.
Therefore can I as th • statutes,
loue nothing halfe so well.
My flesh alas is taken with feare,
as though it were benumbd▪
For when I see thy iudgements, straight
I am as one astond.
I doe the thing that lawfull is,
and giue to all men right:
Resigne me not to them that would
oppresse me with their might,
But for thy seruant suretie be,
in that thing that is good:
That proud men giue me not the foile,
which rage as they were wood.
Mine eyes with wayting are now blinde,
thy health so much I craue:
And eke thy righteous promise Lord,
whereby thou wilt me saue.
Intreat thy seruant louingly,
and fauour to him show:
Thy statutes of most excellency,
teach me also to know.
Thy humble seruant Lord I am,
grant me to vnderstand
How by thy statutes I may know,
best what to take in hand.
It is now time Lord to beginne,
for truth is quite decayd:
Thy law likewise they haue transgrest,
and none against them said.
This is the cause wherefore I loue
thy lawes better then gold:
Or iewels fine which are esteem'd
most costly to be sold.
I thought thy precepts all most iust
and so them layd in store:
All craftie and malicious waies
I doe abhorre therefore.
Thy couenants are most wonderfull,
and full of things profound:
My soule therefore doth keepe them s •• e,
when they are tride and found.
When men first enter into thy word
they finde a light most cleere:
And very idiots vnderstand.
when they it read or heare.
For ioy I haue both gapt & breath'd
to know thy commandement:
That I might guide my life thereby
I sought what thing it meant.
With mercy and compassion both,
behold me from aboue:
As thou art wont to behold suth
as thy name feare and loue.
Direct my footsteps by thy word,
that I thy will may know:
And neuer let iniquitie,
thy seruant ouerthrow.
From slanderous tongues and deadly hate
preserue and keepe me sure:
Thy precepts then will I obserue,
and put them eke in vre.
Thy countenance which doth surmount
the Sunne in his bright hew:
Let shine on me and by thy law,
teach me what to eschew.
Out of mine eyes great flouds gush out
of dreary teares and fell:
When I behold how wicked men
thy lawes keepe neuer a dell.
In euery point Lord thou art iust,
the wicked though they grudge:
And when thou dost sentence pronounce
thou art a righteous iudge.
To 〈◊〉 right and flee from guile,
are two chiefe points most hye:
And such as thou hast in thy law,
commanded vs straitly.
With zeale and wrath I am confirm'd
and euen pinde away:
To see my foes thy word forget,
for ought that I doe may.
So pure and perfect is thy word,
as any heart can deeme:
And I thy seruant nothing more
doe loue or yet esteeme.
And though I be nothing set by,
as one of base degree:
Yet doe I not thy hests forget,
nor shrinke away from thee.
Thy righteousnesse Lord is most iust
for euer to endure:
Also thy law is truth it selfe,
most constant and most pure.
Trouble and griefe haue seas'd on me
and brought me wondrous low:
Yet doe I still of thy precepts
delight to heare and know.
The righteousnes of thy iudgements
doth last for euermore:
Then teach them me for euer in them
my life lyeth vp in store.
With feruent heart I cald and cride,
now answere me O Lord:
That thy commandements to obserue,
I may fully accord.
To thee my God I make my sute,
with most humble request:
Saue me therefore and I will keepe,
thy precepts and thy hest.
To thee cry I euen in the morne,
before the day waxe light:
Because that I haue in thy word,
my confidence whole plight.
Mine eyes preuent the watch by night
and ere they call I wake,
That by deuising on thy word
I might some comfort take.
Incline thine eare to heare my voyce,
and pity on me take:
As thou was wont so iudge me Lord,
lest life should me forsake.
My foes draw neare and doe procure,
my death maliciously:
Which from thy law are far gone backe
ond straid from it lewdly.
Therfore O Lord approch thou neere
for neede doth so desire:
And all thy precepts true they are,
then helpe I thee require.
By thy commandments I haue learnd
not now but long agoe:
That they remaine for euermore,
thou hast them grounded so.
My trouble and affliction,
consider and behold:
Deliuer me for of thy law
I euer take fast hold.
Defend my good and righteous cause
with speed me succour send:
From death as thou hast promised,
Lord keepe me and defend.
As for the wicked far they are
from hauing health and grace:
Whereby they might thy statutes know
they enter not the trace.
Great are thy mercies Lord I grant,
what tongue can them attaine?
And as thou hast me iudg'd ere now,
so let me life obtaine.
Though many men did trouble me,
and persecute me sore:
Yet from thy lawes I neuer shrunk.
nor went awry therefore.
And truth it is for griefe I die,
when I these traitors see:
Because they keepe no whit thy word,
nor yet seeke to know thee.
Behold for I doe loue thy lawes,
with heart most glad and faine:
As thou art good and gracious Lord,
restore my life againe.
What thy word doth decree, must bee
and so it hath beene euer:
Thy righteous iudgements are also
most true, and decay neuer.
Princes haue sought by cruelty
causelesse to make me couch:
But all in vaine, for of thy word,
the feare did my heart touch.
And certainely euen of thy word,
I was more merry and glad:
Then he that of rich spoiles and prayes
great store and plenty had.
As for all liues and fa • sity,
I hate, most and detest:
For why? thy holy lawes doe I,
aboue all things loue best.
Seuen times a day I prayse the Lord
singing with hart and voice:
Thy righteous acts and wonderfull,
so cause me to reioyce.
Great peace and rest shall all such haue,
which doe thy statutes loue,
No danger shall their quiet state,
empaire or once remoue.
Mine onely health and comfort Lord,
I looke for at thy hand:
And therefore haue I done those things,
which thou didst me command.
Thy lawes haue beene my exercise
which my soule much desir'd:
So much my loue to them was bent,
that nought else I requir'd.
Thy statutes and commandements,
I kept thou know'st aright:
For all the things that I haue done,
are present in thy sight.
O Lord let my complaint and cry
before thy face appeare:
And as thou hast me promise made.
so teach me thee to feare,
My humble supplication,
toward thee let finde accesse:
And grant me Lord deliuerance,
for so is thy promise.
Then shall my lips thy praises speake
after most ample sort:
When thou thy statutes hast me taught
wherein stands my comfort:
My tongue shall sing and preach thy word
and on this wise say shall.
Gods famous acts and noble lawes,
are iust and perfect all.
Streach out thy hand I thee beseech,
and speedily me saue:
For thy commandements to obserue,
chosen O Lord I haue.
Of thee alone Lord I craue health
for other I know none:
And in thy law and nothing else
I doe delight alone.
Grant mee therefore long dayes to liue
thy name to magnifie:
And of thy iudgements mercifull,
let me thy fauour try.
For I was lost and went astray,
much like a wandring sheepe:
Oh seeke me for I haue not faild
thy commandements to keepe.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
IN trouble and in thrall vnto the Lord I call, and he doth me
〈♫〉
comfort. Deliuer me, I say, from lyers lips alway, and tongues of false report.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
IN trouble and in thrall vnto the Lord I call, and he doth mee
〈♫〉
comfort. Deliuer me I say, from lyers lips alway, and tongues of false report.

div.head: TENOR, or Faburden.
div.p:
☞ 〈♫〉
IN trouble and in thrall vnto the Lord I call, and he doth me
〈♫〉
comfort. Deliuer me, I say, from lyers lips alway, and tongues of false report.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
IN trouble and in thrall vnto the Lord I call, and hee doth mee
〈♫〉
comfort, Deliuer me I say, from liers lips away, and tongues of false report.

lg.l: What vantage or what thing,
Gets thou thus for to sting,
Thou false and flattering lier?
Thy tongue doth hurt I weene,
No lesse then arrowes keene.
Of hot consuming fire.
Alas too long I slacke,
Within these tents so blacke:
Which Kedars are by name.
By whom thy flocke elect,
And all of Isaacks sect:
are put to open shame.
With them that place did hate,
I came a peace to make,
And set a quiet life.
But when my tale was told,
Causelesse I was controld,
By them that would haue strife.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
I Lift mine eyes to Si- on hil • , from whence I doe attend,
that succour God me send. The mighty God me succour will, which
〈♫〉
heauen and earth framed, and all things therein na- med.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
I Lift mine eyes to Si- on hill, from whence I doe attend,
〈♫〉
that succour God me send. The mighty God me succour will, which
〈♫〉
heauen and earth framed, and all things therein named.

div.head: TENOR or Playnsong.
div.p:
☞ 〈♫〉
I Lift mine eyes to Si- on hill, from whence I doe attend
☞ 〈♫〉
that succour God me send. The mighty God me succour will, which
〈♫〉
heauen and earth framed, and all things therein named.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
I Lift mine eyes to Si- on hill, from whence I doe attend,
〈♫〉
that succour God me send. The mighty God me succour will, which
〈♫〉
heauen and earth framed, and all things therein named.

lg.l: Thy foote from slip he will preserue,
And will thee safely keepe:
For he will neuer sleepe.
Loe, he that doth Israel conserue,
No sleepe at all can him catch.
But his eyes shall euer watch.
The Lord is thy warrant alway,
The Lord eke doth thee couer,
As at thy right hand euer.
The Sun shall not thee parch by day
Nor the Moone not halfe so bright,
Shall with cold thee hurt by night▪
The Lord will keepe thee from distresse,
And will thy life sure saue:
And thou also shalt haue.
In all thy businesse good successe:
Where euer thou goest in or out,
God will thy things bring out.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
I Did in heart reioyce to heare the peoples voyce, in of- fering so
〈♫〉
willingly: For let vs vp say they, and in the Lords house pray, thus spake the folk
〈♫〉
full louingly, Our feete that wan- dred wide shall in thy gates abide
〈♫〉
O thou Ie- rusalem full faire, which art so seemely set, much like a
〈♫〉
Citie neat, the like whereof is not else where.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
I Did in heart reioyce to heare the peoples voyce, in offering so wil-
〈♫〉
lingly: For let vs vp say they, and in the Lords house pray, thus spake the
〈♫〉
folk full louingly, Our feete that wan- dred wide shall in thy gates abide,
〈♫〉
O thou Ierusalem full faire, which art so seemely set, much like a
〈♫〉
Citie neat, the like whereof is not else where.

div.head: TENOR, or Playnsong.
div.p:
☞ 〈♫〉
I Did in heart reioyce to heare the peoples voyce, in offering so wil-
〈♫〉
lingly: For let vs say they, and in the Lords house pray, thus spake the
〈♫〉
folke full louingly, Our feete that wandred wide shall in thy gates abide▪
☞ 〈♫〉
O thou Ierusalem full faire, which art so seemely set, much like a
〈♫〉
Citie neat, the like whereof is not else where.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
I Did in heart reioyce to heare the peoples voyce, in offering so
〈♫〉
willingly: For let vs vp say they, and in the Lords house pray, thus spake the
〈♫〉
folk full louingly Our feete that wandred wide shall in thy gates abide,
〈♫〉
O thou Ierusalem full faire, which art so seeme- ly set much like a
〈♫〉
Citie neat, the like whereof is not else where.

lg.l: The Tribes with one accord,
The Tribes of God the Lord
Are thither bent their way to take:
So God before did tell,
That there his Israell
Their prayers should together make.
For there are Thrones erect,
And that for this respect,
To set forth iustice orderly:
Which Thrones tight to maintaine,
To Dauids house pertaine,
His folke to iudge accordingly.
To pray let vs not cease,
For Ierusalems peace:
Thy friends God prosper mightily.
Peace be thy walls about,
And prosper thee throughout
thy places eke continually.
I wish thy prosperous state,
For my poore brethrens sake
That comfort haue by meanes of thee,
Gods house doth me allure,
Thy wealth for to procure,
So much alwayes as lyeth in me.

div.head: CANTVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
O Lord that heauen dost possesse, I lift mine eyes to thee:
〈♫〉
Euen as the seruant lifteth his, his maisters hands to see.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
O Lord that heauen dost possesse, I lift mine eyes to thee:

〈♫〉
Euen as the seruant lifteth his, his maisters hands to see.

div.head: TENOR, or Playnsong.
div.l:
☞ 〈♫〉
O Lord that heauen dost possesse, I lift mine eyes to thee:

〈♫〉
Euen as the seruant lifteth his, his maisters hands to see.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.l:
〈♫〉
O Lord that heauen dost possesse, I lift mine eyes to thee:

〈♫〉
Euen as the seruant lifteth his, his maisters hands to see.

lg.l: As handmaids watch their mistris hands,
some grace for to atchieue:
So we behold the Lord our God,
till he 〈◊〉 vs forg ••• ,
Lord grant vs thy compassion.
and mercy in thy sight:
For we are fild and ouercome
with hatred and despight.
Our minds be stuft with great rebuke,
the • ich and worldly wise
Doe make vs of their mocking stocke,
the proud doe vs despise,

div.head: CANTVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
NOw Israel may say, and that truely, if that the Lord had not
〈♫〉
our cause maintaind: If that the Lord had not our right sustaind, When all
〈♫〉
the world against vs furi- ously made their vprores, and said wee
〈♫〉
should all dye.

div.head: MEDIVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
NOw Israel may say, and that truely, if that the Lord had not
〈♫〉
our cause maintaind if that the Lord had not our right sustaind, When
〈♫〉
all the world against vs furiously made their vprores, and said wee
〈♫〉
should all dye.

div.head: TENOR, or Faburden.
div.p:
☞ 〈♫〉
NOw Israel may say, and that tru • ly, if that the Lord had not
〈♫〉
our cause maintaind: If that the Lord had not our right sustaind When
〈♫〉
all the world against vs furiously made their vprores, and said wee
〈♫〉
should all dye.

div.head: BASSVS.
div.p:
〈♫〉
NOw Israel may say, and that truely if that the Lord had not
